Text: It's hard to think of original things to say when it comes to such worked over material as 'why capitalism is bad,' but with this video I decided to focus on happiness and luxury, and their relation to capitalism and socialism, which is not the typical Marxist angle and at any rate is more my style. Or maybe this is just counterrevolutionary, bourgeois revisionism. Let me know what you think!

The worst thing about the modern capitalist economy is that hard work and productivity do not lead to significantly higher earnings.  At one of my jobs, the head cashiers are paid 19% more than almost everyone else. But between 9 and 12 of the 16-18 total cashiers are paid the exact same wage. If I'm not fired, there is no reason for me to put in any extra effort at all. That really is a rigged economy. A person should not have to live far from their work, in the second crappiest apartment available at the end of June, with no savings and no legitimate short/medium promotion possibilities. There is an argument that people who can do more than check (I'm not planning on working min wage my whole life or something myself) should go to college, but then it makes no sense why college should be so expensive. If the goal is a productive society then college should be free/low cost. If the goal is happiness, jobs should pay more and more jobs would be involved in real needs instead of accessories The economy works for neither. It works to ensure that a few people stay wealthy no matter who suffers.

To start. What is the capitalism you are talking about? What do you mean by that?  When I hear the word 'capitalism' I have the same question of its nature as when I hear the word 'god'. Do you think I should 'know' the word 'somehow', because Marx once said somewhere what is the capitalism? Did he define that? If that is what Marx have defined, then Marx have defined some very, very bad thing we should avoid at all costs (meaning, we should avoid using the definition, because it is evil) Now we know that we do not use Marx's definition. Then what else can capitalism be? Obviously, 'not socialism', as Marx have invented the word to create socialism propaganda.   Now, when we have something that is not something else, that something couldn't possibly be guilty of every of society's faults. It is also 'guilty' of every of society's successes as well. It is a natural order of things, which is chaos, and in chaos, what you build works how you've built it - but only for a time, after which it brokes and dissolves into basic components, from many of which consists chaos.   If you've said that our economic system is an ineffective economic system which is bad at distribution of resources - I would've agreed. Justs its not capitalism. Our economic system is bad because it is *economic* system. To be good it should be *spending* system.

Also, even from a profit-driven point of view. The way we distribute income, almost equally makes no sense. For an obvious example, if you're Jeff Bezos and love being even more rich off of Nintendo Switch sales - Africa would be a goldmine market, some much stuff to sell to them. Yet, since not many people have internet let alone a Kindle, there's no purchases.   I'm going to one up you then and say that capitalism is flawed because it priorities *short term gains* over *long term gains*. That's why no-ones doing shit all about climate change, while having all your shops drown in the long term is probably bad and would effect business, in the short term its best not to give a shit and buy more cheap oil power.    Distributism is RATIONAL. Unlike you free market economic inequality-loving low T beta cappy cucks.

This is great. Some suggestions about the way you end it: 1. Everyone, read George Bernard Shaw's 'The Thinking Woman's Guide to Socialism, Capitalism, Sovietism and Fascism'. Lots of helpful ideas there.  2. We make the big online retailers, social media and portals (Amazon, Youtube, Facebook) and the big real world 3D retailers (Walmart, IKEA, etc.) into consortium owned by all their suppliers. That is, if you sell $100 of goods you produced on Amazon, or made  for IKEA to sell, or brought in that amount of ads or worth in postings on Youtube or Facebook, you now own the equivalent in voting shares of that company. Same with Uber drivers etc. So these become instruments of those doing the work, instead of their exploiters. 3. We nationalize a few key things like banks and hedge funds, energy, etc. 4. Green New Deal with Full Employment and public health care etc. 5. A new Bretton Woods (look it up) where the leading countries agree to capital controls to end finance's and investors' ability to move at will around the world and play countries off against each other. 6. Money created ONLY by governments through the now public banks by grants to municipalities and worker-owned cooperatives. Family-size private businesses to remain, big companies converted into being democratically owned and run by all stakeholders. This is not yet quite socialism, but it would no longer be capitalism and would create all the preconditions to create a better system for happiness - and thanks for reminding us that happiness is the point in this video. How to achieve it? We coordinate electoral projects in  every country but back these up with movements ready to do what worked in South Africa, and all nonviolent revolutions: make the country ungovernable (general strikes, occupations etc.). When we gain power locally the city turns resources over to neighborhood assemblies and worker cooperatives. When we win nationally we do the big stuff. That's my suggestion.

You avoid two things.  1)  Communist socialism (ideally) rewards workers equally leading to a downward spiral of performance.  The goal for a worker becomes to get away with doing as little as possible relative to how little work another worker is getting away with doing thus maximizing their pay relative to the amount of work that they do.  2)  Every bad aspect of capitalism can be mitigated by governance.  If governance was thoroughly insulated from capitalist influence so that the interest of the public could always supersede the interests of capitalists, there would be much less disparity, maybe even very little disparity.

Isn't there a simpler way to describe how capitalism doesn't work for the benefit of most of the people?  Something like this:  In feudalism, private land ownership was a tool for the feudal landowner to make money and not the peasant.  There is a finite amount of land and the peasants will never get any of it.  Capital is like land in that it is finite today and is all privately owned.  But capital is unlike land because it is 'increaseable' with the injection of labor or new technology.  But the laborers will only get the market wage for their work, whereas most of the new increase in capital (production) will go to the owners of capital, just like it did under feudalism.   So capitalism may increase the overall production of things, but can only further increase the inequality that already exists.

Hello, back from the other video. You asked to provide reasons for why capitalism isnt bad. Some others have made similar points but I'll go ahead and make them now. While I agree with your criticisms of capitalist society and think it is very important to look at, I think that you fell into the same trap Marx did when writing his book on economic theory. The fact is, as you admit, you do not understand how the economic system works. Which is good that you recognize it, however, I think it is troubling to say you dont understand how it works but then suggest that it should change.  As I said in the last video, I think the major problem comes in when we ascribe some sense of morality to capitalism. The fact is capitalism does not care about morality. It is an objective way in which a system works. I think it is important to understand what the free market is and the invisible hand that guides it. The fact is that capitalism is far better at predicting trends in consumer behavior and innovation. Jobs and specializations for jobs are created because there are opportunities discovered by individuals. Or innovations are made because big business constantly pushes research and development to find new things that none of us ever knew we wanted before.   While I understand you are against a Maoist or Stalinist system I think it is important to understand just how much innovation was made under capitalism and still is being made. All of this creates new jobs and creates new wealth and opportunities. If, as you say, we redistribute the wealth, where does that money go? Well, it will likely go into businesses like Mcdonalds or Amazon. It does not create more wealth, it simply recycles it. This, in turn, means businesses and wealthy people are more hesitant to invest their wealth into research which in turn creates less real wealth.  This isnt to say that redistributing wealth would not help the poorer people. But this would only be helpful in the short run. If you look at the long run you will notice that it will actually hurt the economy overall. The fact is that we live in a world where money is still something that is needed. We can go on a debate about what currency is but that is not what I am looking at in my rebuttel. I only care about objectivity, which is what capitalism is, objectivity.  Another important facet of my argument is to understand the two popular forms of capitalism, that being kaynsian and Hayek. Kaynsian is the popular version which suggests that governments spend money in order to jump start the economy. This was brought about because of the great depression in order to solve the problem of the boom and bust cycle. It is effective in places like Taiwan or the US, however, in the long run it is bad for the economy because it creates crony capitalism. Hayek believes in a free market system which I have talked about above which is the one I am for.  Anyway, I'll leave it at that. TL;DR: I think it is important to study how the economy works. We can agree on philosophy but economics is an objective measure and science, not an art. So I think it is important to understand how it works before suggesting regime change.  Also, good video, I enjoyed it. But this was the major problem with you argument I found.

so... I mean, pretty much everything you addressed in these two parts can be handled by federal government regulations on our current form of capitalism. And it's not that we are currently un-regulated, just that we have to vote the right people into office who really understand how the economy works- and that hasn't been happening. I mean- this is pretty much how Trump won 2016. Promising the working class people that he is going to bring their jobs back to the country, among other things. Capitalism overall is a pretty good system- and our version of it allows for social mobility. If you were born with poor parents, you could invent something- or write a book- or pursue the job you want to have in order to live comfortably. One of the issues- college debt- isn't necessarily because of capitalism, it has grown out of a cultural stigma against being in a tradeskill type job- like a carpenter or a plumber (who make liveable wages) and social pressure that one 'can't be successful if they don't go to college' which is a false premise. One doesn't *need* college to be successful. Anyway- I just heard your name come up on WBEZ chicago radio and decided to look up some old videos. Nice work with the criticism, and good on you to avoid advocating for an overly dramatic shift in the economy! And I agree with some points, and hopefully we can fix the broken systems that allow for big corporate entities to have control over the majority of assets.

I think this was an excellent  video and brought up some really interesting points. I'd like to address a few things you touched on  Income inequity has more to do with how much money you can make your employer (eg. How valuable you are to the company you work for) and/or how easy it would be to replace you and your skill set. It should not be thought that your income corresponds with how hard you work.  Sweatshop workers make less because they are easy to replace as they require a low skill set. To some extent, employers see employees as a commodity and means to an end. Just like you need soap to clean your floors you need factory workers to make your products. And like any smart business person, you want to pay the least amount as possible and still get the job done.  In regard to capitalism I would agree that it would be better for use to move away from it to something more socialist/communist. A lot of people would say that communism has never worked and they would be right. I think the issue has less to do with the morals of communism and has more to do with regards to the flaws of humanity. Humans are, by nature, competitive and selfish. I don't think we can, as a species, handle communism. The best we can hope for is to allign the goals of those with power with that of those without. For the most part, capitalism does a fair, albeit far from perfect, job at this.

The real problem with capitalism is that people aren't taught how to properly use the system. To get a good job, you have to have a skill thats in need. This doesn't mean you need a bachelor's degree, jobs like electrical work and plumbing both get fine pay, more than a english major. We're taught that you have to go to college even if all that does is rack up debt in the end.

This may sound redundant, but bad capitalism is very bad, and there is a lot of bad capitalism in the USA and the world in general. I'm not even going to argue that. The thing about liberal capitalist democracy is that ideally it should invite criticism. We call this free speech. Historically we have struggled with this and as a result we wind up with bad capitalism and oppression. However a surplus is always going to be needed to feed everyone and to create a stable working class that lives in comfort. Well call this surplus, profit, and the system of making this surplus capitalism. That's it. It's only as good or as bad as the people who use it, like any technology or social theory. So I invite criticism of capitalism, and in the case of injustice, protest, not to destroy it but to make it better, and more ethical. Which is what I call good capitalism, because good capitalism evolves, and adapts to fit the needs of the people who live wherever it is being practiced. I also invite social programs that are funded by the surplus in the form of taxes to combat poverty, medical care, infrastructure, education, and climate change. Republicans call this socialism but they are building a straw man to win elections (the same way leftists build a straw man out of capitalism to win arguments on the internet). Others call this social democracy but I think this down plays the fact that it is still built around a free market stock exchange. Revolutions don't work, they replace bad leaders with even worse leaders, and I feel completely comfortable saying this about the American revolution. Would the trail of tears have happened if the USA had remained a British colony? Would the USA as it is now have become so anglicized that it gave white supremacy some perceived scientific and therefore legal justification? Would chattel slavery have lasted as long as it did, and the civil war have even happened? Would there be a crisis at the border if manifest destiny ideology not been at the crux of conquering the western half of what is now the USA? Would the USA be so contrarian in dealing with climate change with it's allies if we didn't resent European elitism and lump academics in with that the way we do?  I can't answer any of these questions, but I do think about them,  but the only reason I can think and ask these questions (definitely not because I was born brilliant) is because I have the privileges and education that the surplus of capitalism has provided me and my family, and I have the freedom of speech, the right to assemble, and the right to vote as a constitutional right at least as a white person that is a natural born citizen. This allows for some political action and protests, and that is power that has value! So yes, lets redistribute wealth, rights, and citizenship to all people of all genders, races, and nationalities; but I can't imagine it happening any other way than through a system of ethical trade that generates a surplus that is fueled by economic competition coupled with a rigorous political process where all citizens can vote. This is not the USA that I live in, but I think it could be. Maybe I'm wrong, and I'm not thinking creatively enough, but I am highly skeptical of revolutionaries. Not because we are different but because we are so similar. From my experience some people with power have good intentions, and evil is just a matter of their careless incompetence, and apathy coupled with the opportunism of people who think they are righteous. I think calling what I'm talking about 'socialism' is a cop out. It's capitalism, ethical capitalism; and it will still have shiny stuff, movies and video games, ideally without the abuse. This will never fix everything but it can make lives better and inspire people to think up creative solutions that will benefit everyone, but I don't know, and I'm going to pretend to have all the answers. Feel free to call me an apologist because that's exactly what I am.

Dear Contra, thank you for such a well made statement. However, it only poses more questions then it brings answers. It appears to me that the problem with golden pizza is not just a problem with luxury items or capitalism, but with human thinking in general. Take the other examples of luxury. Things like Ferrari cars or Patec Philippe watches. Where will be their place in the socialist utopia? This products are insanely hard to produce which is making them very scarce in supply, still they are being valued and wanted. It can be said that their value is merely a social construct, and still they are, unarguably products of virtue. Patec Philippe and Ferrari employs specialists of godly qualification that put their life for creation of these products. They don't merely do this as passion or charity - they want to be rewarded for their rear talent and hard work by recognition, money and extreme value for their products. It is only possible if there is a certain degree of gatekeeping that creates the distance between them and other specialists, parallel to how it creates distance between their consumers and those that can not afford their product. Even if those products exist merely to show the perceived superiority of their owners, this superiority may be the may be the condition for self-betterment and innovation. People want to better themselves to be valued and they want to hold attributes of their value. Self-betterment and professionalism exists only if there is a distance between it and mediocrity, and it has to be expressed adequately - in money or filthy-rich shiny stuff that others can not afford. So since we are all philosophical - what will be the place of high professionalism in socialist utopia? What will it be expressed in? How will it be rewarded? Thank you!

I grew up in a society that experienced a huge shift from a socialist planning economy to capitalism (eastern Germany) - I was just 6 when the wall came down and of course our lives radically changed. I am a child of capitalism... but i grew up in a society marked by socialism (and russian glorification). There was this stupid joke that went something like the eastern equivalent of Alice in Wonderland is Olga in Aldi. But that excess of product was just... unimaginable. There. was. no. Competition between products. The government mandated what would be produced and that was the one kind of THING you could chose and everybody was the same. This system didn't work, but i wonder how it would have looked like, if the planning was perfect and allowed for individualization (people want to express themselves and felt they could do that with super expensive products from the west. Also there was an economic war going on... eastern consumer products rarely were as good as western ones, which became highly more desirable.)  Close relatives were a die hard believers in that system. But one of them lost her mind when she was allowed to work in a camp for western teenagers. She did realize, how much better the food was and the beds and just everything - why weren't eastern teenagers sleeping in the same kind of holiday accomondation? Sometimes... the Westerners left gum or hairbands behind, that were ... actually good. She was brainwashed into thinking that all these good products came at a very high cost of ideological downfall (which is true in some respect - but was the same in the east.)  One of my main observations was, that the sheer lack of products lead to a much closer knit society that had to help themselves. Creativity in obtaining products, a swelling black market. And the people were generally much more naive. Every customer wins / congratulations, you're the 1millionth visitor, here is your iphone? You bet ALL people would have believed that. But i am not sure, if that was purely the market or also the system with heavy surveillance and untrustworthy news / brainwashing.   It was forbidden to go to the west (traveling). I pestered my teachers and parents about that. Didn't you think that was unfair? Didn't you realize, you were prisoners? Weren't you angry at the government? Didn't you see the WALL? (it was there to protect us! not guard us...) Well, who is angry at the government for not being able to visit the moon? It was just the same category of unlikely and impossible - that's how the successful brainwashing worked.   I do thinkt he people were happier and way less stressed*. You had no real choice in what you were going to become, but money didn't matter that much anyway. Rent was cheap, childcare free of charge, everybody had work (be it thinly disguised busy work...) - *that is, if you were happy with the system. If you were critical....

Very amusing, and nice to stray from my usual conservative fare into the 'BreadTube'. But I think you undersell the sophistication and beauty of markets.   The golden pizza sucks, and that's why under capitalism practically no one consumes it. Costs are high and utility is low, so it is in very low demand - it's just a crass, niche joke for the uber rich. But under communism, we may not really know the true costs of creating such a pizza. Rather than following market signals (which average the PRIVATE information and preferences of millions of individuals into a single price: PRICES ARE AGGREGATED PREFERENCE-COST INFORMATION), communists produce as much as the politburo dictates. This is necessarily arbitrary, because they do not know how much gold pizza we truly want. Under communism, I could easily imagine a scenario where MORE golden pizza was being produced as a percentage of the total economy (it was dictated in some 5 year plan for whatever reason, and they continued being manufactured and thrown in a well for decades). This is not a joke. They almost killed the whales for arbitrary reasons: URL  So while I find your critiques of capitalism fine and reasonable, when you have to offer an alternative, there is simply nothing there. This is the classic 'least bad alternative' formulation of liberal capitalism. I think this is the despair of the far left AND right: they have no plausible alternative to the neoliberalism they so despise.  Incrementalism is necessary. Capitalism may ultimately undermine itself, so may liberalism. But it reminds me of what Peterson said about how Marxists under-estimate the depth of the problem of inequality. This is his point on lobsters - inequality is baked into the nature of existence itself, like the incel skulls. It is the pareto principle, and the hypergamy of the femoids... This is why JP cries when he talks about Pinocchio and Dostoevsky... it is the tragic nature of life itself. Marxists identify this tragedy with materialism and the economic system, but by under-estimating the depth of the problem, and make the tragedy radically worse. Soviet and Maoist communism weren't just 'kinda bad'. Hundreds of millions of people perished. Their historic cultures were wiped out and had to be restarted. The corruption even infected the human soul, which was the point of Solzhenitsyn. Your critique of Peterson was too flippant because you don't seem to recognize this argument, and anyways it is not Peterson's argument, he is just repackaged Dostoevsky-Solzhenitsyn. Make a video ContraPointing that.

Socialism fails both in theory and in practice while capitalism succeeds in both. Your argument boils down to: 'theres a bunch of stuff going on that's not good under our capitalist system, therefore socialism', this is fallacious in two ways.   Firstly being that our society nowadays cannot really be called capitalist, the amount of bureaucratic, unnecessary regulation that is placed upon every level of the economy stifles growth and innovation to a considerable degree, to the point where some parts of the Chinese economy is less regulated than that of the USA. Also business are able to successfully lobby the government  to pass competition stifling regulation very easily.   Secondly, capitalism necessarily produces an imperfect outcome, meaning it will never be as good as socialism in the mind of a fervent Marxist. Capitalism is in many ways the lack of an economic system, and is the product of people just acting freely in accordance with certain moral rules. Compare capitalism in the real world to socialism in the real world, one system consistently produces authoritarian regimes and failing economies while the other works to gradually raise the living standards of all while allowing the rights of the individual to come first.

Does what you earn belong to you or does it belong to everyone else? Yes you Could buy 100 meals for 1000 dollars or you could buy one meal for 1000 or any other variation of cost but in the end it is what you have earned that you are trading out for sustenance. Currency isn't something you just hold it is made to be traded, The business that made the $1000 pizza now has 1000 dollars that then Could be used to buy 100 kids $10 meals. Nothing was lost in the transaction, People are allowed to be stupid with their money.  Now the reason why people are more stressed by earning more money is not because of Golden Pizza but instead that rich people have to balance finances for their income i.e. People are rich because they created an economy at their own risk (economic or personal) and doing so is *Stressful.* The key factor is that these people created an income rather than making a labor trade with someone with more money. That's why sweat shop workers aren't millionaires, they rely on an individual to give them money rather than several individuals. However Sweatshops are an overseas concept today and they're communist over there.-\_(tsu)_/- We aren't a planned economy here so there is no point arguing against it. Since there are problems with the economy, it is better to see it as a flow than static structure like a river. If people aren't receiving water because water doesn't flow to them is that because A. They are somewhere where the water never flows or B. The water was redirected? In either case we want to either move the people to the water or move the water to the people, any way that it is achieved will have its own hurdles as is life. Therefore if People aren't receiving what they need to survive (in this case money) we have to look at Why that is, if down the river it's that someone is choking the source then unchoke it. We don't want to flood the river (inflation) or cause a drought (prevent money from moving) but a choke is not the same thing as a dam so we will be safe by removing the choke.

Interesting. Your video definitely gets into the details of *why* we think certain things under the current economic system is bad; however, I don't know if you point at the right things to change in order to make things better. For example, my first response would be 'Why capitalism? We live in a system tainted by corporatism.' I do know that this response is very surface-level and doesn't really get at the heart of what we *actually* need to be discussing, but I think it may get us closer at the very least. That being said, I think your video is still quite important in the discussion. Thank you.

The argument that capitalism is materialistic doesn't really resonate with me. I lean to the right on the free-market spectrum, but open to changing my mind.   I rent a small room in an apartment with 2 roommates. I don't own a car. I walk/bike/uber around town (suburban Atlanta). I'm a minimalist and all my possessions can fit in two suitcases. What I love about the free market is the diverse ecosystem of services and experiences, and new things are being innovated every day that make it even less necessary to own material possessions. I don't have cable tv. I don't read magazines. I avoid crowded places with billboards. I don't feel constantly bombarded with advertising, and so I don't understand why people who feel there's too much advertising don't just remove themselves from the places where all that advertising is.  I'm in favor of a social safety net, and making the current safety net more generous. I'm in favor of progressive tax system, and making our current rates more progressive. I also think markets are amazing things and central planning and too much government regulation can be bad. I think that makes me some kind of social democrat. I grew up in Canada, have worked for non-profits supported by government grants, was a member of a labor union for 10 years, and have some perspective on how some of these ideas have all sorts of unintended consequences.  I love your other videos and would love to hear more from you on what you think of specific proposals from the left, for example: single payer healthcare, federal job guarantee, universal basic income.

I've been working at Merrill (formerly Merrill-Lych) for a few months now as an executive intern for an acquisitions manager and what I think most people seem to miss in the conversation of capitalism is that capitalism is amoral at it's core. Capitalism is a robot designed to generate the largest amount of money possible, irrespective of the implications of those robotic processes. The morality of applied capitalism is much more a function of government regulation than of economic purity. Human intervention on capitalism is what got us here in America in trouble. As the capitalist machine grew, politicians hijacked it for their own benefit.

Okay, I've just sharpened my quill so, lets start with the question: What defines capitalism? Private ownership. Okay, that's found in literally every society, since even the bushmen has their own lionsloth. Add private ownership of means of production. You get feudalism. Just to note, when you live in a comunist hunter and gatherer tribe where there is redistribution of products of work, then just forget that you alone would benefit from your work. Even the most stinky douche from your tribe will have a share from the hunt and if you mind it, you're out. Add explotiong of the worker. Not going for the same answer twice, but the institution of slavery or even servantery (? is it a word?) that is ancient and world-wide is also a nice example. So how about exchange value - look at Kula trade of Polynesians, the most precious thing they can imagine is a shell armbend (quite pretty just for the record) and it's use value is like for any jewelery, it's so valued because it has a symbolic value, it's about prestige. Well that's pretty fetishistic. And they also trade other things among their tribes instead of producing them alone so that's pretty capitalist of them. You know, even if you look at the gift economy like Mauss described, it's always the same principle, people evaluate the thing according how much it seems valueble, there's no 'use value' or 'value derived from work' since it's all arbitrary  'well how it kinda seems it should be priced, guys, what do you think it should be? value' , and than they give and expect to get your payment in another gift or your loyalty (there it goes the reification of social relations) but no one's giving a thing for free, it's all cold calculation and promise of profit. Income defferences - royalty. But I really like a feature that was described by Wallerstein: capitalism is supposed to be built on protestant etique which means work and work and work and be modest, don't spent, so there's gonna be plently of product just stickin' in your butt completely unused. So there's the seed of the bottomless pit of the throat of a capitalist, the bottomles abyss in their heart, the thing is not what it is, but what drives it: the infinite accumulation. That you would take the surplus value and innovate so you can make more and get the surplus and innovate and get even more until your anal cavity explodes! But as I said, you can observe an interesting shift in the reasoning: the definition derived from 'why', from the motivation. And where do you get a motivation? Well, from your values, and those are provided from your world-view, your cosmology, your religion, they tell you what you should value, what you should want, what you should do with your life. Let's imagine that those managers and CEOs and owners would just one they say: okay you know what, I think I had enough, I just don't need more zeros on my account, I'll just give another profit to emprove the health care system for common people. Nuh-uh, no way that would happen. Because mummy didn't say: boy, you should built a state where everyone's happy, no, she said: boy, beat them all and be the best, and when you make something then shove it up your butt immeadiately. I repeat, immediately, or those poor basterd will rip you off. Just ask yourself: would you prefer, your kid to be succesfull, capable, smart and rich or good hearted? Aha! so there we go. Capitalism is not a living thing that you can fight, no don't be delusional, it's a tool. It's a tool in hands of people that use it idioticaly, because the good old fashioned christian values are now not good enough anymore and weren't replaced by any other system. Today's world-view that drives us is generally absolute shit, it's incoherent and it's explanatory potential is near zero so people concentrate on the lowest drives and every low-selary worker, if he got the opportunity to be rich, would just kick the asses of his once commerades, because now he made it to the top and that's the thing! Most people are ill-equipped to deal with social question of a complex globalized society and the postmodernism culture is not helping much as an answer for it because most people can't handdle the fact that 'nobody knows what the fuck the truth is', so they just hole up. So you know, when someone says: 'I don't really like capitalism' they say 'I kinda mind that the world is a cruel place and it seems we're all fucked' and the cure for it is then not 'let's fight capitalism, the economic system that provides the most opportunities and freedom of invention and desire' but rather 'let's find some world-view providing values that would enable to use capitalism in a way that the majority of population wouldn't get fucked in the ass, and also provide a lifestyle that makes as little damage to the psyche as possible. I've spoken.

Capitalism doesn't have to fail and there need not be a revolution. The great thing about capitalism is it invites competition. Organizations can be created, anything you want, and it can compete with established organizations that create inequality. The problem is the perception of the masses---people love Steve Jobs, but he would not have succeeded in business if he were not able to convince people to invest in his ideas. Jobs was loved by people because of his success--after the fact, not before. When the masses decide to love inventors, makers, etc., because of their socialist leanings as well as their ideas before they become successful--to invest in them, then things will change for the better.    And, I blame the Jews for circumcisions. I am missing my foreskin and I demand reparations. (I looked for a lawyer to represent me in this matter, but unfortunately, all the good ones I know and trust are Jewish. Oh well.)  (this is my attempt at humor, before I go on a rant.)    And, I blame them for interest rates. Which is true, Jews did invent interest--the tool currently being used to enslave. After all, I could build you house that lasts for 500 years and amortization the cost over 300 years without charging interest at all, if I had the wealth for the initial sunk cost--but that is too much for most people to think about, I imagine. It is all a fiction that seems like a force of nature--but it is made up. Interest rates are determined by the Fed, and mortgages are for 30 years usually and a house will last from 30 to 60 years. All convenient numbers nobody bothers to question. But I could do a mortgage in house, without the government and without interest and still make a modest profit, if I only had the initial sunk cost to kick off a construction/lending organization designed to last for millennia--like the Catholic Church, for example--(Notre Dame, 800 years old, while the little slaves live in disposable housing). Religions figured this stuff out already.   Any takers on kicking me some money--I need about 250 million to make a go  of it--so I can build really affordable housing, excellent for the environment, will keep people safe in a hurricane and last for 500 years? Probably not. If I made 250 million on my own, would I build houses with it to prove my point? Maybe. But why should I? Where were all the detractors of capitalism who supported my socialist ideas but wouldn't invest in them when I was starting out? Maybe not.    All the problems can be solved in the capitalist system we already have. The problem is human nature, which won't change. I am a nobody, so why listen to me? But I need you now so I can bring about equality. If I were millionaire, if I were extremely successful, people would pay attention---but then I don't need people, I am already successful--why should I help the little people now that I am rich? No one would listen to me when I was poor and full of idealism.   So, don't blame capitalism. Take a good look in the mirror. People live in houses with granite counter tops and foundations so pathetic a new industry has sprung up that specializes in fixing cracked foundations----and this is normal. Instead of building fireproof homes we have smoke detectors and about 3000 deaths a year due to house fires, mostly the very young and very old--and this is normal.    The world is exactly the way people want it to be and it won't change no matter the form of government. A revolution would change a damn thing--there would still be the haves and the have nots.

Truth behind capitalism: every human wants to have a higher income, but buys a cheaper goods. So, cheapiest goods, that people are buying in largest amounts, are literrally MADE OF bad working conditions, most likely, in third-world countries.   But what an average socialist wants? EXACTLY the same. But FOR ALL THE PEOPLE. But if we take practice, not the theory, the equilibrium is impossible, because people expect different 'ideal incomes' and have different ideas about 'fair price'. So, if if you want every worker to earn $ 70,000 a year, then you can't make pizza worth a dollar. The purchasing power of these 70,000 dollars will fall, and the level of 'comfortable' income will increase.

Marx described the problem in that the capitalist alienates the labor of the worker and takes a substantial part of the real value to himself, forming inequality. But if you try to install the anti-capitalist system locally, this added value will still flow away - in the form of cheaper goods that will be sold in the capitalist markets. A really good example of this is China.

12:20 Generally, I think there are two main reasons why upper management and executive positions are payed far more than positions lower in the command chain. The first is to provide motivation for entry-level employees to work harder. If the higher paycheck is something to be envied, then it can be seen as a goal to work towards. I can't speak for everyone, but speaking for myself, I like the idea of being paid more for better work because I know I'm going to work as hard as I can. If my best just isn't good enough, at least I know the best product is getting put out there. The second reason I think the pay gap is so wide is that executives (should) carry the responsibility for every downfall the company may face. (See 'Sword of Damocles') If the company takes a hit, it should be the executive's responsibility to ensure they stay afloat. If not, it's the captain who must go down with the ship to ensure that the rest survive. Obviously not all executives are so virtuous. I do believe the pay gap between the lowest employees and top executives in certain companies are beyond ridiculous because it exceeds the risk that being in the position of power entails, (Disney, Apple, Comcast, just to name a few) but I think these problems can be solved within the capitalist system. The simplest answer would be to just stay humble. Obviously that's not very realistic as it can't really be enforced by anyone. Maybe CEOs shouldn't be allowed to earn more than 1000 times more than their lowest paid employees? Idk, maybe they'd just outsource all their work to independent contractors or robots then. Maybe companies should be allowed more freedom to vertically integrate, granting them direct power over the distribution apparatus. It could a sort of 'i do me, you do you' sort of thing. I don't know, I'm not an economist.  On an unrelated note, the concept of measuring an economic system's efficiency by levels of happiness seems to be attributing issues not inherent to capitalism itself to a society that merely happens to be capitalist (granted, you could argue it's not even 'real' capitalism, whatever that means). As for what exactly IS causing capitalist malaise, I can't really say. As for me, I'm happy enough I guess. I don't get much, but I have enough. I don't give much, but I give what I can when I can. To be honest I don't really expect much either. Capitalism seems to be working for me just fine. It's not like some lizard-man snuck up behind me and injected me with depression-anxiety juice in order to brainwash me into buying more stuff to fill the gaping void in my heart.  I don't hold any of these to be ultimate truth. I'm still learning and I just accept whatever makes the most sense. If you can prove me wrong, please do. I assure you I will be more than willing to listen.

I think there are some much stronger versions of the argument for Capitalism that you preemptively attacked.  For the sake of brevity, I'll make the strongest versions of those arguments without what I personally think of them.    The first two are connected so I'll deal with them together Real income inequality from wage labour exists primarily because of differences in labour productivity and degree market concentration, rather than being determined by how hard someone works. If cleaners and medical researchers were paid the same, assuming labour supply is wage elastic, diminishing marginal returns on labour means that the value of the greater cleaning done is less than the value of the medical research lost. Income is not the only determinant of where labour is allocated or how hard people work but it is an important one - if teachers were paid as much as investment bankers there would be a lot more teachers.  If you're a utilitarian, the fact that income doesn't correlate with how hard someone works doesn't matter in and of it's self, if you're not that Nozick's defence is the classic one, although slavery, class and oligopsony mean that property was neither attained fairly nor is the transaction fair.     The third argument is just poor, but it is entirely true that what interest group you align with informs what you advocate for, even if that has no bearing on the argument in and of itself.    The argument that socialism will inherently turn into authoritarian dictatorship is that by giving the state complete economic power, as would be the way to achieve socialism without using revolutionary methods is that a) a lack of economic freedom is a type of oppression itself b) that there will be resistance to this and, if one rejects democratic methods, dictatorship will have to be established to enforce socialism and c) that giving the state this much power will make it much more able to abuse it's power and that Marxist ideologies creates opponents who are considered justified targets for revenge and finally that there will be no one who has any actual ability to put a check on state power.   Straw men really annoy me.

As I see it, the main issue with corporate structure as it is, is that the low pay workers genuinely aren't generating much value. They are often being paid according to market value, which is determined by a large number of things, like potential value generated and rarity of skills. Keep in mind that companies need gain something when they hire a person. When you see companies like Walmart with lots of low value workers, those bits add up, and there's really not that much that can be done, at least from a business perspective, with that money that doesn't look like a waste. Add in to this the competition between companies to attract and keep competent executives, and you start to see where some of this pay inequity comes from.

Really appreciate the nuance. I find myself conflicted a bit, and perhaps it's mostly semantic. It could also be because my partner is a self pronounced anarcho-capitalist and I've grown tired of debating him (and being called a communist) ((I still love him, he's a treasure)).  Capitalism as he understands it is...just the exchange of goods, and that the real enemy is the state; that a world devoid of the state would naturally turn towards capitalism and individualism, creating networks of exchange and, apparently, champagne for all.  I hear that criticism to a degree. Capitalism on the small scale seems to serve the common good, at least for individuals....but then that's assuming that you alone make, harvest, find, homestead, all your product, and that all other people you collaborate with do the same, or that you at least don't violate the sacred Non Aggression Principle (NAP) @_@  In part one you mentioned that capitalism only maintains it's power by the state. Not to be a tabbyist (I grew out of my catgirl phase), but it would seem like the best course of action would be to actively erode the state by creating grass-roots institutions that serve the community. Like, instead of police we organize our local communities to be something akin to minutemen militias with less hatred for the english and more an emphasis on grabbing your shit and hitting the street when Old Lady Minerva down the block accidentally sets her kitchen on fire again while baking quiche. Food pantrys are another good example, and if expanded might they not be able to erode the deathgrip big box stores have on our world? But then, I suppose there is a loss of luxury standing in the breadlines, unless the bread is covered in gold or something...  It's a complicated issue to be sure. I think that there are moves we can make in the now that can actively affect neoliberalism, which I think it a more effective target than either the state or capitalism. The state seems, to me, to be an emergent property of human social dynamics. John has the biggest stick so John gets to make the rules. As Thucydices (yay greek) said 'The strong must do what they can and the weak must suffer as they must' (he was probably a giant asshole). There does seem to be some real, depressing truth to that. Just as capitalism disperses wealth in horribly inefficient ways, it seems like humans, be they communist, capitalists, fascists, anarchist, or what have you, tend towards dispersing power in terribly inefficient ways.  I'm just a transy theologian, so I don't really know what I'm talking about. Maybe we're all just fucked :D I don't have any answers either, but I really appreciate seeing a sister speak on these issues with critical nuance and not just peddling REVOLUTION!!!! and promoting smashing up a starbucks. Good video(s). However, there is a serious problem with your critique. The word 'inequity' assumes that value is objective and well-defined from the perspective of the economic system as a whole. But the reality is that value is fundamentally subjective, which means that different people value different things differently and at different times. A glass of water is not worth the same to a person lost in an arid desert as it is to a person standing next to a natural spring. Similarly, the wage disparity between a CEO and a janitor is bound to reflect the comparative difficulty of finding a person to fill each position. Capitalism is not a coherent set of values or beliefs. It is not an ideology in the same vein that Marxism is an ideology. Capitalism is an umbrella term for a set of phenomena that arise as a result of the subjectivity of value. The same phenomena will emerge in a communist, socialist, or anarchist society, even though the currency may be power instead of money.

While purer forms of capitalism genuinely do have the problems raised in this video, I don't believe getting rid of capitalism entirely is the answer, or is even possible. As long as people are willing to trade they will not be able to eradicate currency, and any attempt to prevent capitalism from recreating itself out of simple trade due to people all having different wants will require a form of law enforcement which must operate above the ordinary citizen, creating a heirarchical inequality again, blah blah 1984 or something.  The reality is that things can't be evenly distributed when people can't percieve it as an even distribution, and that's simply to do with the problem of wealth & income inequality.  Another problem is ads. There would be no ads if there were no free markets, right? Yeah maybe, *but* there would also be no ads if there were anti-advertisement restrictions placed on still capitalist marketplaces. This would mean people would have to start shopping by product reviews and prices, helping with the realization that the best product isn't always the most expensive and the best place to buy it isn't always the one they saw on TV that one time.  But what about free content? Donation-based content! Public grant funded content!  But what about patents and trademarks? Can't people and corporations own monopolistic rights towards distribution of certain products? Yes, but having currency doesn't mean having patent and trademark laws. Abolish them, but like, in a slower way than actually just abolishing them outright. Replace them with a system of giving credit, like many copyleft lisences have, where instead of making sure nobody else can steal your idea, you gotta make sure they have to say it was your idea.  So what about the people who live in poverty, those who can't afford the basic human rights? Get some goddamn social infrastructure in place so that everyone can afford to live regardless.  But what about the lazy asses who will try to just live off welfare and not work a day in their life? Well good thing they're not getting killed off, as you can tell though living off of social infrastructure isn't exactly a life of luxury either, which is good if they don't deserve luxury.  But what if they can't work? More social infrastructure. Have them prove or and provide them compensation.  Basically I believe in capitalism, but without ads, patents, or trademarks. I'm open to hear what others have to say about this.

One of the few effective things that I think people can do to resist or revolt under a capitalist system is to try to even out economic inequality. This means coming up with low-cost, low upkeep systems that make basic necessities more accessible to everybody. A prime example would be starting a community garden or convincing established institutions or businesses to dedicate some of their property to edible landscaping for anyone to harvest. Alternatively, find ways for people to benefit from what others are throwing out. If you can turn something that is effectively viewed as garbage into something of value, you have effectively created more wealth from something that was being squandered and likely cost little. Obviously, this could be done corruptly by a corporation, but when the goods or profits made through upcycling benefit the underserved and impoverished, you have essentially fabricated additional wealth, which could provide a slight advantage to those struggling to thrive in a corrupt economic system.

Proof of this can be spotted at any Goodwill where you will find the state of the art electronics of ten years ago collecting dust in the corner. CRT television anyone? The arguments you address here are the sort of low-brow arguments you hear mostly from conservatives who don't actually understand how or why capitalism works (or at least, how it could work if we had better economic policies). They are not the arguments you'll hear from educated neoliberals or classical liberals. I'm not exactly advocating cutthroat small-state capitalism, nor do I think you would be particularly sympathetic to the arguments of its advocates. On the other hand, if you were to look at social-democratic economists or neoliberal economists who favour redistribution, I think you would not only have a better understanding of its advocates, but you'd also be able to make a much more insightful criticism of it, as you are already making very insightful videos on other topics.

Capitalism is good, actually.  Okay well, capitalism is pretty shitty as you've made an excellent case for, but markets are a necessity. Neoliberals do not defend capitalism on grounds that some people *deserve* more income than others. In fact many neoliberals (though certainly not all) are very much in favour of minimizing what we call consumption inequality (which differs from wealth inequality because it is decidedly in the interest of society if investors are allowed to keep investing).   In Scandinavian countries, we have a habit of redistributing incomes and making tax exemptions for certain services. This is a pretty good approach and you can see how it works with regards to making living sustainable for everyone (well, almost everyone - Scandinavia has an extremely grim side as well that is rarely seen but that's another discussion)   Now, neoliberals do happen to span a very broad spectrum and differ a lot with regards to what they think about helping the poor, but the kinds of neoliberals I am in the interest of defending will tell you that a healthy economy does not require huge inequality in living standards, and that redistribution and social safety nets are actually often helpful as they allow people to take risks and become entrepreneurs without risking having to live a very hard life if they fail. Poverty, in other words, is not a necessity in a well-regulated capitalist economy; it is rather the property of lacking regulation which largely stems from the particular kind of regulation needed seeming undesirable and making for a poor political platform.  Let's examine this latter claim for a moment: What sort of regulation is needed for a prospering economy wherein people can work minimum wages and still live in decent apartments, support their family, eat decently, and have adequate healthcare? Well, since too high minimum wages are harmful to economic efficiency, this will need to be achieved at least in part through redistribution, such as via a universal basic income or a negative income tax - a welfare state, in other words. Now, as we all know, a welfare state is extremely expensive and the money has to come from somewhere. Ergo, we need to remove corporate taxes and capital gains taxes, raise VAT and income taxes *a lot*, and make people pay more environmental taxes and property taxes. It would take a while to explain why this is the proper approach, but for quick confirmation you can use Google and confirm that this is indeed the Scandinavian model. Considering the optics though, it is easy to see why it is hard to implement a welfare state in the USA.  TL;DR: You're exactly right in wanting to redistribute the champagne, but this can be done within a capitalist economy, and in fact it ought to be. Don't redistribute investments (ie. taxing the capital gains of the elite), don't even redistribute labour (ie. subsidies, minimum wages, income taxes without exempting services), but do redistribute the champagne (consumption tax, property tax, basic income). Everyone deserves champagne.

Just a comment on Maoist China:  Mao Zedong was actually a war hero and brilliant military strategist who repulsed the invading Japanese during WW2, and overthrew the corrupt Nationalists to set up Communist China.  But in terms of Economics, his policies were a disaster. One prime example was Mao's policy on Partridges. He literally commanded everyone to slaughter Partridges on sight, because allegedly Partridges ate the rice harvest.  Tragically, Partridges also ate locusts, so with all the Partridges all slaughtered there were no predators to keep the Locusts in check. As a result, swarms of locusts destroyed the rice harvests over a number of years in China, leading to great famine that caused millions of deaths during 'Mao's Great Leap Forward'.  It was Deng Xiao Ping, Mao's immediate successor...who endeavoured to bring in Foreign Investment and Foreign run factories, and allowed Chinese to slowly run small businesses that China's economy began to recover. I.E slowly reviving capitalism in China help China become the Powerhouse it is today. But as the quality if Life increased in CHina, morals and ethics amongst Chinese went down...so the trouble with Capitalism is...when used properly Capitalism can lift people out of poverty and better economic circumstances, but Capitalism can also result in greed and materialism that erodes the moral fabric society is built upon.

A couple points I wanted to argue about:   1. Income inequality, the wealth disparity; whatever it is, is really irreverent. If there are 8 slices of pizza, it would not matter who gets the money; 8 slices isn't going to feed 10 people. Whether it's a shortage of tomato sauce (tomatos, herbs, etc), or the dough (wheat), or the cheese (Milk, cows, etc), the BEST thing we can do to feed the 10 people, is to provide the extra ingredients, give more land to the farmers, give them better tools, etc.   2. Capitalism actually is very old, as old as agriculture, because humans are naturally lazy. In a hunter-gatherer lifestyle, food was caught/picked  on the day it was consumed; the prospect of being 'rich' in the future wasn't as good as enjoying life in the moment. It takes additional incentive to get people to save up, like if we know that it's going to be a bad winter, or that the herds are migrating.  Nature was the first at introducing scarcity, which made us start farming in the first place. But because we settled and farmed, we were vulnerable to attack by other groups (or animals), The natural response was a militia. Who paid for the militia? Farmers.. and by force.

Capitalism is great. It creates a system where competition breeds the best outcomes. It helps ensure under-served markets are catered to. It lets individuals determine where their interests lie, and spend their resources on those things instead of everyone getting the same stuff. It creates hard workers who earn their better pay. BUT. It doesn't do that when left alone. Capitalism cannot be the only system in place. Free markets cannot be allowed to run themselves. 'Anything goes' does not work. You needn't even watch this video to come up with examples of how unchecked Capitalism makes everything go tits-up. But it's the most sensible system, it aligns with our innate ideals that effort breeds success. But the world we live in is not compatible with unregulated markets. IMO, Andrew Yang has it spot on. Healthcare should not be a constant worry and something only working people get. Even looking at it economically, when someone lets their medical problems go unchecked, they end up costing more than they would have if we just gave them the care they needed, no questions asked. Money-earning should not start at $0. We have this amazing country where we're more prosperous and advanced than any civilization in history and the fruits of our collective labor have developed all sorts of technologies that will make the future so much better for everyone, but our vision of 'better' needs to include the people whose hard work is displaced by those technologies. That's not some dreaded evil, it's a natural progression of society, a move from a world where everyone has to put their 40 hour work weeks in just to put bread on the table, to maybe one where we have 24 hour work weeks, people get to spend time with their families, the prospect of losing one's job (and therefore extra income) is not a disastrous threat but instead a real option. We need a world where artists and big idea people get a chance to contribute their own skills that don't fit under the structure of soul-sucking corporate ownership of their lives. We need a world where the massive corporations with tons of power aren't calling the shots in every way.   Capitalism is a necessary component of a successful society. I truly believe we cannot simply discard it, or we lay the groundwork for our own demise. No matter how we distribute the wealth, no matter who we entrust all the power to, there are fundamental flaws in a system that does not place incentives for individuals to contribute their very best. But we are swiftly reaching a point where having every able-bodied person doing their best is completely unnecessary. Soon human labor will be about as relevant to the market as horse labor. We'll still have some jobs people will always be better suited for, and we'll always need the best and brightest working on the technologies and innovations of tomorrow (and educating the children who will one day replace them) but your average Joe toiling and sweating over a hot grill is doing a worse and less efficient job than a machine would. Steve drifting in and out of consciousness as he reaches hour 11 of driving his truck across the country to deliver a load of fidget spinners is far more costly and dangerous than a self-driven truck. I think a lot of the ills of capitalism are solved when we introduce other ideas. Elements of socialism, a safety net of UBI, free healthcare... sure, some people at the top will earn less for it. Let them cry into their gold-plated yachts about it. Nobody (who's even slightly realistic about it) is saying their wealth needs to be straight-up redistributed or that their important job needs to earn as little as my simple one does. Frankly, I don't see how a system like that doesn't just crumble. But if we keep the incentives, let people earn vastly more and control most of the wealth they earn, but raise the minimum earnings level up to a livable wage and make necessities available universally, we would have a much, much better country to live in.

So, in the off-chance you get to see this: You did ask for feedback on economics and why capitalism is good.  Capitalism is the free exchange of goods between consenting individuals. That's it. It's just the way you can trade with a wine maker for his production, or with a butcher for his meat or... with a gold-nail-maker for her gold nails?  Point is: It's not a system designed to keep others down, steal other's people property or anything. Quite the opposite, in fact. It's about cooperation and figuring out how we can maximize our own happiness through individuality. We must seek our own happiness by ourselves. It's the recognition of self-ownership, private property and peaceful, consensual trade among people. To be honest, I'm all in for smashing the State because it is not the support for capitalism, but the very thing choking it! (Anarcho-capitalists are a thing. I'm one of those.)  We could keep this going but this will turn into an effing essay. I'll just say that I do think labels such as leftist and right-winger are severely outdated and barely have any relevance anymore. I'm more in favor of a spectrum between individualism and collectivism. All that said, hope you're having a good one! :D

To quickly address a point in 15:30, capitalism with movies. Movies are art. Movies are expensive. That was not art by committee, David & Dan shared George R R Martin's vision passionately, what we got was art that is completely faithful to the original artist's work. The result? So much fucking money it's hard to comprehend.   The problem all the YouTubers have with this is the value of something comes from its usefulness. A PS2k gold pizza? It will rot, it'll last a few hours before going cold. The value is very low. A PS69.99 stand mixer for someone who makes bread dough for pizza and bread every other day? The value of the mixer is high. A PS69.99 stand mixer for someone who bakes only a few times a year? The value of the mixer is very low, probably only around 20% of the RRP. What is a PS2,500 gaming set-up with VR that you can only use for two hours a day, compared to a PS1,000 set-up you built over 5 years that you can use six hours a day?   Capitalism, as a theory, is ethical and great. Capitalism, how it played out in Human history, resulted in exploitation. Because of globalism, modern economies can exploit underdeveloped economies with sweatshop workers. Unfortunately, it's hard to fix this. If your cotton t-shirts were made by people paid a living wage that affords them the luxuries we can get in our system, then the people working unskilled labour with low wages will struggle to afford them. In the UK, the supermarket Morrison's (somewhere around 15-30% of market share in the supermarket industry?) sell milk and butter that is identical to other milk and butter, but costs more, with the extra money you pay going towards the farmers who produce the goods. The solution to all of your PS1.80 T-Shirts made in Bangladesh? I don't know either, but look at Fairtrade for cocoa. Fairtrade isn't infallible and still has issues, however, if you brand your T-Shirts as being made from people paid a fairer wage, you'll allow people to actually have the choice of not contributing to sweatshop labour, or at least, give the conditions to allow sweatshop labour become more tolerable for the sweatshop workers. Since you asked for it, here it goes... I will not answer every single one of your points because frankly I can't be asked.  But I will answer some on your main points and give a general vibe of why capitalism is not some crappy economic system where we only care about profit, or the least evil of all evil systems. But rather actually is THE GREATEST SOCIAL IDEA TO HAVE EVER BEEN THOUGHT OF. And you might just find, that you are already more capitalist than you realize.  First things first, if you are going to argue against capitalism, it would at least be nice to give a concise definition of what you consider capitalism, because guess what, different people have different interpretations of capitalism. Even the word capitalism itself is problematic, since socialists such as karl marx and Lois Blanc heavily influenced its definition.   So let me give you the definition of capitalism that I will be advocating for in my comment. When I say capitalism, I simply mean a system where you are freely allowed to do what you want as long as you do not violate other peoples rights.  So here is a bit of irony for you, if a bunch of workers want to come together and form a means of production where said workers own said means of production, guess what, that's capitalism baby, since you are not violating other peoples rights.. In fact, in a way, we already have such a a means of production under capitalism, its called a cooperative, and its perfectly capitalist. The problem comes when you want to steal said means of production from another owner and claim it for the workers, because here you have violated the original owners rights.   Under capitalism, if you want to buy a piece of land, and build you perfect socialist utopia there, go right ahead, I'm not going to stop you. Plenty of people have tried by the way, and all of them failed.  Now let me ask you this, can I do the same under socialism, can I buy a piece of land, and try my perfect capitalist utopia? In fact, If I don't want to have any part of you socialist nation, can I opt out? Can I say, I don't want to participate?  Now to address some of your points: -The worth it boys are one of the most PRO capitalist works ever produced, because they show that value is subjective, just because you can't see the value in a gold pizza, doesn't mean someone else will. For example, I value getting my fingernails at $0, there is absolutely no value in it for me, and I would not even pay a penny for it. However there obviously is some value in it for you, you value getting you fingernails painted, and that's fine. So to answer the worth is boys question, IS IT WORTH IT? Depends on who you ask.  - Karl Marx's theory of value is correct, for him and his followers. But it is not the way I value things. VALUE IS SUBJECTIVE! So using that as a rational to prove your point is irrelevant, since I will never agree with it because I value things differently to Mr Marx. There simply is no universal truth of value.  - You like shiny things, Congratulations for disproving Mr Marx.   - Using 'I like things' as your first economic axiom is flawed, because again value is subjective. How do they fit into you economic theory?  - You are right, that buying expensive things you don't need will not make you and most people happy. I'm going to leave some comments and arguments, even though I doubt any of this will ever be read considering this video is 10 months old at this point.  1. 12:45 The problem here is that janitorial work is unskilled work not just due to its importance (I will go into what 'importance' should really mean in this discussion) but due to how easy it is to replace a worker. Anyone can be taught how to clean in a relatively quick time, so a cheaper, less costly worker could easily be found if a current janitor demanded higher wages. Alternatively, executives and doctors are highly paid because it is far more costly and difficult to find someone else with an interest in the job, train them (often through years of education and experience), and then see how they work out. On a more traditional argument, the importance of a job is also key. For example, a sweatshop worker is not all that important. Once again, they are easily replaced, but furthermore, their job does not hold a position of importance in their workplace or industry. Their actions and beliefs do not really impact the greater company. I have no doubt that people will argue about how 'corporations are built on the backs of unimportant workers', but I think that idea ignores that each individual worker is, in themselves, unimportant. It's why one person will get fired if they miss work, but a whole bunch of people can successfully strike. In contrast, an executive or doctor is extremely important to their organizations. Executives are high-level managers who make sure a company operates correctly in a number of different ways, which gives them a lot of importance; if an executive messes up, an entire company could feel the consequences. Thus it becomes important to treat executives nicely, in order to ensure that the position attracts, and keeps, the very best a company can get.  2. 10:22 and 11:07 I agree with the assertion that there is a certain level of income which allows people to reach peak happiness. I also agree with the idea provided that it is due to families being able to pay off debt, rent, education, food, and all sorts of other bills and costs. I don't think, however, that income redistribution, which seems to be the most common tool of non-capitalist economic systems, is the answer. The better answer, in my opinion, is that more support for programs that provide basic resources such as food, water, shelter, as well as reductions in the cost of education would be a better method. This would allow an efficient system to be set in place that allows people to survive comfortably but still pressures them to work hard and contribute to society in order to fulfill any luxury or additional pleasures they want. The US does however already have a system like this in place, but I am willing to concede that it could be bolstered.  Once again, though, I disagree that income redistribution - specifically: taking money from the rich through extremely high taxes and giving that money to programs for the poor - is the answer either. A better answer to bolstering a system of basic resources would be to make government spending more efficient so that it spends less on military and 'secret budget items'. I think this would not only incentivize the government to be more efficient and open about its budget matters but would also promote the greatest public good by helping the poor without hurting the rich. It is also a system that heavily favors individual responsibility, which is a very important concept people need to be kept to.   3. 11:25 I completely agree with this idea, even if our conclusions are different. I think that one of the biggest parts of the whole socialist movement is envy. Some people have everything while other people have less than everything (not 'nothing', because that isn't true for people who don't actively deal with hunger, starvation, disease, and war), and it seems to make those with less angry at those who have more. That isn't justified, it's selfish. If you want more money because you think it will provide you with happiness, then go out and earn it. Construction jobs pay very well. If you want happiness, realize that money most likely isn't what you really seek, and go find a career (ahem, this sort of addresses an argument from the first video) that you actually enjoy and find meaningful.

I have a couple problems with what you argued.  First with exchange versus value. Yes there are products in which the use value, or economically the marginal utility does not match the price. But this does not apply to all people. For some, the utility of a 2000 dollar pizza comes explicitly from that price. But beyond that there's another solution. Don't buy it. Capitalism's assumptions come from people acting rationally. Yes, people do buy things and regret it because they find the use they got from the product was not worth it. But the solution is to better one's financial decisions in order to act more rationally. Capitalism assumes rationality because people tend towards these rational decisions. If someone regrets buying something, they're rarely gonna do it twice.  In terms of distribution of wealth for human happiness, capitalism still arguably does that well. How? Well yes happiness scales with wealth until a certain point, but wealth is ultimately meaningless. See the value of wealth comes from what that wealth can buy. And capitalism's incentive toward bettering production improves what people can buy.  The major thing I'd like to stress is that money is not a consumable resource. Money is exchanged. When you buy the 1000 dollar pizza, the money goes to the company that made it. It is then split between the workers, the supply production for more pizzas, and yes, the CEO. But when these people receive their paycheck, this money doesn't go away. It's fed back into the economy.  So when people get their paychecks, assuming it's disposable income, they either save or spend (Non-disposable income is always spent.). The spent money goes to others and is cycled through the economy as previously described, fueling more production, lowering the cost of production through creation if capital, allowing more people to buy things to raise happiness. Money also goes to workers, letting them buy these products.  But what if the wealthy save, ruining this cycle. As their mountains of cash build up, wouldn't it stop this cycle? Well, money not spent is essentially useless pieces of paper. It's almost as if you burnt the money.  Now removing money from existence deflates that currency. Deflation for an economy is bad because deflation encourages more saving since money is worth more in the future than now, increasing deflation more, and less money is being used in the exchange of goods which lowers happiness since people can't buy things because they're expensive compared to the value of their currency.  But here's the thing, if your economy has a central bank that prints money to regulate inflation like many capitalist economies, like the US, do, than this isn't much of an issue. Maybe you could argue that hyperinflation may occur if all of the wealthy spend their mass amount of saved money all at once, but this doesn't happen for multiple reasons. First the central bank can react to increasing inflation and decrease the amount of printed money. Second, it's ultimately against the best interests of the wealthy since it would lead to recession and hurt their means of income. Third, it's unrealistic to expect this sort of spending without warning.  And ultimately it's in the best interests of many of the wealthy to spend rather than save. While it might seem like CEOs are the boss, they are at the whim of their investors. And investors don't care about wealth accumulated, they care about increase in revenue, which only comes from the purchase of capital.  Those investors gaining money can now invest in more companies, leading to the purchase of more capital, the creation of more companies, and more increased production. (They can also spend it on consumption or save it, which I already mentioned)  Now there are problems with capitalism like markets where demand is incredibly sloped like in Medicare, or effects that hurt society, but not the individual, like climate change and pollution. But that's where government regulations come in. Some of these regulations even come in the form of creating new capitalist markets for a limited number of permits.  While capitalism does have wealth inequality, that doesn't matter if the standard of living stays higher than any socialist nation through how much capitalism incentivizes productivity.   Nonetheless, this was a very entertaining video, keep doing what you're doing. :)  EDIT: I wrote this entire essay on the value of capitalism in an economy and ended it with the wrong your. Nice.
