It's easy to criticise a system and point out flaws in it. It's a lot more difficult to construct a better system that works in practice and not just in theory. As they say 'the road to hell is paved with good intentions'.   Now that you have pointed out a lot of the flaws of our current capitalist system can you also explain how a communist regime would solve any of those problems while avoiding the pitfalls of past communist regimes? Can you perhaps do a similar review of the flaws of communism? Obviously there are a huge number of communist theories out there but then there are also a huge number of different capitalist and hybrid systems that could be implemented.  I certainly don't think that capitalism is the best economic system imaginable. But changing economic system isn't something you should do without being absolutely certain (and ideally there should be a broad consensus among relevant experts on this) that what you're doing is an improvement because it's going to effect millions if not billions of peoples lives. At the very least you should try it out on a smaller scale before you try to implement it in society at large. Reality is incredibly complex and just because something works in your head that's no guarantee that it actually works in real life.  Plus isn't the whole difference between communism and democratic socialism that democratic socialism is, you know, democratic? Granted current Democratic Socialist parties in Europe are more hybrid regimes than purely socialist ones (because it didn't work out so well for them when they tried being more purely socialist) but still.

But also here's some more info on Jonas Salk, to deepen interpretation of his actions and also further prove your point about accessibility, innovators, and fuck capitalism: 'Adminstrative powers above Salk (his involvement is unclear) determined they could not legally patent the vaccine, given previous works. Still, three vaccine shots and a booster priced polio protection only within the reach of middle class Americans and above.  So infection rates dropped among demographics that could afford the Salk vaccine, while rates expanded in lower income communities, especially among under-served minority groups. This was an economic as well as access problem: pediatricians could command higher prices as there was high demand for the multi-course regimen.   Dr. Albert Sabin, another polio researcher, knew that Salk's vaccine was not the best possible solution or even sufficiently safe. His arguments for impartiality and caution were largely ignored by the council backing Salk's vaccine (see link below), yet Sabin labored on. He developed a single orally-dosed drug that allowed low-cost, wide-scale distribution of this life-saving treatment. [...]  Of course aspects of Sabin's work were built off the work of Salk - all of science is inherently iterative. But we as a community and society at large need to have systems in place to ensure credit is given where credit is due. Thanks to a half-century of good PR and first-mover advantage, Dr. Salk is heralded as the vanquisher of polio, while it was Sabin's dogged persistence at achieving a better solution that tipped the scales (not to mention countered an economically and racially-biased course of treatment).  There is an entire subset of scientists who passed through history largely undetected, while making tremendous impacts. Female scientists have made up a disproportionate amount of this subset, routinely discouraged from research (e.g. see comments in this post). For every triumphant Salk, there is almost always a Sabin (or Rosalind Franklin, et al) who deserves equal if not more recognition. Hopefully with improved access and documentation, the scientific community can better allocate credit, resources, support, and realize improvements faster.' - Source: URL

Maybe... not everyone deserves to be happy?  If I went to school and got bullied for being a nerd for two decades while my peers goofed off, I don't mind laughing at them from the top of my office building now that they're getting by and I'm (relatively) rich. Could we make a system where half my income was given to them because I sit in a chair all day while they do backbreaking labor in the sun? Probably. Do I think they deserve it after choosing poorly their whole life? Not particularly. Do I think they should have some means of making up for their past poor decisions nowadays? Yes.  Things that are more expensive are supposed to represent more value. People that are paid more are more valuable people. If a society values the wrong things then it needs changing, but at its core this system of rewarding people who produce the most valuable goods and services with more value-certificates (money) is probably the best. Those external systems that rely on government funding for unbiased research, social programs, and the other things should still exist, because the game of Monopoly is no fun when everyone is too poor to play, but on the whole it doesn't deserve abolishing. For many they're the source of unhappiness but at the same time unhappiness only after taking for granted the fact that you have immeasurable privileges around you and in your very existence, having likely grown up in a moderately low-stress household in global standards, good to ok living conditions, minimal environmental biological factors like lead pollution in urban areas that'd mess with your biology and brain function permanently etc. We have the privilege to be unhappy and not for example starving or actively persecuted, as then unhappiness wouldn't even be on our list of priorities. ok, how about this? You want to improve the world by increasing everyone's happiness instead of their wallets. Fine. So now how do we make people happy? Clearly, you want stuff. I'm not so much into stuff, I just need my pc and that's about it. Now, there are more people like me, who don't really want stuff, so we can't just start handing out stuff to everyone, because that's not what they need to get happy. So then what should we do? It sounds to me like in order for people to get happy, they need to have their needs and wants fulfilled, which I believe you also mentioned.  So how are we going to fulfill peoples needs? If we just ask people nicely to help each other out, that's not going to work. I reckon you're going to get something like the wild west. So we need to have some sort of incentive to get people to fulfill each others needs. So... what would motivate you to go out and help people? Well... You want stuff. What if we give you stuff in exchange for helping people out? But it's kind of hard to hook you up with a supply of champagne bottles, especially because ever once in a while you also want stuff like food and clothes. So what if, instead of giving you champagne bottles, we give you money and you get to decide how you're going to divide that money into champagne bottles and food. Also, the more you go out and fulfill other peoples needs, the more money we give you, which you can spend on getting your needs fulfilled. Now we have an incentive for people to go out and help people, not only that, but an incentive to help people in the best way they can. Imagine there's a doctor shortage in California. For whatever reason, being a doctor simply isn't appealing to the Californians. Because of this, the doctors are undermanned and overworked. There are also a lot of patients not getting treatment. Basically, everyone is suffering. Now imagine that there's a guy in New York, who wants to become a doctor. He also wants to become rich, because he likes stuff. So he looks around and sees that being a doctor is much more worthwhile in California than New York and decides to become a doctor in California. Because of money. The local doctors however are finally getting relieved and the Californians are finally getting treatment. The doctor is feeling great as well, because he is getting rich. Everyone is happy now, because the doctor wants money.  This is basic supply and demand, which you haven't even touched on in your video.

If you seriously want to understand economics you have to study...(Surprise!) economics, and not just read Marx in a philosophy class. These videos make it very clear you've never taken ECON 101. I mean, you're not totally wrong - like Marx, many of your criticisms are valid, but your understanding is shallow and woefully incomplete. And just like Marx, your comprehension of how the world actually works is based on false assumptions. For example, money is merely a tool we use to measure resources and cannot be eradicated in even a totalitarian society. And the same goes for capitalism, black markets will always arise, because 'capitalism' is merely the right to conduct business. It's not the boogy-man that Marxist/communists think it is. Is a 9 year old setting up a lemon-aid stand an evil capitalist pig? And with each criticism of capitalism, you've failed to ask 'as opposed to what?' For example, It's easy to say you hate ads, harder to ask if you have the right in a free society to advertise the fruits of your labor, like, say...your Marxist philosophy videos. Or your Che t-shirts. It's easy to say you hate your job at Uber or Comcast, without addressing the fact that you had the freedom to quit and become a youtuber, a job we can assume you enjoy doing. You're only able to name 1 video game produced by 'communism' (less economically free), weighed against millions produced by 'capitalist' societies (much more economically free). There's a reason why no one in the economics field takes Marx very seriously. I highly recommend binging all of Planet Money and reading liberal economists Paul Krugman and Robert Reich.  The TL;DR version is this: There's no such thing as a purely capitalist nor purely socialist economy. It's a completely false dichotomy. The real question is how much do we as a society privatize vs socialize the economy. Oh and also fighting corruption and crony capitalism might actually be a good idea maybe.

Capital isn't evil, it's amoral. And that's the problem. The system has no value for human life or happiness. Same with a corporation within the system, it's just like a wild animal that needs to keep eating to survive. It doesn't want to hurt people but it will if it has to. And people can make a quick buck by serving these wild animals and so they do, to the detriment of most other people.

The existence of things like public companies makes blaming any one person for the evils of capitalism impossible because the bosses are working to please the shareholders and none of those shareholders themselves are evil or greedy but they merely make self-serving choices. The evil is still happening, people are starving, we are getting closer to global catastrophe etc, but the system has made it so that everyone can avoid blame by saying they are just doing what's reasonable or even mandatory within the system. The negative effects of our choices and actions have been completely separated from the actions themselves and that makes those of us who have any amount of 'power' feel more okay with making choices that will negatively affect others.

It's similar to your observation that some of the most important human achievements have been accomplished by people wealthy enough to not have to worry about money. If people's' immediate needs are met, then they can pursue passion projects, which might look like creating art, innovating, or curing cancer.   Also, are you familiar with Peter Joseph? He makes the internet rounds occasionally with some decent ideas about how capitalism could be transformed by technology--things like car sharing, for example, which are starting now, could change how we think about ownership, for example. Why do a need all the expense of owning a car for only my personal use? Wouldn't it just be better if I had one when I needed one?   In general, I guess, although presently there are some huge concerns with how neoliberalism (Uber) abuses the notion, the sharing economy might point towards a way out. Neoliberalism is founded on classical liberalism, which is in turn based in part on contract law (ownership). So then, theoretically, any move away from contractual obligation (sharing) is a move towards the end of capitalism as we know it?

The value of pizza seems to be irrelevant, as in the price. 2000 dollars is specific but that's not what it means, the 2000 dollars doesn't just symbolize something overpriced, it symbolizes the different perception of value amongst people.   It's the same as spending money on Supreme or diamonds. The simple prestige that comes with the ingredients used, a mixed bag of highly valued items considered to be 'delicious'. Being able to spend money on something considered to be high class, it brings pleasure to some people's mind, seemingly casting the illusion of standing above the common rabble with the purchase of a stupidly extravagant item most people can only dream of.   Perhaps, part of the reason why the ownership of commodity is so alluring to some people, that is also partly why some people can commit acts of immorality without any hesitation. That pleasurable sense of dominance that present in that immoral act tempts many and it is also that which disrupts the brotherhood among many of their fellow men.   There are several things we seemingly do not need. A large house, for example, we can live together in a modest apartment, a room each to reduce carbon footing from the excess construction and also save space, reduce housing price, yet we don't.   Living is a simple thing, you consume the necessary nutrient to stay alive after working, if we were to bog down all of our wants (Electrities for tv, drugs, laptops, large house, extravagant meals, expensive hobbies) to our needs, imagine how much money we could have and how much of it could be spent on others living in misery right at this moment. Do the rich fulfill this theory? Do everyone who lusts for the excess do? What will happen if we all choose to live like Buddhist monks?   Are humans inherent hedonist and lust power? Does the centuries of pillaging, conquest, and bloodshed prove this point? Perhaps not. We also lust after other things, love, the desire for meaning, self-sacrifice, and brotherhood. But were they able to overcome the former? Perhaps this is dualism. That men are both of these things at the same time? Or perhaps there are different men for different things?   My last question seems to be, is it then capitalism that made men, or men that made capitalism?

Here are five myths that cloud our perception of both the past and the present in terms of our judgement of capitalism  (1) The 'robber baron' myth, which holds that in late nineteenth-century America there were powerful men who became rich at the expense of the poor. The reality is that they became wealthy by being productive, and that there is no other period in history which saw such a rapid and widespread improvement in the well-being of the average individual (and you cannot say that communism or socialism did so that is patently false) (2) The myth that the Great Depression (or any other depression of that matter) was caused by a failure of business, when it was, in fact, produced by a failure of government and specifically (in the case of the Great Depression) by the Federal Reserve System (3) The myth that government in the economy has expanded in response to public demand, when, actually, the public has had to be sold 'hard' for politicians to enact every major social program (4) The 'free lunch' myth, which forces the individual to pay more, no matter how the government raises money - by taxing individuals, by taxing businesses, or by printing more money  (5) The myth that government, like Robin Hood, transfers wealth from the rich to the poor, when the reality is that the government usually transfers wealth and income from both the very rich and the very poor to those in the middle. So I'm not going to pretend I'm an economist, but I have studied economics and considered changing my major cause I just loved it so much, but I am also a liberal and I love your videos. This is the only one I've ever disagreed with. I'm not going to refute your claims point by point, but I'm going to outline some reasons why I think capitalism is very compatible with liberal values and is good for society.  Here's one: capitalism has built-in incentives against racism, sexism, homophobia, etc. This may sound crazy, but it incentivizes equality and a level playing field in terms of both supply and demand.   On the demand side, everyone's money is just as good as the next persons. Black in the south in the jim crow area, local storeowners would massively inflate prices for black customers, on top of forcing them to wait until every white customer was served. This gave a company who would serve black customers equally, at market rates and quality of service, a competitive advantage. A company, called Sears, did step in to do so who allowed all customers to order through a catalog. When white storeowners tried to destroy the catalogs, Sears even gave out instructions so customers could disguise their orders and drop them directly off at the post office. The competitive advantage that Sears wielded was one factor that put many racist storeowners out of business.    In addition, when companies are revealed to be racist, homophobic, or sexist, customers can boycott them, which is very effective when it comes to pressuring companies to change their stance. In this way, capitalism has built-in tools for self correction when it comes to equality on the demand side. Source: URL  On the supply side, it is beneficial for companies to treat all of their employees with respect and give them as many opportunities as possible to advance. If they do not do so, other companies who listen to all of their employees ideas and recommendations will have a competitive advantage. For example, a janitor at Frito-Lay had an idea for a new product catering to Latinos. Because the company encouraged their employees to think like owners, and the CEO was willing to hear a pitch from a low-level employee, and they provided him the opportunity for upward mobility (basically making the playing field as level as possible for his ideas) they got a fantastic new product: Hot Cheetos, and Richard Montanez went on to become the VP of multicultural sales for PepsiCo America. If they treated him poorly, he might have made his pitch to a different company, and that company will have reaped the benefits of his invention. Or he would have stayed a janitor, but frito-lay would not have as good of a line of products, giving more companies who treat their employees well room to outcompete them. Source: URL  This may seem like just a few people who 'got out of the system' but capitalism works on a macro scale. Some companies will survive even if they are racist. But they won't have the same competitive advantage other companies who value an equal playing field have. However where this begins to break down is when companies become monopolistic and change laws to benefit them, or make the free market 'unequal' by undercutting smaller competitors. This is why we need government to step in with regulations to keep the market free and fair.   Now, why wouldn't this work on an even larger scale? I believe a country to treats everyone equally, who invests in helping disadvantaged people level the playing field, who accepts everyone, who will try to get everyone the best education they can possibly have, will naturally have a competitive advantage over other nations. This is why corporations should be taxed. It will actually be good for the entire country (yes, including them!!!) to do so! Because there will be a more educated, more agile, more resilient workforce, and government can keep them from short-sightedly spending themselves into a depression.  Also I know I said some reasons and this is just one but this comment is way too long already. I have others if you want to make an capitalism apologist liberal character!! I would be honored.

I am so, so late to this video, but your point about GDP being an inadequate metric often has no counterpoint by people who instinctively support capitalism without much thought. Personally, I think capitalism could provide the things you're asking for in an economy---but America has never sought to achieve that.   Two distinct strains of capitalism exist, at least from my point of view: pure capitalism, which is the famed 'American Dream' where small business thrives and your employer does give a shit about you because she's at the store every day; or corporatism, which is Amazon, Google, Microsoft, Ford, etc.---the kind of corporations that dominate multinational, multi-billion dollar trade. These both function on the same fundamental ideas of capitalism theoretically, but practically they play out very disparately. There's something to be said of shame, and the majority of people aren't going to eat that golden pizza right in front of starving orphans. Your small business owner can theoretically treat their workers as shitty as corporations do, but they sorta can't because their neighborhood or town or stretch of farmland would be pissed as hell, and their business would dry up.   Adam Smith was right about a select few things and pretty wrong about a lot of others, but one thing he kinda sorta had right was the need for the government to get out of business. Except, not really because regulation is vital to any economy succeeding and deregulation is directly responsible for 2008, but in the sense that there are, again, two kinds of regulation: micro-regulation, which is the government dictating comparatively small aspects of the market or business; and macro-regulation, which is focused on large-scale issues like banking regulations or 'hey don't dump toxic waste in the rivers' or 'hey monopolies and oligopolies actually fucking suck so stop'.   Macro-regulation is absolutely necessary, and without it we see some of the worst distribution of wealth America has seen in almost a century. Deregulation on this front is majority to blame for the economic shit show we have now. Micro-regulation, on the other hand, has created a monster. And it's not the 'fucking red tape' kind of monster, though bureaucracy is its own beast, but when government meddles needlessly with Wall Street, Wall Street will answer in kind. High earners and corporations keep politicians in their pockets and are so blatant about their greed that sometimes the letterheads on top of legislation still has the lobbyist group name on it. Business needs the illusion of mutual exclusivity without it truly being so. The Invisible Hand actually has a fuzzy outline like Wonder Woman's jet, but we all /pretend/ it's invisible because pointing it out wouldn't help anyone and just cause a fit.   I think pure capitalism has redeeming features and encapsulates the best aspects of capitalism as an economic system, but corporatism can burn in hell along with the monopolies of the 19th and 20th centuries and the oligopolies of the 20th and 21st centuries.

I want to preface whatever I end up writing that economics is a science that deals with maximization of benefits extracted from limited resources. Because resources available to humankind are always limited, be that due to geography and distribution of natural commodities that come with it, labour availability, efficiency of infrastructure and institutions already in place and other important shit.  The thing is, it is really easy to compare the present situation in the US against the utopian version of communism and point to all the failings the American variety of capitalism has. However, there's no certain way to achieve that utopia since the underlying notion of existence of a state-controlled market more effective than a privately-owned one is inherently flawed. Because government-controlled economy is inefficient by the virtue of, well being controlled by the massive and unwieldy organ that is the government. Any government.  Keep in mind that as long as the government is in complete control of the economy, decision-making processes immediately become bogged down with every bureaucratic rigidity that comes with collective decision making of the legislative branch. Time to respond to demand increases to a point where the economic equilibrium (i.e. supply meeting demand) cannot be established, like, ever. Budget is, after all, decided on on an annual basis, so whatever happens in-between has to be tied to decisions made based on incredibly outdated information. Even on local level small and medium businesses have to make day-to-day financial decisions to stay afloat and juggle its funds from one area to another. On global level, unless the entire world is miraculously transformed into socialist countries too, the plans for imports and exports in such a country will clash against a rapidly changing and unpredictable privately-owned international market, so the trade balance is fucked too. Private market provides flexibility to respond to changes in demand quicker, even when that demand is for a two thousand dollar pizza. Which ties into my next point.  Remember that since the legislative branch is in control of statewide market supply across all industries, it can simply disregard human needs it does not deem essential and relocate funds that would otherwise be serving, for example, the entertainment industry, into something like healthcare (yaaay!), or infrastructure (yaaay!), or military (yaaay?), or salaries for the government apparatus (yaaay???).   /Tangent/ It is, by the by, hard to imagine a system with more conflicts of interest than the one where chief business executives and policymakers happen to be the same people. Corruption and embezzlement in the USSR was something of a legend, and it was one of factors that eventually led to all but legally pronounced merging of the executive and the legislative branches of the government. This is a consequence Russia still can't get rid of today, the most notable symptom of which is the fact that Putin, for all intents and purposes, is sitting his fifth term in a country where the limit used to be two consecutive terms (and each four years instead of now six). /End Tangent/   Also remember that since the state will overall have less money to distribute among the industries - because the economy is less efficient - the question of how essential any federal expense is will gradually become more and more important, and therefore even in democratic regimes where the voters decide who occupies the office at any given time the candidates campaigning for those essential issues will be more attractive in the eyes of the electorate. No one will run on promises to invest into films and press - oh, by the way, all press safe for spare-time Internet blogs is state-funded too, that also goes well all the time - when political opponents run on promises to make the pharmaceutical industry great again. So, death to fashion is imminent, you are right about that, but you can also forget about video games, possibly in their entirety. Because people in the government are not exactly young and hip and they couldn't care less for all your young adult interests unless it serves the reputation of the country or re-purposed for money laundering.  Imagine standing in a queue at a shopping mall in the capital to buy, say, a sweater, for four hours, only to find that the state-run shop has run out of sweaters for now, but they have black leather Hungarian shoes and leggings from Romania, and that's all you can buy now, try your luck in a week or two to see whether they stock something you need next time. That's what shopping for anything other than food in the USSR during the eighties was like. The supply just didn't care.  The thing is, you have all the tools you need to fix the situation. Taxes and legislation of the private sector. Tax the rich more to redistribute income (forcefully disassemble monopolies if you need too, capitalism isn't without its sins in that area as well) and keep the companies in check on labor conditions and environmental impact, and any other issues that may arise. Don't allow commercial organizations to lobby via middlemen NCO and make tax evasion difficult. The US has demonstrated time and time again that its institutions are capable of enforcing the laws, so make that law-enforcement non-selective and you'll be fine.  Lots of stuff I didn't mention, but this is long enough as it is for a YouTube comment from a person who is not really qualified to talk so extensively on the topic.  P.S. The institutions that create Capitalism: the market, commodity production, private property, etc. predate Capitalism as a whole. I'm not advocating that Capitalism is immortal because it's institutions predate it, but actually a case that we can build pieces of Socialism under Capitalism while we wait for the unholy alliance between the institutions that create Capitalism to fail on their own. Community assemblies, common ownership of key parts of society, and mutual aid, can all be created and function independently from one-another to achieve different goals: positive community cohesion, efficient resource distribution between people, and cooperation to achieve common objectives, all of which, if used independently, can actually benefit and help the working class understand itself and its place in the Capitalist system.  While the market and private ownership prior to Capitalism existed, they didn't cooperate. Under Feudalism, private ownership of the means of production lied within the institutions of governance: the lords and monarchies, and manifested itself as the Manor Economy. Markets existed, but were separate from the Manor Economy, primarily with traders and merchants. Their practices would be the backbone of Capitalist methods of selling commodities for profit: advertising, investment, even banking.  As technology improved, colonization was under way, and trade began dominating Europe (yes, I specify Europe because the West itself is the hub of the Capitalist system. Not racist, because Capitalism is shit. It is what it is) the Manor Economy became irrelevant. The need for self-sufficient communities decreased when a workforce can be hired, or, forcefully imported, to till the fields and operate the tools instead. The colonial-era slave trade played a major hand in Capitalism's rise, with the market playing a big role in the success of this new economy.  This created a problem: the European systems of governance were created and structured in such a way that they functioned most efficiently under Feudalism and the Manor Economy. Once Feudalism began to collapse on itself, it wasn't because the Capitalists rose up and overthrew it, replacing it with a form of State that was structured to organize a society built on a cooperation between the Market and Private Ownership under the decendents of the merchants and traders: the early bourgeoisie. This state is the Representative system. Almost every state today possesses a form of Parliament with political parties vying for control. Even dictatorships, such as North Korea, possess a national assembly (fancy phrase for 'Parliament') with a political body in control. This new system of governance was strikingly similar to the structure of the new economies: political bodies competed for control (similar to how companies on the market compete for profit) with a twist in using propaganda to manipulate the public into support and votes (similar to how companies use advertisement). The Representative State is a Partner, and interweaved, with Capitalism. All key elements to both predate them, but as the preexisting system began corroding away due to its natural contradictions and ever-globalizing material conditions, new conductions would arise for a more flexible form of economics and governance.  Similar to how the German Peasants Revolt of 1524 and the English Civil War saw a new trend heading in the inevitable direction of Capitalism and the Representative system, we see naturally occurring trends (not ideological ones) beginning to flourish showing signs of the system that will replace Capitalism. The early 20th century 'Socialist' revolutions aren't good examples- they were forced, only reactions to ideology, not because of Capitalism itself. The latter half of the 20th century saw Revolutionary Democracy begin occurring naturally, and not ideologically (1968 France, 1994 Mexico, and the Rojava Revolution). The justifications for why these events even happened/are happening is because of contemporary conditions beginning to support their rise: ecological disaster, the corrosion of the current economic order, and cultural suppression by the Representative Nation-State, rather than 'some guy in a book said this system is bad and oppressive'. These revolutions and events happened by nature, not nurture. The YPG was founded as a result of the Arab-centric society in Syria over the Kurds in 2004, not because Socialism was more appealing. They only began building an ideological platform after their formation, and a platform they saw would fit the needs of the people in that region. Same with the EZLN in 1994.  I wouldn't go so far as to call these movements 'Socialist', however. The Rojava still maintains several institutions of Capital. I would instead call it what it is, a phrase I mentioned earlier: Revolutionary Democracy. The primary changes in the Rojava are more oriented towards changing the cultural and political relations, and less about economic relations- councils must have 40% or more of their body be female, policies are made locally, active attempts to integrate all kinds of cultural communities by building a platform capable of sustaining them: which can't be centralized. This is what the new political body will look like after Capitalism, at least a primitive version of it: decentralized and egalitarian.  But what about in the realm of economics? Unions? I think not. Unions are failing, and are a product of existing labor relations: something a post-capitalist system will lack. The labor relations of Feudalism were different, and most certainly the labor relations of a society post-Capitalism will be different.  Cooperatives? A possibility, the amount and success of cooperatives economically and when it comes to integrating their workers as compared to traditional business models is certainly different and beneficial, but if they are what's coming next, they are certainly in their primitive state: still bound by the existing economic order.  I think the fact that these, certainly revolutionary, but definitely not Socialist, at least not yet, institutions actually beginning to form today naturally is a sign that things will change. Capitalism isn't self-sufficient, it requires various institutions and social orders to even function crudely, unlike Feudalism, so it certainly won't last as long as Feudalism did, even though it's wayyy more powerful. So things might be coming around soon enough for the common masses, but definitely not for at least several more decades.  I'm going to end here and let you contemplate what I've said. Please don't trash me, I'm not a political master.

Ok so some economic facts  - capitalism in all its flaws does creat wealth and that distribution can be more even than you think which is why World poverty rates since 1980 have been cut in half. The idea that new wealth only goes to the top is false the portion of the population within the higher middle class and middle class in American has increased 11% since 1980.  -capitalism has its best effects when it is allowed to fun free for instance the cheapest goods in America (things that have actually become cheaper since 1980) are the items least regulated by the government for instance cars, refrigerators, dishwashers, food, and any consumer good you can think of. Americans spend the most money on housing, health care, and education which are subject to massive regulation by federal government via subsidies, quotas, mandates, and zoning laws. Hello I was sent your way by Paul Camplos at Lawyers, Guns and Money (URL Really enjoyed watching your series on what's wrong with capitalism and looking forward to seeing some more of your stuff when I have some time. You did ask for valid critiques of the video/defenses of capitalism so here's mine, with the caveat that I generally agree with most of your points about utility maximization in capitalism.  You address this briefly in your video but it's worth noting capitalism has created the most maximized human environment for innovation in all of human history. You reference prior innovators briefly and note that their motivation for their efforts was contributing to the common weal, not profit maximization, because they were already wealthy. But it can be argued and is probably true that it was a condition precedent to their efforts that such historical innovators were wealthy, which generally allowed most such innovators in human history the independence to pursue innovation for the good of man. Your rebuttal on this point is weak (and I do keep in mind you spent about 10 seconds on it).   The era of Capitalism has unlocked the most sustained and consistent course of innovation in human history. I don't think examples are necessary in my opinion, that statement can stand on its own. In comparison to previous era of human existence innovation for the last two - two and a half centuries has been proceeding at an extraordinary pace, and most of it has been coming out of nations that have embraced capitalism. Historically innovation in pre-capitalist society proceeded at a snail's pace, probably precisely because so few people had the independence necessary to devote significant resources to innovation, and further because the rewards for innovation were less predictable in a society that did not have any meaningfully developed intellectual property laws. It's arguable that the modern era's period of innovation also comes from fully embracing the enlightenment and the scientific method, and people in previous societies were hobbled by poor modes of thought, however it's notable how much innovation has come specifically out of the United States and Britain during this time period and how much of it was profitable, indicating capitalism is playing a significant role.  True socialism does not meaningfully address the innovation component of human activity sufficiently. Classic marxism destroy's significant incentives for innovation that exist in the present system. And halting the process of human innovation would be a tremendous net negative for humanity, one that we need to be mindful of when proposing what should follow capitalism. We need to keep in tact these incentives for innovation and creativity and build a society around forward progress in the sciences, engineering and other high-level forms of human endeavor (art/philosophy/etc.), and disproportionately rewarding people engaged in such endeavors is an important means of doing so (maybe philosophy in the latter half of the 20th century has suffered and fallen into meandering minutia precisely because it hasn't exactly been a money maker (unless you like Focault or the cast you roll called in your video and think they've genuinely been meaningful in comparison to Socrates, Hobbes, Descartes or Marx)).   No answer's here but I suspect in the medium term the goal will be to socialize the bottom rungs of Maslow's hierarchy of needs while creating even more hyper-capitalistic environments for the attainment of the top sections of the pyramid. Some of this is playing out already, independent of dollars social media cred is it's own form of currency and value, though it correlates tightly with dollars most of time. Ideally we should socialize up to love/belonging to create a safer society (reduce anti-social behaviors) but I'm not sure how you would socialize love/belonging or if that's even possible (maybe drugs/robots/VR for the wretched cases?). We can definitely at minimum strive to create entitlements to food/shelter/medicine for all people though, we have the resources or will in the future. Meanwhile innovation will still be highly rewarded with stuff/societal esteem in a continued capitalized/competitive environment for more high-level goods.  Anyway thanks for the efforts, cool video, looking forward to seeing more of your work!

We don't live in a capitalist society, if by 'capitalism' we mean a system where industry and trade are privately owned. This definition assumes a real separation between the state and private enterprise. What we in fact live in is a fascist system, where governments and the global corporations are united in purpose (at least mostly), and this is true for a lot of the world. The 2008 'Great Recession' illustrates this point nicely. When the private banks gambled irresponsibly and failed, the FEDERAL RESERVE, a government appointed but privately owned bank, created massive sums of money to bail out the banks under the guise of bailing out the economy. Other central banks did the same. This in turn bailed out the private owners of the corporations whose stocks were all plummeting, causing a massive stock market boom that is only now beginning to roll over. Unless we can fully understand the structure of our society, we cannot imagine adequate solutions. Giving the state more power, for example, is no different in our society from giving it less. This is because there is no independent state. Capitalism would in fact be an improvement. Under a capitalist system, for example, interest rates would be set by the market, instead of being set by a privately owned bank for the benefit of the global banking/corporate elite. Remember that normal people are still a large part of the market. A good way to ensure the people have no power is to ensure they are poor and a good way to ensure that is to make saving impossible. Capitalism might be an improvement, but this is not to say I am endorsing an Ayn Rand libertarian society either. A free market requires law and oversight. Capitalism requires a separate state power to regulate it.

As someone who studies economics, I am not sure what is meant by anti-capitalist. There are certainly problems with some of the results of capitalism but at the end of the day it is merely a very efficient debt management system which reduces hording and ensure greater employment of resources by allowing for a profit for lending unused resources. I can agree that maybe this extreme employment of resources leads to excess production of useless things, but that is more due to subsidy than capitalism. Subsidy is in many cases a symptom of corruption.

A good example of a communist economic system is seen in government agencies. The managers of individual units practice budget maximization in order to make sure they get the same or greater amount of resources the following year. This tendency to horde resources leads to resources going to the wrong places. Also without a market where people bid-ask for resources it becomes a game of favoritism on who will get those resources.

I completely understand that there are problems with the wealth distribution structure of capitalism in it's current state. However, to throw out the resource management side of the system seems extremely counter productive. Capitalism does make essential commodities much cheaper. It is making these essential commodities so cheap that makes it so the excessive commodities could exist at all. There are some notoriously hard essential commodities that are very difficult to make cheap due to lack of portability. Housing and healthcare are two examples. In these cases a socialistic approach may be helpful but would involve long waiting lists. Would a capitalist system which was made up of  workers cooperatives, as opposed to companies which represent very few interests, quell some of the issues than anti-capitalists have with capitalism?

Just on a side note market access used to be almost impossible before for the average person. Furthermore non-self directed investment schemes like 401ks only give the powerful more power. In a non-democratized market the arguments against capitalism seem much more valid. However, these days if you want to 'own the means of production' save up some money and buy some of it with Robinhood. Will you have as much power as the rich person or institutions in shaping the economy through your investment choice, no. However, if more people actively participate the economy should greater reflect what we want. This type of participation does require a different view to investing than is traditionally used. The institutions have the time and resources to manipulate small investor actions by playing on their greedy. However, I think we will see a shift in power and economic composition as active investing becomes more normalized for even the low-end wage earners.

I've really come to love your videos over the like, past 72 hours during which I've watched basically all of them for the first time, BUT - ohgod I can't do this.. Let's skip the but.  I've really come to love your videos over the like, past 72 hours during which I've watched basically all of them for the first time. What strikes me as a little bit peculiar in these two videos though, is the seemingly lacking sense of self-irony in regards of capitalism and the lifestyle that your videos could be interpreted as portraying (which is different from saying that it was the lifestyle that you had. Obviously I don't know you - other than for that you like shiny things, but then, who doesn't?). You can take unchecked concern for appearances, sexualism, hedonism and pleasure and combine that with social justice and liberties and equality and present it as superficially something hugely progressive. But under the realities of current availability of resources, under the realities of capitalism, that can only ever be local. Outside our sphere of pleasure someone pays the price of our champagne, costumes, the layers of makeup. That's largely the Chinese factory workers, at the moment. Or if you're really into cocaine, then it's the innocent bystanders of cartel wars and farmers forced to turn their fields, that used to give them food and thus grant them at least a theoretical means of self-reliability, into seas of coca plants.  In my opinion, the best direct action you can take against capitalism and global inequality is to minimize your consumption. This said, I'm not meaning to be overtly critical of you as a person; *even if* this was a flaw of you, one flaw doesn't break the person, but might as well be that it's something you're well aware and also take into account in your daily life outside these videos.  In any case, to me, personally, what actually makes your videos even more charming is that I can interpolate the lifestyle portrayed in them to such an absurd degree that it becomes this dystopia of pink curtains and golden lace and bubble warp made of silk. And I do honestly believe that your style is particularly effective in reaching a certain part of the jaded young generation. But, looking at things through my own red-green glasses, I remain a little bit surprised that some aspects of it - globalism, environmentalism, etc - are something you haven't yet touched much, not even self-ironically.

In regards to the question 'would video games exist after capitalism,' your answer is of course correct. I make video games (though I've yet to finish one) because I like to make them, not to make money. I certainly would choose a different genre of game to make if I were interested in making money from it. One thing I DO wonder about after capitalism is: 'is there anyone who is passionate about cleaning sewers? About cleaning up puke at a bus station?' Maybe you address this later in the video since I paused it to write this comment, or maybe I'm just a simpleton.

As a liberal who has studied economics, stuff is not that easily attainable without some form of capitalism incentivizing people to innovate and start businesses to produce stuff. There needs to be natural selection in the market place in order to end up with quality stuff. It works because people figure out what people are demanding and work to satisfy that need with the incentive of profits, which leads to production and a healthy economy. Mass starvation happens in communist countries because people aren't producing optimally because the government is controlling their decisions. Since the government doesn't know what the best decisions are locally for the food producers but still tries to control them, food production suffers (best example of this is China) and GDP is too weak to pick up the slack with imports.   That said, people worrying about starving to death while the rich get richer is bad for a free market too since the rich simply hoard their money while most people are too worried about working so they don't starve to death to start businesses or innovate. People need to feel safe to take risks, so worrying about making the bare minimum to survive or losing health insurance also hurts the free market. There are also things like the environment which nobody is considering when acting optimally for themselves, so you need government regulation to incentivize people not to break the environment.   To maximize well-being, people having the freedom to decide what's best for them works pretty well in most cases, but having a safety net and rules to protect from collective harm are also extremely important. I believe in taxing the rich a lot more and universal healthcare and education, but pure communism is not the answer.

There is a missing linkage in the comments which few communists apparently understand. Yes, companies pursue profits. How does a company offer a service or product at wide enough scale or with wide enough margins to keep the lights on? By meeting demand! A non-corrupt company produces things people actually want and need. The profit motive could never be serviced without actually providing for other people.  No single plan is as adaptive or responsive as the decentralized, organic system we call the free market. There are elements in capitalism which are exploitative or unpleasant, but if you like having your wants and needs met by competent organizations, and if you like a variety of choice, capitalism is for you. If you like one kind of shoe (determined by a planner), one kind of car (determined by a planner) and one kind of pizza (determined by a planner), then please go seastead a communist paradise (there's an oxymoron) into existence. So many great points in this video. I wish people would also let go of looking at things as black and white, all or nothing. It's entirely possible to form a society with a capitalistic economy that's tempered by socialist policies, or maybe other polices that come from whatever other 'ism' you please. We don't have to be ALL capitalist or ALL socialist,  we don't even have to use those terms, we can just be a society-with-whatever-rules-we-deem-work-for-us-ist. Honestly capitalism needs a bit of socialism to work anyway, because as much as some people are trying to pretend otherwise it's undeniable that it needs healthy and happy humans to achieve peak performance. Capitalism is supposed to work as a cycle, where businesses employ people and make products, and those workers make enough money and have enough free time to go out and become customers for other businesses, so that those businesses can make money to use to make their products and pay their employees, and the cycle continues. People need to be able to eat well, rest well, and afford healthcare so that they stay healthy physically and mentally enough to perform their work, in order for the business to run well. When people get overworked they'll start having trouble doing their jobs and customers will be affected either by getting bad products or service, or worse - the biggest contributor to the spread of the cold and flu last winter was people coming into work sick because they couldn't afford to miss a shift. So you have a business literally spreading bad health because they're not looking after the health of their own employees on a larger scale. Whether it's because of bad products, bad service, or bad experiences like getting sick from the person who served them, this will cause a decline in customers. So now the business is suffering a fall in the quality it can provide and losing customers too, and they'll usually try to compensate by pulling even more support from employees and cutting corners on their product, and that only lends itself to making the situation worse and worse. Right now we have all these people up in arms to defend pure, unfettered capitalism, as if there is no greater imperative in the world than generating money, but I agree with Contra - what good does it do to raise all that money if it never translates into a better life for the vast majority of people who raised? And in fact in many cases it gets used to lobby politicians and instill policies that not only try to ensure those people never see a return on all their hard work but actually get less and less of it. In the best case scenario it just gets put in some off shore bank account and sits around never being spent, but collecting dividends that the few powerful elite will splurge on all the while never directly using those funds to truly benefit anyone. Is preserving the freedom to just drain the economy and hoard all the wealth that the country collectively generated so that a handful of people can grow fat off of its fruit while everyone else fights for the scraps that 'trickle down' to the people who did all the hard work really a freedom worth preserving? Is it actually moral to preserve all freedom, even the freedom to destroy other people's lives? Historically society has not allowed this, that's why there are laws saying you can't kill people, or steal, or do other destructive things. We've never been free to indulge in just any and all desires and impulses, yet these corporations are trying every day to establish that kind of freedom for themselves as if no harm could come from it, totally disregarding the massive amounts of harm already being done by them WITHOUT that kind of unfettered freedom. People need to stop looking at generating money as the end all be all goal, the only thing that isn't evil. There need to be checks and balances on all human systems so that they don't collapse. Capitalism can't be allowed to grow disproportionately more significant than humanity, they need to work in tandem. Otherwise It would be like putting a jet engine on a tricycle - it wouldn't do any good because the thing would just rip itself apart and be impossible to steer before it crashed and burned, both the engine and the bike. But, you put a small motor like one of those e-scooters or e-bikes have onto it and you have a perfectly functional tryke that's faster and easier to use. You put a jet engine on a jet and you've got yourself a perfectly functional really fast plane. You mesh the two things (in this case the economy and humanity) together in a way that they can support each other and make the most of each other's strengths, and you get yourself a functional society.

The difference between capitalism and socialism? Capitalism has lots of rich people, socialism has a handful of rich people and lots of poor people. Our society is not perfect, but it has been a story of continual improvement since the very beginning and it will continue on as such unless people who share your agenda are somehow successful in taking down capitalism (I note, without a functional substitute in mind). Historical point: countries that were based on a communist ideology did many horrible things.  General premise: if any country based on a particular ideology did many horrible things, then that ideology should be rejected  Political conclusion: communism should be rejected.  Now the conclusion follows logically from the premises, and the premises look plausible.  But the problem for the anti-communists is that their general premise can be used as the basis for an equally good argument against capitalism, an argument that the so-called losers of economic transition in eastern Europe would be quick to affirm. The US, a country based on a free-market capitalist ideology, has done many horrible things: the enslavement of millions of Africans, the genocidal eradication of the Native Americans, the brutal military actions taken to support pro-Western dictatorships, just to name a few. The British Empire likewise had a great deal of blood on its hands: we might merely mention the internment camps during the second Boer War and the Bengal famine.  This is not mere 'whataboutism', because the same intermediate premise necessary to make their anti-communist argument now works against capitalism:  Historical point: the US and the UK were based on a capitalist ideology, and did many horrible things.  General premise: if any country based on a particular ideology did many horrible things, then that ideology should be rejected  Political conclusion: capitalism should be rejected.  URL

It's not about the hardness of work, it's about the scarcity of the skill. Supply and demand. Relative importance is more or less irrelevant. Relative scarcity is what matters.  This creates some incentives that are bizarre, but scarcity can explain them. Not justify, but explain. Value under capitalism is entirely disconnected from utility. I would argue that is good, because it is the most pure expression of democratic ideas: consumers (all of us) voting with our wallets on what should be valued. Which, I guess, is the Kardashians: we, the people, chose them with money. Yuck.  Marxism is thus inherently anti-democratic: it seeks to connect utility and value even when people explicitly do not want them connected. People reject marxism because it takes away choice, even if it might make them happier. People don't want to be forced into happiness, they want to choose their way into happiness, and marxism is antithetical to that pursuit. Solution?! GEORGISM. We need to get out of the trite dichotomy between capitalism and socialism.   Georgists agree with socialists that capitalism has failed to reconcile fairness with efficiency.   Whereas capitalist policies increase national income, they also cause extreme inequality.  Georgists agree with capitalists that socialism is inefficient because government monopolies are rarely any better than private monopolies.   Most policies to help the poor by equalizing incomes have the negative side effect of reducing the productive power of the economy.   That is why China and Russia shifted from socialism to capitalism in recent decades.  Georgists believe it is possible to unite fairness and efficiency by taxing away the rewards of privilege so that people can earn money only by being productive.   Since much of the power of modern corporations derives from those privileges, proper taxes could reduce that power. So capitalism is good at making lots of things and money. But mostly for people that already have lots of things and money. Proper Government intervention can shift how much of that money goes to people who don't have lots of things and money so that more things and money can circulate in the economy because people with fewer things and less money spend more of what they get than people with more things and money. But the people with lots of things and money are very good at avoiding taxes and if you make taxes too high many of them will move their profits outside the country with or without actually leaving the country. So you need good laws, a careful balance, and not too much corporate lobbying (I think 0 is a good amount). So it is complicated. But with a certain degree of democratic socialism, you can redistribute wealth enough to ensure universal healthcare. It isn't that hard, all the cool countries are doing it, we aren't drowning in taxes, and the waiting lists are mostly only for elective surgery (non-life threatening stuff). I think that it could be possible to socialize basic nutrition and housing, as it has been done in times extreme hardship through charity. And if charities can do it, governments can do it too. Charities only take from the nice people (or people who want to look nice), taxes take from everyone (hopefully). And charities are often very inefficient, like food drives near Christmas that collect tonnes of canned cranberry sauce which is unusable and unfit for human consumption when if they were given cash, they could buy exactly what they need. And tax money is much more consistent and reliable than donations.   So while capitalism has some problematic tendencies, they can be moderated to some degree and it does have some strengths. Mainly that it is good at harnessing incentives to get things made and exchanged. If people don't have incentives to do things, they probably won't do them. And the marginal benefit of spending your time doing one thing over another is what is important, not the absolute value. If everyone is paid the same no matter what they are doing, there are no incentives to make them do the work that actually needs to be done. So while our current system can be greatly improved I don't see how it could economically function without some degree of capitalism.

I love this video, but i feel like it glosses over one important question. At 9:45, Natalie says that she prefers that the economy work for the people, and so we ought structure our economy to maximize human happiness. Very thoughtful series! I do think there are some important pro-capitalism points you didn't address. I'd appreciate it if someone who opposes capitalism reads this and responds; I haven't seen these concerns adequately addressed IMO. The below is pretty rambling and way too long, but I'd really appreciate it if you read it anyway!  I have three major unaddressed objections to anti-capitalism: the empirical, the theoretical, and the moral. I will discuss them in order.  ____________________  Perhaps the strongest argument for the current system is this: it works better than anything else we've tried. The percentage of people living in extreme poverty has plummeted under global capitalism. Seriously. 250 years ago, about 85%-95% of the world was living in 'extreme poverty', as per the UN definiton. Today, it's 9%.  That's not to say the system is any good---it isn't---but please don't replace it with something worse. Namely, don't replace it with anything we've already tried.  Look, by any metric, this is the best period in human history, and it's getting better. The fact that it still sucks is a stark reminder of why we can't afford to go back to the way things were. Prior centuries make 2018 look like a goddamn paradise, so let's not fuck this up, okay? We need to FIX capitalism, not annihilate it.  On a similar note, partially-socialized capitalism is the best form of capitalism, according to the data. From minimum wage to social welfare, socialized capitalism has made the world a better place and addresses the failures of capitalism that it could never fix itself.  ____________  That's the empirical argument for partially-socialized capitalism: it sorta-kinda works, if you're nearsighted and squinting and blind in one eye. And as pathetic as that success is, it is, relatively speaking, a triumph. But why? Why does it work so 'well', relatively speaking? If we can understand that, we can understand what parts of capitalism ought to be defended and what parts ought to be torn down. In my view, it comes down to diversity and fault-tolerance.  Different people have different values and outlooks; if they are free to pursue what they want to pursue and express themselves how they see fit, it should result in people being successful. That's obvious. What might not be so obvious is the efficiency that markets experience when they leverage this diversity. When people are free to follow their passions, you end up with people creating the digital revolution in their garages. Since good ideas can and do come from anywhere, any attempt to enforce conformity and control innovation is bound to slow progress. Similarly, when acting independently and in aggregate, human society converges to a reasonable approximation of the aggregate of what people know and value. Prediction markets/futures markets are the best example---they show the wisdom of the crowds, as long as the members are sufficiently diverse and acting sufficiently independently. I can expand on futures markets if the discussion goes there.  Interrelated to this is the fact that capitalism, like democracy, has a degree of fault-tolerance not seen in any other economic system thus far. Here's what I mean: for any large-scale human societal structure, ask yourself:  *If everyone involved are greedy bastards who care only about themselves, what happens?*  Communism and other forms of totalitarianism fail this test instantly: if power is concentrated, then a selfish leader will fuck everyone else over for their own benefit. Anarchy suffers a similar fate. But democracy and capitalism fare much better. In a democracy, if you only care about your own personal power, you should faithfully execute the will of the people. Otherwise, you'll get voted out and lose your power. Similarly, in capitalism, if all you care about is money, you should make products that people want at prices people like; otherwise, people won't give you money. In particular, you need to keep making better and better things, or more and more food, and do so at cheaper and cheaper prices. Otherwise, a selfish competitor will surpass you.  Obviously, the above is an idealized version of how things are *supposed* to work. Things like monopolies, trusts, and false advertising can break down the system. That's why you need consumer protection laws: their purpose is to ensure that the markets are free, competitive, and based on informed consent. But, in my mind, there's no denying that capitalism fares better under the 'everybody sucks' thought experiment than, for example, communism. It does even better if democratically-enacted consumer-protection regulations are present.   Most of all, I don't want to see *a single point of failure* in a socio-economic-political system. That is, there shouldn't be a single point where, if it breaks, all is lost. When you concentrate power (e.g., by putting a single entity in full control of all markets), you get gulags.  ______  Finally, I want to argue for the morality of capitalistic ideas. As I've alluded to in the above discussion, I think that there are foundational human rights that anti-capitalism denies. If you're opposed to capitalism and have made it this far into my ramblings, do you fundamentally disagree with any of the following claims?  * Generally speaking, people have a right to own things. Private property is just, and its abolition would be oppressive.  * Generally speaking, if Person A owns Thing A, and Person B owns Thing B, but each like the other's thing more, they have a right to swap. People have different values, and if they are uncoerced and acting in full knowledge, they have a right to engage in trade. Markets are just, and their abolition would be oppressive.  * Markets have no reason to be restricted to pairs of people in the same place at the same time. Money, a social construct, allows dozens or thousands or millions of people to engage in trades across spatial and temporal borders. Insofar as it extends the right to exchange private property with consent and without coercion, the monetary system is just, and its abolition would be oppressive.  * With respect to these rights, all people are created equal, and have no more or less intrinsic claim to them than any other.  In my view, the above are the central moral arguments for capitalism. Communism, for example, explicitly denies each of them---except for the last, for it insists that everyone has no right whatsoever to them, and hence technically have an equal right to them. A system that respects and defends the above principles would be a form of capitalism. When capitalism fails to deliver the above, it is failing to accomplish its goal. But, I believe that these rights can be defended in a democratic society: I think capitalism can be fixed, piece by piece, at the ballot box, *without* sacrificing the things it's supposed to stand for.  __________  Thanks for reading, and I apologize again for the unreasonable length. What do you think?

Oh yes, the Capital is the enemy... your very body, your first capital, is the problem. How convenient...  The very problem of your argumentation is that it entirely reposes on human happiness, the most abstract and flickerry thing ever. If happiness is eating and sheltering yourself, *some people say they have found happiness after forsaking all that*...........  The goal of human life is closer to Meaningful Struggle than Happiness, yeah that's Peterson-level of cliche, but it's true. You **WILL** die, thousand of years of happiness can be ruined in 5 minutes of inattention or malice. Your body feels pain and sadness a thousand times more than it feels pleasure (for obvious evolutionary reasons). If happiness is the goal, your entire existence is ill-designed.  If the economy role is to maximize our happiness, well it's already doomed. No, what it is yet one of the thousand tools we have invented to make life bearable enough that we can FIGHT in it, compete with an actual *chance* of winning.  It's a tool, and like all tools it reflects its user.  At best what the user tries to do with it is to make our Struggle meaningful.

Gee, am I a little late to the party. (But not the Party.) No matter, here it goes.  I think there's an element of the capitalist world-view (if there's such a thing) and at the foundation of various philosophies that are either in favor of it as an expression of 1) acceptable status quo; 2) a desirable laissez faire state of affairs or 3) an acceptable compromise with bourgeoisie and ((( bankers))) until the Imperium can be reestablished that is like a see-through, yet completely impermeable film, making the Left's and the Right's arguments slide off of each other like water off a duck.  You, for example, assume as self-evident that feeding thousands of homeless is good and a $2000 pizza is obscene regardless of its gustatory achievements (and doubly so when none are evident). With this, I might agree. Kitty-kat in kombat boots may agree. Whole lot of other perfectly reasonable people even right-of-center may agree. Well then, why can't we all then form a united front against all things bad, rallying around all things good?  What The Golden One and The Crustacean Philosopher might not profess too openly, yet is at the very foundation of the Right is the notion which the Left seems to always sort of circle around, yet ultimately not meet head on, the notion that is is GOOD to let millions starve or be destitute, for implacable Destiny had made them weak and deserving of this faith. The Last Man is feeble, economically inept, and wears last year's Yeezzies. Woe to the Last Man. And of course it's good to have a $2000 pizza, ESPECIALLY if it tastes like crap, because this pizza is a flight of Man's indomitable Spirit, and, as true art, it should have no utility. Hooray for inequality and cruelty, the engines of all great achievements of humanity.  Now, the reason the Left has trouble addressing this head on, is not entirely clear to me. One reason, I think, might be that, whether you'd like to smash TERFs, punch Nazies or guillotine the Royals, you can't be too appalled by cruelty. And that's putting it mildly.   But the other reason might be that, historically, inequality and cruelty have been tried and seemed to have worked nearly unfailingly. As long as you don't go waaaaay overboard and cause a revolution (but even those are always started at the top and for the benefit of the top, and I don't mean this in your dirty gay way, I mean the faction of the ruling class that felt itself shortchanged).   And the Left has nothing, short of a few nearly comical and quick-to-fail examples of Utopias and Kibbutzes, to show for its positive example. And no real desire to debate the Right on principles and values, rather than stupid facts. Who cares if the immigrants are the cause of 1.5% or 35.8% of rapes? It's the Golden Ones who should be raping the immigrants. Else how are we to build das Ewige Reich?   I mean, truer words have never been spoken (at least never with an Austrian accent): 'The best in life is to crush your enemies, see them driven before you and hear lamentations of their women.' 12-year old boys of all races understand, Borban Beeberson understands, Camille Paglia understands, even Milo understands. And what is the Left's answer? 'We need to eliminate the alienation of productive forces from their labor and the added value they blah blah...'  Meh.

So, I agree: capitalism has a LOT of problems. State regulations can make it more bearable (look at Western Europe), but discarding it is... Hard.  1. Even communism is capitalist now. China isn't the biggest growing economy because wealth is distributed equally. Their people produce, and if you don't produce, you die. 2. Money reflects want. So if someone makes outrageous amounts of money. It's not because he works hard. But his work is wanted really badly. Suppose a country taxes rich people a lot, it will push them away. This has happened in most communist regimes. 3. In the same way is communism really bad in making people do more boring jobs. If a task needs to be done. But not a lot of people want to do it, there will be a lot of want (money) for the people that do. So it will be done. If you want equal pay, no one is going to do the shitty job. 4. Money isn't all bad. The 'want' that it represents does correlate with happiness. Supermarkets, medicine, garbage disposal, those are all things we want and we're happy with. Want and happiness just isn't the same. And things like advertisements show the difference.  So an optimal system needs SOME capitalism. We don't want the most wanted people to leave. We want to reward people for doing difficult or boring things. It's about finding the line.   In America's case, I think taxing the rich a fair bit more, and providing more economical safety for the poor are fair things to do. Just know what you're balancing.

I am an economics major, considering post graduate school. ( I only say this as a way to qualify my perspective not as a way of saying I have the answers).  But I do agree that capitalism is inequitable in its income distribition and its central parogative is around explaining how firms maximise profit and how consumer's maximise utility. I've been thinking about this for a while. Utility, philosophically and quantitatively speaking is an almost useless measure of happiness but it is the only means an economist has of understanding consumer satisfaction (at least in main stream economics).  It's really really difficult to implement philosophical rationals into the real world. For instance, public economics (welfare, social security) can only really be understood mathematically at a more advanced level than most undergraduate programs will aproach.   I know this is super rambly, but I guess my central theme is that this stuff is hard to figure out from the economics framework, and it's really easy for someone with a cursory understanding of the subject to walk away with the impression that libertarianism and small govt is the only only way an economy can function.   However, ultimately I think regardless of what form the economy takes, economics will be a large part of how the economy is understood.

One thought: the issue with labor and income inequality is partly due to the supply and demand of/for skilled and unskilled labor. As an absurd example consider Lebron James. Not many people have his skills and his skills are in high demand. This lends itself to a high wage. Now, consider kindergarten teachers. While they indeed do hard and necessary work, many people could do (and would want to do) the job. This has the opposite effect and puts downward pressure on wages. So it is not really a question of how hard a job is to do but rather a question of how many people are willing and able to do the job compared to how needed (for lack of a better word) the job is.   As an example of this in real world, take a look at contrasting qualities of relatively high and low paying college majors (forbes has a good list). Generally, what you will find is that majors that end in higher starting salaries are more difficult and/or unattractive to students yet are in high demand by society (c.f., nursing, engineering, and statistics).   Just my two cents. Great videos.   -friendly neighborhood globalist   PS: I don't mean to pick on teachers. The same logic applies to military servicemen, police officers, etc.
