So, here's your problem.  When you say 'the economy should serve the people,' that's a little bit like saying 'the climate should serve the people.'  The economy isn't a thing that people make or shape - it's a natural, emergent system that springs fully formed from trade systems once they reach a certain level of size and complexity.  You can't control it to the extent that you're assuming.  For instance, you can't solve poverty.  Ever.  You can mitigate it to a certain extent, and you can narrow the gap, but, as some dirty hippy once said, the poor will always be with us.  So long as scarcity is a thing, poverty is going to be a thing.  You can't kill it.  Somebody will always have more while somebody else has less, and the nature of basic supply and demand guarantees that some amount of demand MUST be priced out of any market in order for goods and services to achieve their fair value (and when you try to stop that...well, just look at the seventies for what happens when price ceilings go into effect on critical necessities, and at the right fucking now for what happens when you put price floors in).  Now, what you CAN do is work outside the economy to balance the scales a little bit (a good idea) or you can try to leverage the market to achieve specific goals (neoliberalism getting a little full of itself).  In practice, the latter course tends to have unintended consequences and they're rarely positive, so the only solution you can trust is to directly intervene with an act that is essentially outside the economy.  Nothing is truly outside, of course, but it's basically economy adjacent.  You progressively tax the wealthy and redistribute that cash to fund the sorts of community improvements that would naturally arise from a more affluent population in disadvantaged areas, and you do more than a little bit of direct redistribution of actual cash money (though in practice this tends to evidence itself not as a check from the government, but a smaller bill).  America has been on a ride in the wrong direction of that particular balancing act for about thirty years now, but it's important to realize that the solution is not in any way Marxist because Marx's understanding of economics was...let's say limited.  The appropriate remedies to the situation are already largely in place - they're just not being driven hard enough.  The good news there is that this means we don't have to reinvent the wheel - just increase funding for social programs and finance that action through taxation primarily or exclusively directed toward the disproportionately wealthy.  The political obstacles to that are considerable (Americans, at a pretty fundamental level, believe that they are 'winners,' and only 'losers' need the gub'ment to give them things - overcoming that attitude is pretty much essential if you want to become more Sweden and less Galt's Gulch), but it's a hell of a lot easier than trying to pitch people on fundamental rearchitecture of a system that you can't really fundamentally rearchitect to begin with.

If you want to understand, how capitalism actually undermines our consumer wishes, you just have to think about the internet. With other goods, you might argue, that limited resources can't just be handed out for free (you'd be wrong, but that's harder to explain, so I'll just let that stand). But with data, you can copy it as much as you'd like without it losing any of its properties that make it useful. Imagine all the wealth contained in the internet nowadays: movies, books, music, sources of knowledge, games etc. Theoretically, anyone with an internet connection has an incredible source of wealth at their fingertips. But under capitalism, that access needs to be limited, because you can't make a profit if everyone has access to everything.. So companies have come up with ways of restricting access, prohibiting sharing, thus undermining the very nature of the internet (its very essence being a way of sharing information) itself. In my lifetime I've seen the internet turn from a source of free, nice stuff to a ad-riddled, restrictive nightmare. And finally, I think YouTube itself is a fine example of an incredibly useful product, that millions use all the time, but also one, that everyone hates more and more, with each passing year, with each new problem (just think of the Adpocalypse or the Fair use controversy) because sharing content freely is simply incompatible with capitalism.

Just came across this. You're not my typical viewing and your...unique personality and proclivities aside, I thought the 2 parter was a good series. Here's the thing, your premise is flawed. I don't blame you, liberal arts does a number on how you approach problems. Feely arguments are valid so long as there is a little data to back you up. I understand where you're coming from, I do. Capitalism feels unfair. Thing is, economics-the abysmal science that it is-still has rational actors. We spend money on stupid things when we have disposable income. Or invest it in business when there is a place we can do things new or even just better. That's where most of us are employed, luxury items like cars, tech, entertainment, retail, scientific research, etc. We can't all be farmers and carpenters. We're rational enough to make the right decisions or we'll drive a market to a bubble and ultimately a market correction or crash. In numbers we make intelligent calls... eventually. Socialism doesn't do that because it's directed by a small number of individuals. No matter how well meaning these individuals are they have blind spots and won't invest in a diverse economy. This inevitably leads to a long term collapse. Venezuela is a best case scenario. Their collapse should, I really hope, be short term. There are enough resources to recover, assy least there used to be or socialism. Soviet communism or socialism in general is fundamentally inefficient because every possible economic niche isn't being filled. It's the same as a healthy biosphere, diversity breads durability. That usually means that when things go bad, and they will in any system, the leadership that controls production is left with limited options, usually double down on industries that are no longer sustainable or hide the failure/blame the capitalists. This leads to long term poverty and even though pretty much everyone is equal, they're all poor. During the 2008 crash how many starved in the US? No one who didn't want to. We'd stored a lot of wealth and had a safety net. I'm not going to argue against those-they're obviously helpful. Some public programs are good. Healthcare, might be viable maybe not. A lot of people will lose their jobs though. Take time to research more numerically based econ. Study the thermodynamics...that's what it is after all. It works, regardless of the system in place. The key is how diverse is the system and how efficient it is. Are cities being built in they middle of nowhere just to put people to work or are people moving to places where there is work? Are new and out of nowhere ideas getting into the market or has the mix of industries gone unchanged for the last 50 years?The whole 1% thing us more complicated than many would suppose. Most middle and upper middle class folks that are middle age to retirement will be in that category for a year or two. It's a generational gap more than anything. And the benefit of that stupid pizza is that it takes the wealthy peoples money and gets it back into the economy. Is it gaudy? Sure. I'd certainly feel uncomfortable eating it but if I could charge some nut $2k for a pizza and employ a few more people, or pay the ones I have better, will I. Probably. That's the brutal truth. Ultimately, that money isn't just going to charity to pay for food. It's going to employees who then themselves contribute to the economy. Are there gaps? Yeah, no system's perfect. But those hungry kids have food stamps so they probably aren't going hungry. And that stupid painting paid someone's mortgage. Happiness, levels off because you have disposalable income and the freedom to pursue your dreams out to just live. We can talk about ways to fill gaps but capitalism models natural economic behavior closely. We don't want to get rid of it.

Ironically video games are where I first started to see the negative impact of capitalism on art. Will there be video games after capitalism? Of course there will. And they will be a lot better than the trash they pour millions of dollars into making now.

I disagree with your take on Peter Singer here. I do agree that effective altruism is flawed as a movement. It is immersed in - at best, tacitly, and often explicitly, as in Singer's case - doctrinaire Act Consequentialism. This is the first problem with the movement, given that Act Consequentialism is a bad moral theory (see, moral philosophy 1789-2018). Partly as a consequence of this association, it is infected termite-like with pretty hopeless and toxic liberals. The cumulative consequence of this (see what I'm doing, MacAskill?), is an excessive focus on individual activity and an unwarranted neglect of coordinated, wider systemic change (I can hear the Mills whirling in horror in their graves at what has become of their creed).   Nevertheless, the basic arguments of Singer in ''Famine, Affluence, and Morality' and Unger's 'Living High and Letting Die' remain true today. At least not without further argument and serious engagement, the upshot of their core arguments are not corrupted by the defects of the contemporary effective altruism movement: *relatively globally privileged people have an obligation to donate significant amounts of their non-essential income to high impact charities* ; this is the least strong construable conclusion, but the arguments are independent of abstract moral theory and, I would contend, political ideology. Living relatively modestly and giving to charity does not preclude political commitment and activity. I'm sure you're familiar with the arguments and their general cogency: I think they deserve more than the peremptory half-dismissal presented here. I hope you will engage with the arguments more seriously in the future - if for not for the really serious nature of the issue, then because I am sure your perspective will be interesting, reflective and amusingly conveyed.   I hope it is needless to say that this is intended as constructive feedback - I love your videos.

There's a lot left out between 'you only need $75,000 a year' and 'gentlemen scientists used to exist, so clearly impassioned work is its own reward.'  First, a lot of people DO enjoy working hard in order to be rewarded for it.  Working hard because you think of your wealth as a living video game score is what's sociopathic about the billionaire class: money doesn't matter to them in a material way any more than it did to gentlemen scientists in the 18th century.  Most of the people who do want to work hard and earn more than $75k a year think their work is worth more than the bare minimum because they DO have unusual skills or talents, or they realize the cost of living somewhere that isn't a boring rural shit hole is sometimes way more than $75k a year.  Arguing that some labor is rare and should be incentivized surely isn't arguing for the reptiles.  As for the gentlemen scientists, as much as I love Carl Sagan and his 'curiosity lurks in the heart of every child if you don't crush it' ethos, the fact remains that there were *very very very few* gentlemen scientists in history and a LOT of good scientists who demanded to be paid well for their work.  Jonas Salk is exceptional for NOT patenting his cure.  Unfettered capitalism has failed an enormous swath of the population, but it also HAS rewarded ingenuity and hard work in ways that DID improve billions of people's standard of living.  When people walk down the street screaming 'revolution', I don't think most of them have thought beyond eating the rich, like you pointed out in your first capitalism video.  Not that I thought you contradicted any of that, I just thought the capitalist talking points (common and flawed as they are) were a little bit of a straw man by omission. I disagree that it's 'capitalism' so much as it is individuals making poor choices when they are given choices and freedoms. (To be clear, I still think they should have those freedoms to make those horrible choices, even if they use that ability poorly.)   The definition that many people on the left use for capitalism, 'the private ownership of the means of production.' The body is the ultimate means of all production, so there is a clear problem with that definition.   My critique of the current economic system is its lack of congruity which is what leads to its weakness and ultimately makes it easier to exploit by those who would seek power above all else.   My conception of capitalism from my study of economics is merely the explicit contractual agreement with your community to not initiate force against people who use their bodies to produce, protect, maintain, and exchange things in a fashion which is voluntary. Law in such a system deals with establishing who has attempted to attain something through the use of force and using force to return the goods. In sum, the goal is 'if you acquire something unjustly or that you haven't earned, you have to give it back.'   The problem is that we choose to support things we shouldn't because we are fucking stupid and we don't understand that consequences of our actions. But, would it be more in accordance with the goal of morality (seeking eudimonia) for us to allow people to make mistakes and poor choices or to force them to be unable to fail? Well... the value in life comes from the pursuit of the good and feeling like you are doing something beneficial with your existence. If you give people all the answers, more people might live longer and fewer people may suffer with challenges low on maslow's heigherarchy of needs, but no one will ever truly attain fulfillment or be able to feel accomplished. It is the level of guidance that we give people through regulations and laws that makes our current society feel so vacuous, not the fact that we are surrounded by what you conceive of as capitalism.
Anarcho-socialism is best system of human governance. Communism still features systemic power structures.

Please read Mao so that you can understand what was going on in the USSR and the PRC during and after his lifetime. Just reading a few of his documents, even skimming the little red book, it becomes incredibly obvious that he never abandoned the road laid down by Marx and Lenin. In fact, he continued right where they left off and gave us even sharper tools for our liberation. Mao wasn't a fascist or a hypocrite; for his whole life he led a people to liberate themselves more and more from capitalism. Capitalism has come back since his death, but that didn't bother Marx when he saw the Paris Commune fail, and it shouldn't bother us either; we already know what's possible.  There's a reason the 60s was turbulent across the whole globe, and it's in large part because of the leadership Mao and the people of China showed the world during the Cultural Revolution. That leadership is a large part of why the black panthers existed, why the troubles started, why May 68 in France happened, and why there have been Maoist people's wars in Peru, India, the Philippines, and Nepal. It shook the globe, and people everywhere took notice in big and small ways.  More than just understanding why capitalism is bad, we have to know how to end it and why its end is inevitable, and we have to grasp that truth not only with our minds but also with our hearts and souls so that we can fight for ourselves and everyone we love. Entire countries have done this before, and the entire world will do it one day soon. To anyone in the US who is interested, I suggest looking into the Red Guards collectives and the organizations they support, because they are inspiring and show that the work can and will be done here too, even if the movement is small right now.

I'm not sure we can dissociate glamour from a capitalistic construct, and if we could what alternatives would we point to that do not function as envy-producing, power-perpetuating models?  I am not saying that, for example, wearing glitter on one's body is inherently this or that. I'm only saying that we have to actively redefine it's social meaning, rather than throw all of the glitter we have at our disposal onto ourselves once we've overthrown capitalism. Such celebration is understandable, but is, in the end, capitalism's desperate final attempt to manifest. In other words, if the masses shift toward a gluttonous celebration by way of referencing those luxuries that were prior to this point unavailable to them, we're, in my view, perpetuating the mindless hedonism that capitalism instilled in us (or really perpetuated) in the first place.  If it isn't obvious, I'm not arguing for the deletion of fun and replacing it with pure reasonable responsibility or something like that. Instead I'm arguing for an active, intentional transition process of deconstructing the social value of many commodities, such as those you implicitly (or explicitly) celebrate in this video by assuming the masses can relate to the 'I like stuff' point of view far more than the Marxist jargon initially utilized.  Alcohol, for example, is utterly normalized. From a societal and economic lens, it's transcended its taboo image (maybe since the abolition of prohibition?) and is seen as simply a part of life. Your channel certainly does not challenge this notion (though I admit the argument could be made that you tend to associate consumption of alcohol with the idea that the world is a shitty place, thereby implying that such consumption is our collective desperate attempt to distract from the ills of capitalism).  However, alcohol remains one of the most dangerous commodities in this nation. The statistics are glaringly obvious to me, but if any reader feels they should be cited I'll come back to this thread.  The point is that we are conditioned to value alcohol the way we do at least in part by its market appeal (duh), but most of the alternative factors involve capitalism indirectly, such as the perspective implied- or at least the perspective I interpret- in your videos. Not only do they involve capitalism, they at least keep it as the status quo, and at worst perpetuate it.  On a case by case basis, shit happens and escapes are necessary/understandable (I use alcohol as such an escape myself), however, if in the minds of revolutionaries or 'socially enlightened' figures overthrowing capitalism simply translates to a hedonism no longer impeded by mandatory competition, wealth disparity, or professionalism being the metric for moral soundness,  then I need to seek out a different group.  In short, we definitely acknowledge many of the same problems of capitalism, but we seem to be differing on the degree of emphasis needing to be placed on collective intentionality for cultural innovation so that we're not mindlessly flopping around once we've achieved the next economic reality.

I disagree when that many of the things we like will still exist without capitalism. Sure they will still exist in some form but capitalism is what allows the allocation of so much resources to those things to make them at that scale or quality. Video games for example would all be indie level without capitalism. There wouldn't be any expensive triple A games because those resources would be better spent on things like infrastructure. There would be no more Marvel movies for the same reason. You can argue that those  things are not necessary, but that is exactly the point. Without capitalism they would not get made and so it is a bit disingenuous to imply that without capitalism we will still get the same stuff.

I'll say this much about the wealth stratification & happiness threshold (and this is purely anecdotal, so take it with a grain of salt): I live next to a community of multi-millionaires, and they absolutely flip their shit when a property tax is issued or the marginal tax rate is bumped up, even if by a fraction of a percentage point. I straight-up asked a guy (after he had calmed down a bit from raging at the sky) why he was so mad - the tax wouldn't impact his well being, wouldn't impact his ability to leave inheritance for his family succession & wouldn't impact his ability to grow his business.   It impacted his net worth, is what he told me, and this positioned him at a social disadvantage to those who didn't live with such a tax. People over in Vancouver with much more lax taxes would treat him like the weak little bitch with a weak net worth.    There's this entirely new social dynamic at the upper echelons of wealth that we just don't even notice while we're hovering around or below the happiness threshold (which is why Donald Trump's 'real net worth', which most people couldn't give a fuck about, mattered so much to the wealthy commentators who kept bringing it up during the American election). I think you might be able to liken it to (and I realize this is silly, but it's the comparison that jumps to mind) someone's Xbox Achievement score, where people get surprisingly competitive & aggressive over a very arbitrary & easily inflated number.

I was studying to become an accountant until financial aid ran out. This is one of the things that got me riled up. Current economic theory, specifically Reaganomics or trickle-down economics/voodoo economics/supply-side economics, is that we should sacrifice the standard of living for the GDP. The only reason anyone cares about the GDP is that it is an indirect measure of the standard of living. So, the current economic theory is that humanity exists to serve the economy, and realizing that is how I became a socialist. I lay awake at night pissed as fuck because people think this is a good economic theory. Literally, the only way to support it is to not understand the conversation, that's how goddamn stupid a theory it is. And this is the thing that rules our political discourse, an idea disproven by definition alone, proven faulty by all of history, the idea that humans exist to serve a byproduct of their existence. The only thing that makes this more comical, is that the Republican party, obsessed with the economy as it is, has a worse track record than the Democratic party when it comes to supporting the economy. It's almost like the theory that depends on not understanding what words mean doesn't work

From a longer and broader look at history, I would say that much of human history boils down to a kind of class warfare waged by the haves vs the have nots, and occasionally the have nots towards the haves when things become unbearable and too oppressive.         Let's go deeper than political labels, terms, and concepts and get to the root of this.  I think that root and core has to do largely with psychopathy, which is a severe lack of felt empathy and conscience at it's core (the kind of, 'Let them eat brioche' kind of mentality, mind or 'heart' set).  And perhaps in the context of, vs the rest of us--i.e. the majority who have some empathy and conscience.         NO, I am not saying all the 'haves' are all psychopathic. Psychopaths make up a fairly small subset of the general population (depending on what source you cite, it ranges from 1 to 4%  Tbh, I doubt it can even be measured accurately within even a +/- of 2% range).           I'm more so saying that there seems to be a long term, repeating trend of psychopathic types eventually weaseling their way into positions of most power and wealth, and then negatively influencing and affecting the society and civilization they are found within, towards that of eventual breakdown and entropy through corruption, greed, inequality, misuse of power.           In today's society, this avenue of power is primarily through banks, corporations, and government.  I'm not even sure if I should mention government as a separate avenue since it's been so infiltrated by the former two that it's practically, though not completely, an extension of the former two.  Or in common parlance, it's largely become 'bought and sold'.        Who but psychopaths can wage wars for completely unjust and self serving reasons?  Who but psychopaths can develop, foster, and maintain systems that not only promote but reward individuals, groups, belief systems, and ways of living that create inequality?           Yet, to some extent, we, the majority of non psychopathic types, are complicit to some degree or another, so we cannot solely lay the blame on them alone.  We allow ourselves to be duped, bamboozled, and manipulated. They dangle the carrots of materialism (the belief system of happiness via stuff, status, and/or power) and we follow.  We've become an entirely too materialistic society (and increasingly cut off from nature), which is helping them to phase us and society into their image.  That breakdown/entropy point has begun for current civilization.       It's interesting to compare and contrast these larger, more organized civilizations (Babylon, Egypt, Persia, Greece, Rome, Huns, the 'West' + America in general, etc) with smaller and nature based societies (often referred to as 'primitive', indigenous, or the like).  These were aware of and had their names/labels for psychopaths as well, but rather than let them connive, con, and weasel their ways into positions of overmuch power and influence, they usually dealt with them swiftly and harshly once they started to cause problems for the tribe/community.  It was understood and realized that they wouldn't and likely couldn't change their ways of causing harm to others. They were either booted out, or killed.        Being nature and community based, and often having some kind of strong spiritual and/or nonphysically oriented core of ideals and/or beliefs, they could not be bamboozled and tempted so easily by such types.  Perhaps the smaller size and population also just made it easier in some ways, since everyone tended (tends for current ones) to know each other more fully and more intimately.  Plus, everyday survival and relying on one's community and neighbors was such an ongoing and vital part of life that you probably tended to look a little deeper at and into those around you.         Solution(s):  Become educated about real psychopathy research and not Hollywood and media versions which tend to be exaggerated, distorted, and often focus on the rare extremes even within same, such as serial killers and the like. Most psychopaths are too smart, self controlled, and self protective to become serial killers, or even occasional killers, except in the legal and government sanctioned forms like wars. Your average psychopath is your surface friendly politician, police officer, fireman, CEO,, t.v. media teleprompter reader, lawyer, or the like.        Start demanding that positions that inherently give power and authority which can really affect the lives of others, be subjected to a battery of tests that can help to weed out psychopathic types.  Whether talking police, congress, parliament, CEO's, to Presidents, Prime Ministers, etc. There is increasingly accurate and more objective testing being developed such as brain scans, pupil/emotional reaction to different stimuli, and other ways that are already being used in a research way.  As we are learning more, we can develop better testing.       Potential police candidates do go through some very basic testing, but it's along much more subjective, psychological questionnaire and interviewing type, which is not (obviously) adequate. Psychopathic types are often very good at conning those of us with empathy and conscience.  Sometimes they are even downright charismatic and 'likable' on the surface.        Start moving back more to nature and real community as a culture and society in different ways, and start becoming less materialistic and ego based.        Ultimately the change starts with us on an individual level.  The more who choose and align to real Love--(universal) and who become more and more healthy and positive within, the more it will spread, strengthen, and eventually become easier for the many.  It's a quiet, but potent revolution of consciousness, and this too has begun alongside the entrophic societal breakdown.          Though it might come off as 'fringe' and out there for this largely intellectual type crowd (in some ways, I'm much more a mystic at my core, having had a number of so called 'unusual', nonphysical oriented experiences), I would also add that we are getting various kinds of behind the scenes help, and likely will get some dramatic, obvious help in the near to nearish future. You fail to grapple with any of the real challenges to capitalist critiques, almost all you produce are strawmen only said by those attacking capitalism. For instance no one actually defends the view that the ultrarich 'deserve' their billions while the poor toil away in run-down areas (in fact many would laugh at the conception of anyone 'deserving' any level of wealth given the desperate poverty which has gripped most of humanity throughout history). To quote Milton Friedman one of the greatest economists and statisticians of all time, 'Most economic fallacies derive from the tendency to assume that there is a fixed pie, that one party can gain only at the expense of another.' This fallacy is committed throughout in talking of the maldistribution the existing wealth produced by the capitalist system, it is precisely the capitalist system which allows for such accumulations that produces the observed level of wealth. You also fail to mention the value of the price system in allowing for the communication of the distributed knowledge of our preferences so that shortages and waste is minimized. This is not a serious critique of capitalism, but rather crude propaganda.

I have many criticisms of our economics but I think that founding those criticisms broadly on capitalism is chasing a red herring.  Every economic system I can think of had an elite, a middle people, and the suffering. Very small societies sometimes were an exception but in any large feudalist, communist, or capitalist society this pattern emerges. As long as people are interested in having more than other people around them the same problems will emerge in any system. The golden Pizza never existed to taste good, it exists as a blazing pronouncement that I have so much I can afford to waste. And it's not a new thing lords have forever been seeking ways to distinguish themselves from the masses. The roots are in psychology not economics.

Supermarkets are the reptiles. Banks are the reptiles. Insurance companies are the reptiles. Corporate media are the reptiles. The Film and Music industry are the reptiles. Congress are the reptiles. Big Oil are the reptiles. etc.  You have no choice but to invest in the reptiles; you cannot survive, legally, within the framework of society, without funding these establishments. Taxes to fuel subsidies and people who don't work at all really exasperate this problem...   And yes, while ironic, a lot of the people who happen to be the CEOs are Jews; presumably this is just ironic coincidence, and Feminists would be as valid in saying that all men are reptiles because the CEOs are men as the conspiracy theorists on the right side (in perfect parallel) would be in saying that all Jews are reptiles because the rich people happen to have money.   You want to stop everybody from misinterpreting the situation and create enemies based in identitarian mode of thought? You should address the dynamic that makes somebody the 'reptile' instead of the people who happen to be the reptiles.

Hey! First of all, your awesome! Thanks for the videos. On min 12:20 you said that the problem of inequality is that people working really hard in sweatshops are not making a lot of money. Now, some jobs are really important but the supply is always low, such as engineering, so you need to pay more to incentivize people like me who don't like to digest a ton of boring a$$ math to go into the field while discouraging overcrowded fields such as unskilled labor. A solution would be free education and a better chance in high school for teens to sample possible future careers paths as well as giving them info on the demand and pay of different careers paths (instead of wasting their time). A decent minimum wage to increase demand (Ford pay his employees well enough to afford his cars) and a general system more like the European one also could be of help.

20 year old college dude here: I used to be a staunch right-wing libertarian activist and pretty active in their circles... and then I watched your channel. Since early high school years, I've looked all over the internet and debated all kinds of people on political issues, but it only solidified and strengthened my confidence in the ideas of free-market capitalism. Part of why I turned to radical right-wing politics in the first place was due to my family's background. They grew up in the Soviet Union, so I'd been more than briefed on the corruption and atrocities of Stalinist-era 'communism.' I delved into literature  on classical liberalism, anarcho-capitalism, etc.. for years and mindlessly followed the ramblings of the capitalist intelligentsia. It wasn't until I stumbled on your channel, ContraPoints, that I'd heard some of the best critiques of neoliberalism and developments in radical right-wing culture in contemporary contexts.  Thanks to you, I've gradually found myself aligning more with the left and shifting mindsets on all sorts of topics.

There are still people who do philanthropic things in a capitalist system so the polio example to showcase how a world without capitalism would be more giving is somewhat flawed, especially when considering the system gives  people a reason to work and do the great work that they do. Although people are unfairly paid it constantly gets better because the system helps correct injustices because of buying power from the consumer. Don't like that Nike uses sweatshops, buy another brand. There will always be those who are unjustly paid though because people are imperfect so creating anything that is 'perfect' will always be imperfect to someone else. Doesn't mean that we shouldn't aim for something better but in the words of Churchill, 'Capitalism is the worst economic system except for all the others.' Until someone figures out a better one it's the best system so far. I would argue that as social creatures our lives are more fulfilling when we focus on others as well instead of materialism but the fact that capitalism creates an environment where people do not have to hunt all day for food or build their own homes and defend their land from other humans directly (for like 90% of people) allows us to focus on community, family, and friends more than we would have to otherwise. I think anyone though that believes capitalism is perfect is off their rocker but there are definitely huge benefits that would make a video amiss that addresses capitalism and doesn't discuss how much capitalism has forwarded civilization while at the same time exploiting people. I also believe that the goal of capitalism is not to maximize happiness but to put people in positions where their skills are best suited (like in administrative positions) to try and bring happiness from a work environment to government level. The framework that has allowed inventions like the washing machine, automobiles, and smart phones would be difficult to have invented if the legal and societal structure weren't there to provide resources and incentive ($) to make these things that have helped us get to where we are now (less time wasted on washing clothes, trying to walk someplace, or talk to friends/family so we have more time to talk about why capitalism sucks :) ). Idk I could be wrong too.  Love your videos, keep up the good work!

Utilities and cable companies would probably be good targets. I'm not sure the tax code would currently support this but it could be made to support it: the hostile takeover targets could then be controlled by not-for-profit organizations. You're wrong. Very, very wrong. You're working on the assumption that wealth is distributed, as though it was a naturally occurring resource that everyone is entitled to an equal share of. It isnt: it's earned. The fact that it is 'distributed unequally' has nothing to do with capitalism. The cause of the unequal distribution is the Pareto principle. Any accumulation of wealth is aportion of the sum of an emergent systemic process of decision making engaged in by us all. What accumulates will inevitably accumulate more in few people, in the same way that only a few stars and black holes in our galaxy contain almost all the mass; they bigger they got, the more mass they attract. The more mass they attract, the bigger they got. They aren't greedy reptilian capitalists. They're stars.  The reason this pisses you off is another erroneous assumption: that in the absence of malign influence, economic outcomes would be evenly distributed. But nothing in the world has ever been evenly distributed.   I like the example of tornado's. Being an apparently ubiquitous weather phenomenon, it strikes people as bizarre when they learn that the vast majority of tornado's occur in one place: the Midwestern United States. But why? Are there weather racists that onlynlet the poor tornado's occur in one place, and do we need to Rosa Parks the mother-fucker and redistribute those tornado's over the planet so that they can finally experience justice and suck up cows into the upper atmosphere wherever they like? Or is it simply that other locations around the globe lack the prerequisites for tornado's to occur.   The tornado's have rights, but...you know. That's life I guess.

I like stuff too. Not shiny things though. Most of my stuff is crummy, used or old. But it's my stuff. I like my books. Sometimes I like to revisit my favorite passages. In some of them, I've written a lot of notes, and it's often interesting to see how my mind has changed about certain over time things or how it hasn't. Some of my stuff I've inherited from my grandparents, and it brings me joy to use my grandma's saucepan to cook mushrooms, when she's no longer able to. Some of my stuff, I've built myself, and I've fixed even more of it. I'm not saying I did a good job, but I'm proud nevertheless. I am not going to let anyone take those things away from me. I even like my stock. Not because it's worth a lot. Because it isn't. But it was my decision to buy it. A bad decision, you might say, but I own it, and I still have hope in the company. My partner and I have arguments about this all of the time. My headspace is squarely within the wealth-sharing, egalitarian side of economic theory, whereas his is more nebulously capitalist, with a strong lean towards 'taming, controlling, and regulating the beast'.  He also has a background in finance and business, so his insights hold some value to me as expertise, even if at times it feels more like he drinks the 'kool-aid' than actually believes in its theoretical foundation.  He doesn't think our more utopian vision of the future will be possible until all of our necessities like food, water, shelter, electricity, internet, medical care, etc. are inexpensive or free, universal, and made through fully automated means. Until that point, he believes that careers that earn people less money will always be the foundation of a capitalist economy, precisely because those job paths are inexpensive and multitudinous. An example: most Americans like to eat cheeseburgers and live in houses. Thus, McDonalds jobs and construction labor jobs are easy to come by, but are relatively unprofitable. Whereas, famous, well-received artists are fewer and farther between, so the market values their economic output more. In my opinion, this is of course unsustainable and cruel, but it's the 'nature of the beast' to capitalists.  In his view, the future we all want is one where the necessities of our lives are free, fully automated, and fully regulated, while the Capitalist economy that would still exist afterwards would only be sustained by the value we decide to place into it, via our non-essential skills in more luxurious, consumptive markets like culinary arts, travel, hospitality, sports, design, art, music, film, TV, etc.  In my view, this is just as utopian as my view of an ideal future, and it too heavily relies on a benevolence we would have to entrust the ruling classes with. But of course, what do I know.

Adam Smith and David Ricardo figured that out and Marx does does too but then says it's awful.  Your forgetting that anyone can be good at a lot of things at the same time but to be great at a few things makes more sense because individual preferences change and adapt.  It brings massive efficiencies and lower costs overall to the general consumers.  This sort of quasi jack of all trades for all makes everything sluggish.  Ironically, Marx and Engles Manifesto, the first few chapters glorify the good things capitalism has brought to societies. This creative destruction that got rid of the old and brought in the new. 9:16 Capitalism leads to innovations in technology, which in turn lead to less labor needed to do the same work and the currency acquiring a higher value, and those changes make life cheaper and easier, giving people more time to be human.  12:12 Sweatshops don't exist in the US; although, I wouldn't be surprised if there are a few that employ undocumented immigrants. Workers in manufacturing in the US tend to get paid pretty well for their work. Work in factories tends to be very difficult and dangerous. Difficult and dangerous work almost always pays well, and definitely quite a bit more than minimum wage. Those people could find jobs as fast-food workers and janitors, but they choose not to. I would think that factory workers in the US get paid somewhere in the range of $15-$30 per hour depending on where they work. Factories in the US aren't like the sweatshops in many Asian countries. Also, if a worker gets injured on the job, the company he works for has to pay the medical bills for his injuries as well as pay him for all the days he can't work, and the company can't fire him. The workers will sometimes sue the company, and the company will have to invest in improving the safety of the workplace to avoid more lawsuits. The United States has regulated capitalism and big corporation can't treat their workers like slaves like they had done throughout the Gilded Age.  Also, thanks to capitalism, when companies don't want to spend as much money on workers, they invest in engineers to develop more efficient tools and machines for manufacturing. With better technology, we have safer working conditions and less people needed in manufacturing jobs. Therefore, less people being exploited and dying from work related injuries, and a higher demand for STEM related jobs that require higher education. This has also resulted in those companies paying there workers higher wages for their hard and dangerous work. Nobody would work in such a place if it paid minimum wage or anything near it, it would be very illogical.  My dad works in remodeling. It doesn't require any higher education, but the work really makes you exhausted and you always sweat like a dog. Sometimes you work in a very cold or hot environment. Sometimes you work in a dusty environment, or an environment filled with toxic materials in the air. There's also the risk of getting some pretty nasty injuries if you're not careful enough, like getting a nail in your foot or losing some fingers. Working in remodeling can have pretty negative effects on your health; therefore, people who work in remodeling don't tend to live as long. However, in exchange for your hard work, you get paid between $20 and $30 per hour. No fast-food worker or janitor gets paid that much, and those jobs require the same education as jobs in remodeling.  Most wealthy people who would spend $2000 on a pizza would not get a pizza like the one shown in that Buzzfeed video. They would spend that kind of money to buy a pizza from one of the best pizza chefs in the world, because they have a passion for good food. Only some crazy rich people buy food with gold in it.

You're thinking about this the wrong way. Bartering for things of value is human nature. If you try to squelch this because some people are too good at it, you'll won't be able to. Look at the drug war, is it working? No. People are just selling drugs illegally. Why? Because other people strongly want to buy drugs. If I have something of value, or am able to provide a service of value, people will give me other stuff of value for it. You can call this 'capitalism' if you want, but it's not really a system, it's just the way humans are. The best we can do is try to prevent people from getting an unfair advantage. But you can't stop people from trying to acquire things of value. And you can't change the reality that some people will be better at it and will acquire more things.   Trying to implement systems that go against fundamental human nature never works, because people literally can't help defying your system. Sharia isn't going to stop adultery or 'fornication', for example. The drug war isn't stopping drug sales. Banning abortion won't stop 'back alley abortions'. And communism will not, and never has stopped inequality. All you'd be doing is agreeing to willingly give all the wealth to a small group of people who would then use it to mercilessly prevent anyone else from acquiring wealth (and as I said, they certainly will try). And you're trusting these people to 'redistribute' the wealth fairly. Which they won't. This expectation also contradicts human nature. How many examples of this do you need before it becomes clear to you? What are they teaching in philosophy majors these days. Jesus Christ.

The labor you call 'exploitative' is causing the world rate of poverty to drastically decline and will almost end in the next 20 years. Also, the Buzzfeed video - you had pleasure from eating food, you gave the audience pleasure in watching, you paid off all the people it took to make the video (production team, all the people who picked the crops to make the wheat, the cheese makers, etc.), and everyone benefited. The real problem is that as we move to a service economy, less and less people will be needed for labor which will eventually cause the need for a basic income, but that's because WE PROGRESSED SO MUCH. I swear to God, you are going to be flying in your car, drinking a potion which makes you live to be 500, eating food made entirely by machines without water, with the entire world out of poverty, and saying, 'But, not everyone is equal.' Personally I believe that a decent way of combating capitalism is to fight it within it's largest sphere of power...... The market place itself.  The idea is to form cooperatives that would create and sell products like any normal business but the main difference is that these cooperatives would be owned by the workers with elections to decide who shall lead the cooperative. Once the cooperative has become a rather successful business than you atempt to find another cooperative and form a sort of cooperative partnership and the goal is to keep expanding until there is a sort of union of cooperatives in multiple industries under a sort of similar system (or at least under multiple systems that aren't a threat to each other) and if this union of coops where to be formed than that union would be tasked to make as much profit as possible whilst keeping a worker based republic or any other worker based democratic system. I think that most problems you are describing are caused by few main things: 1.) Patents. They stifle competitive market and allow swollen corporations to grow while being grossly ineffective and treating their workforce as crap. 2.) Regulations that require proactive compliance. I believe that you should be able to just do stuff you love and make as much or as little money on it as you like, as long as you are not hurting anyone. Regulations that require proactive compliance force you to use scummy business practices until you can afford to comply with them. 3.) Corporations as a legal business entity itself is a problem. You should be able to do any voluntary deals you like, and earn billions through signing such contracts and employing lots of people, but you should also be legally responsible for your actions. CEOs would rarely do any fraudulent things if they could be personally punished for the consequences.  4.) This is the biggest one - remove a legal responsibility of a corporation to maximize profits! Right now, if you don't do every single money grabbing thing you can think of, you are actually breaking the law. That definitely has to go, and it would solve so many problems.  Removing those problems is very easy, all it takes is to scrap a bunch of laws. Direct responsibility and fair competition with no ability to hide behind a corporation or a patent would solve a lot of that.   And I definitely have to disagree that capitalism must be removed. I am open to less intrusive corrections, like basic universal income, especially when automated labor makes labor of large amount of population unnecessary, but I am strongly against deciding how much someone needs or deserves and redistributing it. It some robs people of ownership of their work and others of responsibility for their destiny, often - a reason to live. You partially or fully enslave some people to partially or fully infantilize others. The reason is total misery, and it is no wonder that any economical model other than capitalism requires tyranny and totalitarian terror to exist. Countries like Soviet Union could only last because of prolific black markets, otherwise people there would have kept starving to death by millions well after the Holodomor.  My basic idea is reducing state to bare minimum, removing both things that harm and benefit the rich people, maximizing freedom and opportunity in favor of security. Hi Contrapoints! I really enjoy a lot of your videos, and both this and Part 1 were good at both analysis and entertainment. However, I'm concerned by the use of the lizard metaphor for capitalists/capital itself. While you explicitly clarified you don't mean it to refer to Jewish people, and in your Part 1 you referenced David Icke's conspiracy theory, I think that the 'lizard overlords' is such an antisemitic conspiracy theory/dogwhistle thanks to Icke that trying to use it in a different way just doesn't make much sense and detracts from your overall point. While Icke's use of antisemitism through Protocols of Elders of Zion involves his claims about actual bona fide lizard people, SO many antisemites use the lizard people/lizard overlord metaphor as a dogwhistle even though they don't actually believe in the lizard part. Rather, it becomes a way to blast antisemitic rhetoric about Jewish control of the world without actually saying the word 'Jewish' and sparking outrage, but still signaling their true intent. Someone who uses 'lizards' in the exact way you do to describe capitalism in another context, maybe a tweet or Facebook post or another Youtube video, would use it to mean truly vile antisemitic propaganda. That's something that no leftist should want to associate with! While you mentioned Icke in terms of his selling a lot of books through conspiracy theory, I think it's just a terrible metaphor for trying to sensationalize a philosophical and ideological argument. There are so many better ways to make it interesting, other words to call capitalists or etc, than using this conspiracy theory that has basically become inseparable from antisemitic connotations in modern Internet culture. While it's good you clarify your intention with who you're referring to as lizards, it was still deeply unsettling to watch these two videos and see that rhetoric again and again that has origins in arguments that are so contrary to what you were trying to say. This detracts from your overall message, and probably alienates a large number of Jewish anticapitalists in your audience. As leftists, we need to stand up to antisemitism and show support for Jewish people, and I think that no matter how good your intentions are in this video, using the lizard analogy has such an antisemitic history and ugly connotations to this day that even with your disclaimer, it just can't be fully separated from that.

I think comparing capitalism to communism is apples to oranges. Communism is a founded system, whereas capitalism is an emerging system. I create a knife. You need a knife. i give you the knife I made. You promise me an amount of food for that, food that I couldn't get because I was busy making a knife. Of course, I want a bit more food. You know. For resource security. So that I have something to eat while I am between knives. Profit. Since you won't be making your own knife, you agree to this 'favour' I ask of you, and give me a bit of extra food. Simply put, that is the essence of capitalism: 1-on-1 trade with a bit extra on the side.  The problem with 'capitalism' as I see it is not capitalistic at all. Not really. The problem is that an aristocracy has accrued power, and is using that power to gain privileges for themselves, while limiting the amount of power other individuals have access to. And this... This situation will occur in any society. It doesn't matter if you get your soldiers because of the law you made, or because you can pay them. The end result is that you wield more power than others, and wield enough power to secure that power. It's not a uniquely capitalist problem.  As for 'will there be games?' Tetris... Isn't a good example. Because it has zero story. Yes, it is a great game, but gaming today is not just about scorepoints. Story and character perspectives are incredibly important to many people's gaming experience.  Communist countries don't produce a nice diversity of stories. They just don't, because diversity means a challenge to an authority that remains in power in large part because of its insistence on conformity. in our capitalist West, we can make The Last of Us. We can make Dragon Age. We can make the Witcher. We can make Metroid, we can make Skyrim, we can make all sorts of games with all sorts of stories, all sorts of characters, all sorts of perspectives. As long as you can find a market for it, you can make it and sell it, and it really doesn't matter who does or does not approve. The same is not true in a society where you are banned from the market because your perspective does not jive with that of the Authority.  Soviet Russia created especially great music. Bombastic music. Music that celebrated Soviet Russia. Music... Without a message or perspective other than the Greatness of Russia.  Soviet books that recieve high praise were generally written and published in secret. Illegally.  Art does not survive uniformity.

There's a couple of major flaws with your critique. First of all capitalism isn't a system that creates wealth inequality. The problem of wealth inequality is deeper than capitalism and broadly speaking comes down to differences is capability of individuals leading to a differences in value output. These are differences that are rooted in biology, peoples IQ and trait contentiousness plus a lot of other factors, like luck, timing, etc. There has been vast differences in wealth all throughout human history and certainly long before there were any kind of cohesive socioeconomic structures like capitalism. What you are however ignoring is that capitalism has vastly increased the absolute wealth of basically everyone. When you reward high IQ people who have the ability to generate vast amounts of value for the planet to enjoy, they're motivated to keep doing it, they find ways to better achieve that.  Secondly, while wealth inequality has grown, the total (absolute) wealth has also grown massively, while the people at the bottom of capitalistic hierarchies have significantly less wealth than those at the top, they also have significantly more wealth than those people who are equal under non-free hierarchies, ones like communism where the markets are centrally run. And the evidence for that is plastered throughout history, if you look at say the USA post indepedence, they were one of the freest countries from state power, thats why they fought the UK for their Independence because of the tyranny of the government. And look at their staggering increase in wealth and quality of life from then to now. Then compare the same time period in say the USSR where millions of people starved to death.  Sadly this has the classic look and feel of people who don't really care about the poor. If you care about the poor you'd want the best for them and the poor are richest under capitalist (free) economies, than what they'd be under basically any other non-free market system. It seems like all you care about is lowering the wealth of others so that everyone has the same amount of stuff, a race to the bottom. That it's OK to make the poor people poorer because at least then they're on equal terms with the rich then.  Making the argument about happiness is all fine and well, the data on that is clear. But it's up to individuals to decide what they'd rather do, either be happy by focusing less on wealth once they hit diminishing returns. On average the happiness of women has declined steadily since WW2 whereas men's is about the same. The freedom to work and focus on careers has not made them happy, the highest levels of happiness reported by women is when they're mothers and raising children in a stable and provided for family. Yet presumably you would not accept the happiness argument in this context?  Finally the best arguments for capitalism is that free trade absent any coercion/force/violence is the most moral system that exists, it's also one of the most efficient. If A and B want to trade privately goods/services they legitimately own then that occurs with consent of both people. Then if person C comes along and redistributes that wealth somewhere else they have to do it through force, which is immoral. When you have free trade absent force you develop high trust societies and the higher the trust the less the financial overhead and the richer we all become.

11:50 'and honestly, I don't really understand how the economy works'  And this is the core problem with your work here... You don't actually know what you're talking about but you're still talking about it like the fool you are. While this is a great example of the Dunning-Kruger effect, what you're doing is irresponsible and you should feel ashamed.  Have you considered that an inefficient allocation of resources literally results in unnecessary death and suffering? As you don't understand how an economy works, you've taken a lot of characteristics of an economy for granted, such as what is driving all the economic activity that generates wealth and improves living conditions across the board, and you don't seem to understand that by messing with the free market, you can only decrease the efficiency of the economy and therefore create needless death and suffering. What you are advocating for, whether you realize it or not, will result in needless death and suffering, which is ironically, what you're trying to avoid. The free market simply can't be tweaked and configured to improve things, as you seem to believe is possible. You either take the free market as it is, or you mess with it and make things worse. There is no third option.  Have you considered that income inequality gets worse when state power increases, even if you're increasing state power specifically to reduce inequality? Basically what will happen if you attempt to re-distribute the wealth of the rich, is that the rich and powerful will use their resources to acquire state power (if they haven't already), which will ensure their stuff isn't taken and re-distributed. By expanding state power, you're literally giving the people whose wealth you think you can re-distribute the power to prevent this from ever happening. Simply take a look at the world right now - corporations are being subsidized with tax money, they receive all kinds of tax breaks, bailouts, etc... Do you not understand what is happening here? They control your precious government and they are using it to prevent their wealth from being re-distributed.   Have you considered that the state is a tool being used by the rich and powerful to maintain their positions in society, and not a tool that the weak and the poor have the resources to wield? Just think about it logically - do you expect people who were resourceful enough to amass a fortune to sit idly by and let their fortune be taken? Or is it more likely that they will employ their resources to seize control of the tool you're attempting to use to take their stuff, thereby making your objective impossible? This really isn't that complicated, and we've seen this play out, time and time again. The state doesn't serve the weak and the poor, it serves the rich and the powerful because only the rich and powerful have the resources required to seize control and wield the power of the state.  It's really sad how people seem to believe the government is the answer to all their problems, when in actual fact, it's the tool which is being used by the rich and powerful to create and maintain them. At the same time, they reject the freedom that what will bring them salvation, by putting them on equal footing with the rich and powerful. Instead, they would rather expand the power of their oppressors while deluding themselves into thinking that they are going to take from a group of people that is smarter and generally more resourceful than them.

Income inequality exists for multiple reasons. 1.  People don't work the same number of hours. 2.  People that work the same number of hours, may not work at the same time of day (such as serving foor at 2AM vs serving food at 12PM), which in the service industry (like, say Taco Bell cook) means that no one is there to utilize your labor as effectively to pay you for your food. 3.  People don't work in the same locations, which means the subjective desires of the place you work may not be the same as the place that others work. 4.  People do not work at the same productive capacity in the same number of hours, e.g, if I work as a programmer, I might not work at the same capacity as someone that has worked as a programmer for several years (I would need to look for reference more often than a pro) OR I might goof off and watch youtube videos while programming. 5.  Certain jobs are in greater demand in modern society, I will make more money building computers than I will building rolodexes. 6.  Sweatshop workers work hard, but what they are doing isn't valued by society.  If I don't need something made in a sweatshop (no demand) then I will not pay for it.  This puts the productivity of a sweatshop worker at $0 if every person were like me, which would put them out of business.  However, not everyone is like me and some people might want whatever a sweatshop worker is selling, it then comes to how much of the customer's labor they are willing to spend in exchange for the labor of a sweatshop worker.  Let's say they are making shoes.  How can a sweatshop worker fight against automation?  By lowering the value of their labor to compete against machines.  Machines require fewer resources to be productive than people in many cases, which means I will either pick the underpaid sweatshop worker's shoes or the automatically manufactured ones.  Automation drives down labor value. 7.  You have to ask yourself why people work at sweatshops.  What are the trade-offs?  Perhaps the government in the area collapsed for budget reasons and heavy regulatory costs made businesses impossible to be run at profit or equilibrium.  Income inequality is more a difference in productivity.  Do not confuse productivity for merit or hard work, your productivity is the subjective value people give to your labor. An example of this is gold, if I have a home and find a gold vein in my backyard, and it takes me 2 hours to collect 2 kgs of that gold to sell, then my labor value is whatever people are willing to pay for that 2kgs of gold.  The going price for gold is about $44,000 per kg.  Therefore, my productivity (excluding the time it took to sell it) is $44,000 per hour.  If no one wanted to purchase that gold, my productivity would have been $0 and so would my labor value.  Remember, a non-profit business is always more efficient than a for-profit one.  You only gain profit when people are willing to pay you more than the cost of maintaining the manufacturing process.  Maintenance: labor, machines, power, negligence, etc.  Profit: business owner keeps what is left over after labor is paid for, machines are maintained, electricity is paid for and damages from other sources are all paid off.  Sorry for wall of text.  Keep up with the great content and CHALLENGE MY BIASES!  =)

Here's how we know Marx was full of shit: nothing's value is based on how much time and effort went into making it or the value of the individual parts of a product. What determines value is whatever people are willing to pay for it. I don't care if your pussy hat took you 5 hours to make and is laced with gold thread. If people don't buy it from you for $1000, it's not worth $1000. It's interesting that you shame people for buying a pizza with truffles, gold, and caviar on it and the restaurant that dares to sell such a thing, but Marxists appear completely blind to the fact that those ingredients were bought from the working class. Fishermen harvested and sold the caviar to the restaurant. Farmers harvested and sold those truffles to the restaurant. Miners harvested and sold that gold to the restaurant. Are these people also abusing the common man because how dare they not donate the products of their labor to starving kids in Africa? No, and even in a socialist society they wouldn't do that either. In fact, in a socialist society African children still wouldn't have food and neither would the farmers, fisherman, and miners.

Here's the thing, although $2000  pizzas are absurd Capitalism doesn't make many of them because people cant afford them but it does make heaps of 2$ McDonald's  burgers even if they do taste like cardboard.  A million dollar painting is obscene compared to feeding the poor its true, but it also means there are many average paintings worth $200  that give striving artists a living.  The problem with Capitalism is that if it is unregulated and continues long enough eventually all the money ends up down one end. An individual having a billion dollars in itself isn't the problem , the problem is he cant spend it all no matter how much food he eats or  clothes and cars he buys , he is forced to invest it . When too many people have this problem we have a tidal wave of money washing around the planet trying to find a place to live with the highest return.  This is so much it destroys local economies and causes housing and stock market bubbles , pushing prices up far beyond what ordinary people can pay and far beyond the underlying worth of the asset. This in turn causes market crashes and forces ordinary people to spend half their life working to pay for what should really cost them much less. The only was to solve this is to tax the rich heavily.

So, like, capitalism is a process to allocate labor, at least in theory, when labor is scarce, right?  Put value on jobs, incentivize activity, pay out the dosh, which can be used in discretionary spending, right? Or is that just economics in general?  If that's *all* capitalism is, and it says nothing about the inherent rights of those who own the means of production, and nothing about the ability to generate 'value' out of thin air, now that labor is inbelievably cheap... Is it that capitalism is flawed, or that it is no longer relevant, due to advancing technology?  Labor isn't scarce anymore. We're generating jobs just to employ people to keep the money moving.  We purposefully retain a certain level of unemployment because it destroys bargaining power of labor.  That means, this isn't the situation where capitalism is effective.  We need a new system whereby rewards are not given for labor produced, but as a means of maintaining society in a world where our labor is superfluous.    Labor is a tool, and it shouldn't be a means to survive.  It certainly isn't for the top whales, who literally generate revenue by *having money*.  You pay an investment firm to throw your money behind the right people, and you get richer just because you had the money to be rich in the first place.  Good work, well done, we're all so proud of you.  I don't know if we are following a particular process, but this is the outline of a plan.  1. Develop a new system. Figure out a system and all its intricacies that actually creates a society where abundance is shared by all, where necessary labor is performed, where helpful labor is rewarded, where people's needs are met before luxury is distributed.  I know of several proposals, but I don't know if we've yet got a cohesive plan to bulldoze the entrenched systems with.  2. Spread the idea. Once the system is ironclad, even if it moves at a glacial pace, the next goal is to propagandize it. That doesn't mean the propaganda can't have ethics to it, and, ideally, it should be open to adapting new improvements as long as they meet the same tenets laid out above, but in essentially a war for people's minds, in order to be effective, it will require some emotional and irrational propaganda.  This allows for it to develop into a movement, and as a movement, a collective bargaining tool and voting bloc.  This becomes the platform under which politicians can win, if that route is possible.  3a. Support political agents. This is really constrained by just how far the system is willing to allow a change in ideals.  It hasn't been, though this new wave of progressivism *might* be a sign that the ground is fertile for some big changes?  We can hope?  There's not that much cost in this option, so it's worthwhile no matter what happens out of it.  3b. Bring it down. This is the Tabby land.  Smash.  Not really my area of expertise, but really, when given no other options, what is one to do but build guillotines?  I'm not really versed in modern revolutionary theory or tactics, and this does potentially involve conflict with the state, which means it's going to take a LOT of really crafty strategy to even be possible.  4. Ensure the new system endures. Whether by political change or by force, the system upheaval is going to create a weaker state of being. This isn't a capture the flag that ends when the base is taken. The system will have opponents, whether it is the previous beneficiaries of labor who have been deposed, or people sympathetic to them, or those who believed themselves to be deposed despite being liberated, or those who truly believe in 'the American Dream' ideology and its cognitive dissonance.  What does this look like?  This is where I tap out, because I have no idea how to walk this line without encroaching on fascist territory, and I'm not comfortable doing that.  That's actually the biggest problem I have with any communist doctrine I've been handed before; they all suggest using force and coercion to maintain a system, and once you get that far, I'm out.

My current (novice, say-it-like-I'm-five) understanding is as follows: The free market incentivises production of stuff, which then leads to more stuff being available for everyone (and since that means more supply, there's less fighting over who gets it). But since the more stuff a person has, the easier it is for them to get more stuff, you get inequality.  Capitalism means most people are better off (Yaay!), but some people are way more betterer off (Booo!). That why I think we shouldn't get rid of capitalism, but we should keep a big social safety net (so that everyone benefits from the more stuff going around), and make the ladders up to getting more stuff easy to climb.
So if I understand you correctly... the $2 pizza is better than The Golden One.

Capitalism sucks but everything else this far attempted sucks harder. Which, as you point out, isn't to say that we can't eventually do better, but the onus is on the critics to suggest something that hasn't been tried before.   I think capitalism and it's forerunners have been so long-lived and flexible because they reflect a lot of what is probably genetically innate in us, at least over the past 10,000 years of our evolution. Nobody knows the nature/nurture split, but suffice to say it seems like we like to fight each other on every end of the earth we occur,  and we like to create hierarchies on every end of the earth where we occur. Capitalism does a good job of preventing only the strongest people from living the good life. It provides multiple avenues for various skill sets and dispositions to derive a live-able existence by exchanging what they have for what they lack.   An under class has virtually always existed in every form of economic or social organization known, so this probably reflects a behavioral tendency in our species towards binary and hierarchy. We always find a way to have a bad so that we can distinguish the good. Someone always ends up suffering unfairly or arbitrarily. I agree with you totally in seeking to reduce that as much as possible. So far it seems to me that capitalism with built in protections for those who get wrecked by it is the best option conceivable. Capitalism ain't something I'm wedded to. As you say, should the economy work for us or should we work for the economy? I say capitalism is the best way to make the economy work for us at this time. Happy for an alternative to supplant it if it can work better for us.

Tech work, like software engineering, is a form of labor that creates a ton of value, and often don't require being in charge of anyone to do so - it's not that much different of a mode of production from being a mechanic, where you just know stuff and make or fix it.  Tech workers get paid way more than most other jobs, but ironically, tech workers care a TON about open source stuff. A big job complaint is not being allowed to contribute to giving away their services for free for other people to use. Ideas about giving away all sorts of stuff for free both as in gratis and as in libre, have come from people who make more money than the general population, and from people who produce extremely valuable things.  'Why would anyone become an innovator or a researcher if they would make a good living as a janitor?' Just want to give some counter arguments. Particularly in the definition of inefficiencies associated with distributing wealth. This is an assumption that labor theory of value holds where prices were also seen as absurd. Governments throughout history have held prices constant to be met by massive reduction in production, because simply put: prices signal scarcity. The pizza in this example is priced so high because for one, gold has many industrial uses and is hard to come by. 2, the ink in the dough comes from a rare animal, that for one shouldn't be killed but hey, some people are willing to pay (and with that comes ethics). At the very least, most people are priced out of these expensive endeavors of luxury - dare I say, rightfully so. It's obscene. Nonetheless, capitalisms openess and price signaling,  yields the best outcome we know of given the context of history. Our jobs as agents in the system is to reduce profit margins and reduce costs for goods, overall. I also think looking at labor economies as a zero sum game is rather disingenuous to developing nations, as they too benefit from cutting costs.

Part of the problem with the way we tend to view insane luxuries like gold-flake pizza is that we focus on the price tag and not the direction the money is flowing. Some idiot who buys a pizza for $1000 doesn't have $1000 and a pizza, they have '-' $1000 and a pizza. The money they paid is distributed among the members of the industry who created the pizza, many of whom are much, much poorer than the idiots who can temporarily afford to buy them. With this in mind it could actually be argued that worthless luxuries actually do a great job getting money out of the hands of people who have too much money. The real issue is that a number of people with little money to spare are duped in this same way, which is where Socrates, Diogenes and many later transcendentalists assert it is necessary to question the real value of the materials we acquire from the basis that most things aren't worth the energy required to maintain them. Even if they are shiny.  I'd also like to point out that Capitalism doesn't value hard work in the sense of manual labour, and doing so would be totally absurd as a model for investing wealth. Typically in economics the idea is to pay the 'least' for manual labour, and on the part off industrialists is this model of paying the least that has driven businesses to increase the use of mechanization in place of manual labour. It is likely that any attempt to increase the amount paid to labourers will also increase the rate at which industrialists pursue mechanization - which I'm all for, but it won't actually solve the initial problem of poor labourers getting enough money to get by. Capitalism rewards smart work, not hard work. To most people suffering is not a valuable commodity. Reducing suffering is.

One big problems with capitalism regarding efficiency is that while competition breeds innovation, economic imbalance causes it to also breed waste.  Poor people can't afford the most economically efficient versions of things (due to higher cost), so they're forced to buy inferior products, which do not last.  In the long run, they spend more money than they would have, had they been able to afford the most cost effective (but more expensive) items.  This wastes resources, and drives prices up (because it creates more scarcity).

Capitalism isn't the real problem.  Unfettered capitalism is.  Capitalism is great at generating wealth.  But it's just an economic system.  In the USA, we've treated it like it's a form of government, or worse yet, in the past 20-30 years, like a religion.  Capitalism + regulation + social democratic government = prosperity for most, progressive safety net for those that fall through the cracks.
