Capitalism's great strength is that it is very nimble.  Imagine that there are ten different kinds of cars. There are pickup trucks, jeeps, sedans, coupes, and so on, and maybe alternate versions of each of these. How many of each should be produced each year? How should that vary from year to year? Where should they all be shipped? These are quite difficult questions to answer for a small group of people working together, a car planning committee, who have to make guesses like how much hauling a family in a particular area has to do, and which families need larger and more expensive to make vehicles, and which only need smaller coupes.   What makes it much easier is the introduction of personal choice to this equation, where each person or family asks for a particular car, but again, people being people, everyone is likely to want one of the more expensive vehicles to make. So, we sweeten the deal - take a coupe instead of a hummer, and we'll give you more of other things at another time. By far the easiest and most direct way to measure this is with money. Flawed or unpopular cars will lose sales to cars that are a better value to people over time, and those car companies can buy out the factories the old ones were made in easily enough. It responds dynamically to people, and gives them a sense of agency in their lives.   So, you've probably considered by now, why not give everyone the exact same amount of money, and have all corporations be state-owned, but still compete with one another this way? Suppose that we had a really great engineer named Sam. Now, she's not some 'great woman' who will revolutionize everything, she's just, you know, really great, probably one of the top 5 employees at the company she works for. Sam might have a passion for designing big, powerful cars, and in an equal pay society, she might choose to do that. It might be in society's best interest, though, that Sam works on a new airliner, something to help bring cheap air travel to the emerging markets in India, China, and South Africa. Knowing that Sam switching over for the 6 month project might save humanity, say, $200 million over the life of the plane, a number should be offered to her up to that figure that would get her attention on the project, because it would help the most people be the most happy. That, in and of itself, creates huge inequality, but it does so by raising one person very far, not lowering anyone else.  It's also worth noting that the investor class is an artifact of this system, not it's engine. The big piles of money that are thrown around by their stockbrokers  do serve a valuable purpose in refining new technologies, but they don't. If most of the profit went to the government instead of the investor, it wouldn't really change how the stockbroker evaluates companies and makes trades, or any part of the useful functions of the stock market. Other than a fear of capital flight, there's no real reason not to tax the investor class extremely highly.  The real issue, as I see it, is the conflation of capitalism with austerity in the public mindset. There's nothing about this process that requires the poor to suffer. The government could very easily send a monthly welfare check to everyone alive, and also let them work to earn more, and people would still opt to drive coupes, and Sam would still build our airplane. If anything, it'd be much more likely, since there would be a lot more people for whom air travel is affordable, but not easily, so the potential profit from such a plane would be much higher, and it would create much more happiness. Arguably, high taxes do generate some efficiency losses, because if Sam is taxed 80% and would have only switched to planes if it would have earned her more than $50 million after taxes, and that does cost society money, but it's fair to balance that loss against the gains in stability, happiness, and consumer power. This type of 'Social Capitalism' is still capitalism, but it's a better capitalism, one we can feel proud of.  If you're fortunate enough to live in a Western nation that isn't the United States, you likely have a major party you can vote for that would define itself as a social capitalist party. In the United States, there are politicians within the Democratic party who want to see the party move in that direction. If this is an issue you're passionate enough about to protest, your goals should be to attend every primary election you can to try to reform the Democratic party towards this end, and to try to talk about the advantages we'd share under a system like that.

It sounds like your argument here hinges, to some extent,  on wealth being interchangeable with income. I could write (and have written) a thousand-word tract on this point, but that's irritating for everyone to read.  The main thing is, income and wealth aren't really the same thing. Wealth is income retained and/or put into appreciating assets. If the problem is a disparity in wealth, that's easily fixed with a bit of financial education on how to budget, save your money, and not get swindled by fees and interest rates, along with other basic financial literacy info.  If the problem is income inequality, then accounting standards have to change. Accountants are the ones determining what to pay people based on the value they provide. This is a point that seems to be missed a lot in this conversation. If necessary jobs can't earn a living wage, then either the dollar needs to deflate or be replaced, or accounting standards need to change.  Boiling the capitalist structure down to 'stuff is good' seems a bit misguided, as succeeding within the structure of capitalism is more about avoiding the stuff that's being advertised to you and instead buying the place that sells the stuff and getting a cut of the profits that the stuff earned. That and not spending your money over a long period of time. That's what I've heard from the rich people, at any rate.  I haven't been especially convinced that the problem of happiness in relation to money is caused by the inherent structure of capitalism so much as it is caused by 70% of the population being financially illiterate and not saving money until their mid-30s.   Internet disagreements and Youtube comments aside, I hope you're having a lovely day! This was a good video, and I enjoyed watching it.

Contrapoints, I'm a big fan of your stuff, but you are wrong here.  I'd love to hear your thoughts on my point of view.  Basically, you seem to subscribe to the same utilitarian worldview that I do; that economic systems exist to promote happiness.  However, where you miss the ball is in your 'moral maths'; you fail to take into account the happiness of future generations.  It is a well known fact that overall, socialist systems (I'm not talking Denmark, I mean actual socialism) have less strong economic growth than capitalist ones.  Even if, in the short term, the more equitable distribution of wealth results in greater utility, in the long run the growth rate is what is most important.  If we implemented socialism right now, we might delay important innovations such as (for example) curing diseases, improving computing power and AI, and making farming more efficient.  So, in the long run, socialist systems lead to a decrease in living standards relative to capitalist ones, thereby decreasing utility.  This is, of course, predicated on the idea that you have an obligation to future generations, but I think it's fairly obvious that we have at least some duty to them.

Constructive feedback: Firstly, overall, good video. Thought about things from a new angle, was entertained. You're awesome, thank you for doing what you do.  I saw that you got some twitter replies saying that the introduction to the video felt slow and/or unnecessary. Reading that after having first watched the video, I agreed that the beginning felt a little slow, and thought you'd said 'I'm a dumb-dumb who likes shiny things' a few more times than was necessary. Now that I'm re-watching, I can't identify anything that could have been cut, because I think everything in the first half does add usefully to the video.  I did feel some confusion over whether you were playing yourself or a character. At the beginning I thought I was seeing a character, but then you went back to your normal voice and the video continued and I concluded you had to be playing yourself. I think I prefer it when there is a clear distinction between characters. 'I'm a dumb-dumb who likes shiny things' also added to the confusion. Clearly you like shiny things, and I would not dispute that. However I do NOT think that you are a dumb-dumb at all. I understand that you're probably using that as a deflection technique but I felt the need to say that I object to you calling yourself a dumb-dumb. Of course you don't have all the answers. Nobody does, and I respect you more for admitting it.   I would have found it helpful if you'd added a horizontal line at $75,000 on the graph at 10:32, so that we could easily see what was above and below the happiness threshold.  It might have been better to use a graph which showed the income distribution at a particular time (with household income on the X axis and frequency on the Y axis, to give a bell curve or whatever distribution US income has). That kind of graph would have the drawback that people would argue you had picked an anomalous year, but on the other hand some people don't have the maths knowledge to easily understand what a difference between mean and median implies. Showing trends over time didn't really relate to your point, and people might draw conclusions about things getting worse that aren't necessarily applicable because that graph doesn't seem to account for inflation and I doubt we have happiness/income data from 1980. A graph showing how far the upper tail of the income distribution extends beyond $75,000 would have helped to illustrate the point you made at 10:57.  When you mentioned video games you could have made a point about how annoying microtransations are.  Finally, I did rather enjoy being called a filthy Q, so thanks for that ;)

Marx believed that man would 'evolve' into a socialist, yet you still like shiny things. You like shiny things because you reject higher knowledge beyond the empirical. If all that can be known must be seen and measured, then you have created the axis on which value is determined. Secularism is capitalism. Marx tried to interject a secular framework for morality which could be solved by economics. This is a fool's errand. The reality of the world is that shiny things have been bartered for a very long time, and will continue to do so if the predominant worldview is one of empirical values in which no higher knowledge can be obtained. His distaste for Christianity was to some degree a form of jealousy, that within that framework was a way to manipulate the value of goods out of the market system by inverting the perceived value of having profane wealth, vanity, and worldliness. Marx could never achieve this by mathematical means, he could never justify *not wanting a gold Lamborghini* beyond an appeal to empathy toward an undefined poor person who could have benefited. But to what is the poor person owed money? What empirical value is there for empathy? You only live for a few decades, why bother? Keep in mind, this is the worldview that the United States wants to export to the middle east. They will help those meek savages by shoving them into the total market economy of Jeff Bezos and A.I. algorithms, so that they too can complain about how they like shiny things but never have enough money, and no means of actually changing the system within its framework. This is of course called 'exporting democracy.'

I feel like, begrudgingly, that I must defend life in Socialist Russia and Maoist China. You'd probably be fine living in either, except for circumstances that weren't economic at all. Our associations of Stalin's time should always be considered in the context of a Nazi invasion that killed 40 million Russians, for example. You wouldn't want to live in 1941 USSR, nobody would, because it was facing a Nazi extermination campaign. Instead, you should compare these countries in peaceful times, although those can be hard to come by (Thanks, Capitalism!). Life in the USSR vs life in the US in the 1960s, for example, could be nearly identical, if you were part of a nuclear family. Similar luxury goods, movie theaters and tv and radio and novels (and no, they were not obligated to be propaganda, they were obligated to NOT be Capitalist propaganda). You wake up, you eat breakfast, you go to work, come home, consume some media or hang out with friends, and then go to bed. The big differences would instead be the far greater access of non-nuclear family living situations. Apartment buildings with communal kitchens and group meals were common, for example.  Mothers had no financial coercion to stay with a shitty baby daddy, so single mothers were far more common than in the US.  I understand this instinct to say 'I'm not absurdist left, I'm reasonable left!' but the arguments/dismissals used to express that are too often useless or even actively counterproductive. Seeing life in Communist countries as being miserable and not worth living is a big part of the ole Capitalist propaganda playbook.

Great video Contra! But let me push back on the thesis of this video a bit: that these are inherently flaws to capitalism.  First, let me just say that I'm not talking about really existing capitalism in the US. That shit's trash. I'm merely talking about any system where the means of production are mostly privately owned, there's wage labor, and a profit motive. Let's also add this in: because governments exist, all wealth is accessible. In other words, the government can tax whatever it wants however much it wants (theoretically, of course). And as you stated, capitalism produces the most wealth. So, assuming a good government, that means capitalism makes the most wealth possible for redistribution. Obviously, I'll now bring up Nordic countries: the happiest, most equal, and most democratic countries in the world. They are not communist by any means: rather, they tax at a very high rate, and redistribute wealth through strong social welfare programs.  This seems like the best system to me, producing the most wealth for as many people as possible. Obviously, there's a lot more complexity to the Nordic model, but that's the gist. So yes, your points about the profit motive ruining creativity and making people feel empty are well-taken. But it's the system of government that determines whether this leads to massive inequality or not.

I think that the problem with taking down capitalism as a whole is that the golden pizza is offensive to almost everyone. Apart from the people who profit off of the spectacle of being bourgeois (a la Trump), the majority of the actual bourgeoisie would be equally appalled by the golden pizza, and I think that's precisely the same logic that lets them justify their own place of structural power. See most people, no matter how rich they are, feel financial pressure, they feel as if they are using their disposable income to better their family's lives. Most Americans, I think, see displays of wealth as a noveau rich thing, or as something to do when you're not actually that rich, and moreover, most wealthy people see their wealth as the means of making their children's lives better. Therefore, the golden pizza seems equally appalling to the rich, but it's not because it reveals the emptiness of wealth, but because it points at the fact that the wealth enable indulgence, which is an uncomfortable reality when your entire world view is of being 'upper middle class, but still things are tight sometimes' like the top 20-5% of income earners probably feel. No one feels rich. No one, apart from people who are realllly at the top, would say they can afford to drop 2 grand on a pizza. And it's not those really at the top that lobby against school integration, that drive the exclusionary structure of suburbs, that hold the majority of electoral power, it's that top 20%.    So, the problem comes -- how do you convince people to struggle against capital when they see their own capital not as a luxury but as a hard won means of securing their children's future?   I think if you said to the average American -- 'we're going to have communism', their first question would be 'will I get to keep my house?'.

Great production as usual. Fundamentally flawed argument, ...as usual.  Fact 1: if it wasn't for capitalism a normal pizza would cost around $1,000! Let's say $10/hour for about 1,000 hours to plant, harvest and mill the grain, plant harvest and prepare tomatoes, cheese, etc., etc.,. But thanks to capitalism a pizza costs the average person about the same as s/he could earn in the time it takes to eat it and the pizza is far better quality than a single person could hope to produce in 1'000 hours of effort.  Fact 2: Re capitalism and the 'exploitation' of people in 3rd world countries. Capitalism targets _and finds_ the poorest people in the world and gives them money in exchange for work. It doesn't force them but gives them the choice of working although you will argue that they are in no position to negotiate the fact is that they are better off working than not. The only failure of capitalism (and every other mechanism we know of) is that it can't reach the parts of the world that are not stable enough for anyone to risk investing (capitalism) to build factories.

DISREGARD MARX.  Acquire Nitzan and Bichler.  Their capital-as-power framework supersedes both Marxian and neoclassical schools of political economy, exposing their underlying supernaturalism. Both assume that prices are like a distorted reflection of some non-material substance called 'value'. Marxians say this value comes from socially-necessary labour. Neoclassicals say it comes from subjective utility vs scarcity. They get the whole thing upside-down.  In reality, prices aren't a reflection of anything. There is no 'real' price of a good that's separate from the 'nominal' price. The only thing prices represent is the power of the price-makers, most of whom are capitalists. The agency for setting prices lies solely with them, not in some spectral realm of 'value' composed of either labour or utility.   In other words, money is power - not only metaphorically, but literally. Money is a technology for 'controlling human mobilisation', getting people to do one thing versus a different thing.   Correspondingly, capital is not the 'bottom-up' creation of either labour or utility, it's the 'top-down' creation of the powerful. Capital is the symbolic quantification of the power held by capitalists to control the social fabric.

I'll play devil's advocate here:  > 'The extreme economic inequalities of society are laughably unjustifiable'  What makes them unjustifiable? In what sense? If an economic system exists, and that existence breads such inequality, what is unjustifiable about it? It just is. Are floods that kill people 'unjustifiable'? They are just a force of nature that exist, and while it kills some people, its source (rain, rivers, etc) also provides irrigation for crops that make humanity possible. If we assume an economy can't be micromanaged and controlled in a way that it can actually work, isn't the only way to think about it as a 'force of nature' that we just try to control as much as we can?   Just like a flood is not 'unjustifiable', but it sucks and we try our hardest to control it and prevent it (e.g building dams, building better alerting systems, and more); maybe economic inequalities aren't 'unjustifiable', but they suck and we can try our hardest to control and prevent them. But just like we don't try to devise a new global irrigation system to replace rains and rivers (because we'd suck at it and fuck up the world), we wouldn't completely replace the complex capitalistic economic system with a new one like communism/socialism/etc (because we'd suck at it and fuck up society and the economy, and there have been plenty of such examples so far). Makes sense?  > 'Capitalism as we know it is a defective economic system because, although it's good at creating large amounts of wealth it distributes wealth in an incredibly inefficient way (not the capacity to maximize total wealth, but the capacity to maximize human happiness)'  Is it just for an economic system to determine how wealth is distributed? There are a lot of other concepts involved in an economy other than just 'create wealth' and 'distribute wealth'. You have concepts like rights; property (private and public, personal and non-personal, etc); freedom; voluntary choice; coercion; etc, which aren't just related to economy. You know, like what the 'taxation is theft!' people always talk about. You can't just say 'Oh, this economic system distributes wealth in a way I like' and call it quits; if it contradicts other principles and becomes unjust then you have to think of something else.  > 'Should the economy serve humanity, or should humanity serve the economy?'  Does the economy even have a possibility to (successfully) do anything else other than serve itself (and only serve humanity incidentally)? Again, just like rains and rivers don't serve anybody other than themselves (and that's their only purpose), but humans devise ways for it to serve us; the economy only serves itself, and we humans devise ways for it to serve us too (usually with the involvement of the state, but other times via culture, via social movements, etc).  > 'A good economic system produces the most happiness for the people who are a part of it'  Utilitarianism vs deontologism. If a system 'produces the most happiness for the people who are part of it', but it came to fruition by an act that we'd call unjust (or it perpetuates unjust acts), is it still the right system?  Is there a way for a different economic system to replace capitalism that 'produces the most happiness for the people who are part of it', but does so justly, without breaking any human rights, without needing any immoral act (e.g stealing, forcing someone to do something against their will, etc), and it ending up working in the end?   Most criticisms of 'replacing capitalism' (usually with communism/socialism) fall under that umbrella: They are either unjust systems, or the process of going from capitalism to them involves unjust acts (the other criticisms being that they don't work, but well that's specific to the system in question, it's not general)

'Let's throw philosophy in the trash' - *proceeds to drop a shelf of clearly unread books on the floor*  Mate, maybe if you actual read the old wisdom, you would find it helpful. You can't reasonably claim that philosophy is nothing besides confusing jargon, when it is abundantly clear you haven't read the works.  If you don't want a $2000 pizza, don't buy it. Capitalism allows you to vote with your wallet. If you do want the golden pizza, and you value the experience more than $2000, you buy it, and guess what, the vendor values that same pizza at less than $2000, you just experience the virtue of capitalism: positive sum interaction. So wouldn't the implication of wanting/waiting to see capitalism fail be to oppose anything that makes it stable, like financial regulation?  Or would the failure of capitalism produce a power vacuum for the most awful, reactionary forces around?   Or is the problem not 'capitalism' as if it were some kind of monolith, but about the balance between/aspects of capitalism and socialism?  I think the case you're making is against NEOLIBERAL capitalism, not capitalism overall.    Capitalism is good because it provides for markets, allows for flexibility, and gives people the psychological security derived from ownership.  Socialism is good because it reins in our worst insticts and ensures a minimum standard of living.  Capitalism and socialism need one another for balance.  The problem is that neoliberal capitalism is so unbalanced in the direction of capitalism, not that capitalism is inherently bad.

Economic and governance systems as they exist in reality are far too complex to be considered puuuuurely 'capitalist' or 'socialist' by theoretical standards and academic (or armchair in this case) dichotomization of these systems underrate the efficacy and power of the emergent systems which exist today. And attempts to create such pure markets tend to just end in totalitarianism for a multitude of reasons. Just as the fact that some of our taxes go to welfare doesn't make this Socialist society -just because a state owns all of the legitimate business within their reach doesn't entail a purely Communist society.

Not to be that kind of person, but there actually is a section in Kropotkin's A Conquest of Bread where he outlines how much people value luxury and how it's important to keep that in mind when modeling an egalitarian society. Art, science, pleasure, all of it is important. Anarchists in particular, Goldman included, do take personal expression very seriously. I think some 'socialists' on the internet fall into conforming to some weird Stalinist viewpoint when they really don't need to.

I am a big fan of your work, but I was honestly disappointed. The first video on this was quite brilliant, and I have watched it multiple times. This one didn't seem to address much anything too new from the previous video and videos you've made in the past that weren't directly related to capitalism. I think you could have put significantly more emphasis on how 'stuff' isn't necessarily a product of capitalism, but rather a product of labor. Labor has existed since before capitalism and will exist after capitalism, so 'stuff' will always exist. Maybe this stuff will be different, but it will exist. I did like the point about Tetris as I didn't actually know that came out of the Soviet Union. I think you could have put more examples of this.  I also was largely let down with Tatiana Tankikova. She to me looked like a brilliant new character on part with Tabby Catgirl. However, leaving her entire role as an extremely small seen saying she'd defend Stalin and calling you a fascist was a let off. I think it's fair acknowledging their were some really horrific things that happened in early socialist states, but it may have been a good opportunity to have Tatiana explain some of the positives that may have come from the Soviet Union, China, Cuba, etc. We both know they exist. The idea being we take the things that they did right or had good ideas and discard the obvious failures for how we plan a future socialist society.  The other thing is something that tbf you've touched on quite a bit on other videos and I think that may have been why you left it out. I think you could have made some good points on how while electoral politics aren't revolutionary they may at least allow us to avoid it getting worse and even shift the Overton Window to the left. More left leaning countries almost always have stronger communist parties. That really does help no matter how much the elitist wanna disagree. You could have also pointed out certain ideas such as that Yanis Varoufakis has spoken of which will allow a steady transition in to communism as automation takes place. I believe the idea is to tax corporations and the wealthy significantly higher than they currently are where this money then goes into a fund which will be used for a substantial UBI in the future making work unnecessary for the majority of the population once automation reaches certain stage of efficiency. I did really enjoy the jokes at the end with Tabby. That was genuinely cleverly done and is one reason why she's such a great character. I hope to see her back and would like to see some expansion to the character of Tatiana.  I really do like your videos, so I hope I wasn't being too harsh. You still make among the best leftist videos on youtube, and I think you're are doing amazing work of both informing people on these topics as well as making them entertaining.

I never expected a look at capitalism's focus on profits over creativity/innovation/people to use the goddamned golden pizza as an example of not only capitalism placing way too much value on a shitty pizza but also as a means to symbolize how utterly stagnant the whole industry is since people think that being bad with designing opulence (or not tapping into what made the good opulence acceptable) is what makes for acceptable opulence, i.e. why movie sequels have to be more bigger, better, more expensive, etc.

That was fun. As for capitalism, it IS the best thing anyone's come up with... so far. But we're in that late period where the bloom on the rose is well-and-truly faded, and it's hard to deny the disparity between the 'haves' and the 'have-nots.' But before anyone rolls the dice on another 'Storming Of The Bastille' that may or may not end up all murder-y and dictator-y (remember, the ten years after the French Revolution were called 'The Reign Of Terror,' which only ended when a military-bigwig from Corsica wanted to start stomping around Europe pretending to be Alexander The Great), remember that art and entertainment make life worth living, and it shouldn't really matter if the intent of a given work was to 'sell you' on something.  I love 'Transformers: The Movie.' Yes, it's a junky 90-minute toy commercial, but it also tells a cogent and interesting war-narrative about youth surviving and even thriving in the face of upheaval and even apocalypse. So yeah... I consider it a work of art, even if its original intent was to sell 4-year-old me a truck that turns into a robot.

Capitalism is apparently really inept at providing voice lessons to trannies and can do little more than make poor efforts at a generic falsetto only part of the time. What it is apparently phenomenal at is allocating enough R&D funding to tranny surgical operations as well as medical talent to perform such operations as well as the infrastructure needed to make sure that people don't die in the process.  ...As for happiness, Jonathan Haidt's research suggests that impoverished prostitutes in India report only marginally lower ratings of life satisfaction than people from wealthy countries. We tend to perceive happiness and life satisfaction based on upswings and downswings. There's the oft repeated example of where someone who wins the lottery vs becoming paralyzed wouldn't be appreciably happier in either case after roughly one year passes after the events.  So what does this all mean? Possibly that felicity isn't the only aspect of human well-being and that happiness as a condition is dependent on things secular to economics. Therefore it doesn't really make that much to argue for or against capitalism on grounds of reported levels of life-satisfaction, rather it's better to gauge whether capitalism is more or less desirable based on which countries people are most willing to move to and least willing to leave of their own volition. When we stop comparing capitalism to authoritarian communist regimes and start comparing it with its potential, we can move past capitalism.

Great video! Wish there was more of Tatiana.  Also I think you're mistaken when you say that capitalism is inefficient. Capitalism is really really efficient at what it's supposed to do. And it does that really really well. And that is not to maximise happiness or freedom for all but to maximise profits.  Capitalism never was, never is, or never will be about anything other than profit margin, specifically maximising that profit margin. Everything else is just a side-effect, intended or unintended.  Which is one of the reasons why we need to do away with it. Capitalism's objectives are not in line with the objectives of the people. Happiness, freedom, glamour, whatever are all secondary to the primary goal of the system of capitalism, while for humans the happiness, the freedom, the having stuff, having shiny stuff part is the primary goal.  What matters to people is access to what they need, the stuff. But under capitalism access is regulated and limited. This is because Capitalism instead prioritises the profitability part. We don't give everyone gold nails cuz we physically can't, but because its 'unprofitable'.  Capitalism must go, and if we sit around and wait for things to change it'll be too late. We're on the clock; saving the environment isn't particularly profitable as nature doesn't pay you for not destroying her. In fact it's the opposite, exploiting natural resources is profitable. So if we don't stop capitalism soon it'll be too late for us to have stuff like stable climactic conditions conducive to the continual progress of human technological civilisation.  It's a huge misconception that capitalism is about happiness from stuff, it's about how to profit off of giving you the stuff.

What can possibly be achieved by revolution that can't be achieved by democracy in this country? With enough popular backing, communists could overtake and amend the Constitution. And frankly, I think it's a horrible idea and would inevitably go wrong. We shouldn't be engaging in country-wide communist experience in the US; way too much could go wrong so why not try a smaller country? And revolution just increases the chances things will go horribly wrong.  Why can't we change gradually? Most changes are destined to fail, and I think we are best off by going slowly and filtering out the bad policies over time. And this is sort of what you recommend we do while we are awaiting the conditions for communist revolution. The irony is that, if effective, those slower changes will weaken the need and urgency felt for revolution; although personally, I view this as a good thing.  But I would go one step further and say we shouldn't just support policies that appear on the surface to lessen income inequality. This is essentially the purpose of economics. In fact, studies about what level of money promotes happiness is part of economics. Economics isn't fundamentally about how to produce the most money. In practice, it often is about exactly that, but the core of economics is in utility, whether we define that as human happiness, or meaning and fulfillment, or whatever. I think that only game in town is to gradually use the tools of science and rational thinking to approach more effective institutions for maximizing utility. It's far from perfect, but I see everything else as a short-sighted shortcut.   Ultimately, are lives could be vastly transformed by the existence of superhuman artificial intelligence, which could be with us sooner than expected. It's possible that levels as high as 90% unemployment will ensue as artificial intelligence exceeds the ability of humans at both manual and intellectual labor. Wealth could increase exponentially, and inequality will hit unprecedented levels, and we will be forced as a society to completely restructure, likely moving towards a more communistic model. So if we are waiting for anything, we are waiting for that.

The most important part of this video, I think, was that Contra managed to bridge the gap between the boring academic definition of 'use value and exchange value', and brought it to a real world example by usage of the golden pizza analogy. She also did this with the profit motive churning out hundreds of boring sequels, in essence stifling creativity, although this was already common knowledge.  This sort of thing, I think, should be what every leftist should strive for, to bridge the gap between the boring academic jargon and the common day-to-day observations we make. I would love to see more of this sort of stuff, where people take critiques of capitalism that exist only in books, and find ways to make them relatable to everyday people.   We need to build up our vocabulary in a more accessible direction.

I would take qualms with your argument that capitalism is defective because it distributes that wealth in an inefficient way. The first lie of bourgeois economics is that capitalism is a system of distribution. With this lie, then a comparison of the systems can take place. But the systems can't really be compared because a comparison implies a commonality. The purpose of capitalism is to augment money, to make more money from the money one has. The purpose of a planned economy is to meet needs. The truth is that in a market economy nobody coordinates, no one worries about the needs of others (only insofar as they can be exploited to make a sale). Market subjects have other concerns in mind when they get to producing. Everyone offers something on the market and the whole coordination consists of whether the salesman has success or not. If the salesman has success, he has success; if not, then he takes his unsold things home with him and cannot sell them. Where is there any coordination? One hits on a solvent need and by chance has success; another strikes out and fails, possibly even becomes destitute due to his failed attempt to produce and sell. Only: what is coordinated here? Nothing at all is coordinated here! In truth, the alleged service of coordination/distribution does not take place, because needs are actually not respected at all. A seller looks for a solvent demand; needs that are not backed up by money do not count as needs and therefore go unmet. The market does not coordinate existing needs and production, but the salesman in the market sees what solvent needs can be taken advantage of. And also, the other way around, for the buyer on a trip to the market, the need itself does not guide his decision to purchase, but what he actually gets is the commodity he can afford in keeping with his wallet. Whether he buys those things that he then buys because he perhaps can't afford better, so that instead of the quality product he buys trash, or whether his need goes completely neglected - this is very much the question. With the whole coordination, on one side stands production, which never wants to meet needs, and on the other hand stands not needs at such, but purchasing power.

I love that Contra flips 'the noble savage' to be 'the noble rich person' who does brain surgery for the love and betterment of humanity. As if a shitty position is a good position if you retarget it at someone else.

One question always pressed is 'who will do the shitty jobs in a post-capitalist world?' A contradiction lies in peoples' unconscious minds, especially those who pose the question. If you look at the 'shitty' jobs compared to the 'non-shitty' jobs (paralleling with blue collar to white collar jobs) most of the shitty ones pay less. That means that there's something intrinsic to peoples' motivation to the shitty jobs. They like doing them. We need to wake ourselves up to the revelation that many people actually like their work. Being that we're nurtured into capitalism, it may be difficult to understand. We're told that we have to be driven to work, motivated with abstract rewards and frightened with discipline. Even if not everyone is equipped to doing particular jobs, anyone can be made to understand the joy of seeing the direct impact their labor has on society. This is why the major drive into the white collar 'non-shitty' jobs has to be money. Polls show that a big chunk of the workforce think the world will do without their work or a significant portion of it. That's the non-shitty well paid sector. Suddenly it seems as though the shitty and non-shitty labels should be reversed. Low paying jobs that vench off further from the capitalist model of short term self gain will contain a negative stigma around them and be made to seem like the natural order is that no one would be willing to do them. The higher you go up the ladder and closer to the core of this system (capital and profit) the more you have to be 'driven' to do your idiotic pointless work and the more willing you are to continue the cycle onto others (through fashionable consumption). We need to be disciplined in some way under capitalism. If you enjoy the production aspect of your life, you're gonna be in a rough deal in terms of the consumption aspect, and visa verca. Of course there are exceptions as there are well off people who do enjoy what they do, but I still stress these are exceptions.

Eh a technocratic socialism is something I can get behind. Efficiency in doing things is a pretty admirable thing to aspire for humanity to achieve however maybe we don't wanna invest resources into doing extremely terrible things as efficiently as possible. Like I theorise that there is this limit breaking point with capitalism, where the downtrodden unwashed masses become washed and educated but nevertheless downtrodden. A state that exists in constant oppression but that actual oppression is so benign that people resign themselves to their fates. A freedom in a cage scenario. A permanent dictatorship without a coup or revolution. A cultural stopping point that dooms humanity forever by making us noncompetitive and dull, void of ambition. This system cannot be achieved until there is a one world government be it a loose confederation of mutually beneficial trading partners or an actual top down system. I don't think smashing the fash will stop this happening. I actually only see it increasing the speed it happens. I think the only way we do get around this end game point is taking active roles in our respective governments and energising the entire human race so we see the larger picture without giving into authoritarianism. This however increases unification and therefore makes this cultural dead end more likely. Perhaps a solution is a return to a citystate model. Where every city is unified together to be the best city it can possibly be and compete with other cities for glory. This fragmented unity may actually be the safest route to an efficient system. So perhaps the best way forward is a decentralised government that doesn't have the power to ruin the human race's potential while still prioritising efficiency.

There is perhaps a misnomer with the title of 'Capitalism'.  Most people do not strive for capital or increase their capital. People muddle through their lifes trying to make it better. One of the undeniable factors in the improvement of peoples lives is the celebration and entrenchment of Bourgeois Virtues/markets (I highly recommend Deirdre McCloskey book series of the same name.)  Which is what I think ContraPoints hits on here.   So the fundamental question to me is how do we preserve markets and address inequalities?  Because a lot of the perversions we see today are functions of government/state power (not making a libertarian argument).  The golden pizza is stupid but the prison for profit complex is criminal.

There's an inadequacy to the way you address the problems with previous non-capitalist regimes. Until you or someone else develops an alternative, communism and capitalism are the only economic systems which societies can choose. We can't be certain that nothing of that sort will ever be proposed, and it might be good to keep the problems with capitalism from fading from our minds in case that ever happens, but nothing of apparent merit has been so far. As it stands, the only alternative to capitalism is a regime similar to the soviet union, Cuba, or any number of other communist dystopias.  And no, socialism is not that alternative. That word is used in so many different ways by so many different people that it's effectively meaningless, but everything I've ever heard called socialism was either a highly regulated form of capitalism or simply communism.  I don't like any of these conclusions, by the way. Feel free to educate me.

Very strange that you actually make videos explaining white nationalist talking points to 'debate' them but immediately dismiss and denounce 'Stalin defenders' as a joke. Past communist countries were not 'shitty'. In fact they were far better for the poorest members of society than any capitalist country. The Soviet Union provided universal education, healthcare, and employment. Wealth was distributed incredibly fairly, with the top 10% not ever 'owning' much more than 20% of the wealth. No individual could personally accumulate and control billions of dollars worth of wealth. There were also no economic 'crises' in the usual sense of the term. Production was carried out primarily on the basis of need rather than profit. The millions of women who were plunged into unemployment and poverty and forced into prostitution after the overthrow of the Soviet system probably wouldn't take too kindly to calling the society which prevented such social ills 'shitty'. Pretty sure a majority of sex trafficked women in Europe come from the former socialist bloc of countries in the east. If the system was so 'shitty', why did it's overthrow lead to that? A majority of soviet citizens voted to KEEP the Soviet Union in 1991. Their voices were ignored by the likes of Yeltsin whose political rise was bank rolled by America.  Why dismiss these arguments and historical facts as a damn joke but take nazis seriously ?? Also, fun fact: STALINS SOVIET UNION STOPPED THE FUCKING NAZIS!!!!!!

I think your approach to understanding Soviet or Chinese communism is flawed. The problems you portray with these societies were not caused by communism, they existed before communism in these places. Austerity, scarcity, conformity, etc were more present in Tsarist Russia or Japanese-occupied China than the societies that succeeded them. In every way Soviet communism was an improvement for the Soviet Union, a region that, when founded in 1922, was almost entirely agrarian and extremely underdeveloped. Fast forward 40 years and they were an industrialized nation with a drastically higher standard of living, rate of literacy, full employment, and record breaking scientific accomplishments (first nation in space, anyone?)   It's a common liberal tendency to compare everything to the United States, forgetting that, globally speaking, there are entire capitalist continents that would have viewed life in the post-40's Soviet Union as paradise. Liberals compare communism to a handful of countries in the imperialist core that were wealthy long before communism emerged in the east, exclusively in poor, commonly semi-feudal societies. Marxists understand the development of society as a historical process, one which soviet communism drove forward at one of the fastest rates in history.   Of course these places weren't perfect, they had many defects, as any experimental system would. But to ignore their accomplishments and throw them out with the bath water because of their (often exaggerated) mistakes does nothing for us.

While pointing out these unmatchings between generation of wealth and overall human happiness is spot on, I don't know any way to give an answer to this concern. The only thing I know is something called the universal basic income model. Basically, if a country has enough money from the start (good luck on that btw, which is a huge obstacle in its way), this model proposes that you just give enough money to everyone in order for them to have their basic living costs covered. Studies actually found that giving money to poor people generally doesn't lead them to buying more alcohol or drugs. Giving free money to people may boost their productivity, but then again this is still built on capitalism's roots. Would be fun to hear what you think about this.
